All Reviews

  1. This shaves CLOSE! I also like it that I can see the percentage of charge. Reviews said it was good--smoked prior Norelco (glad it got lost). Quality. Tried to pick up another for one of my sons but the price went up about $39. I didn't realize I got such a good original deal.
  2. Excellent electric razor. Very close shave with a swivel head that can follow the curves of your face. Battery lasts about 2 weeks.
  3. I much prefer the Panasonics to all the other shavers I've used, including high-end Norelco and Braun. Apparently the skin on my throat is VERY sensitive, since a blade - ANY blade when I try to get very close - leaves me covered with dots of blood to be followed the next day by spots of infection.<br /><br />The weak point, for me, with the Panasonics is the little spring-loaded plastic tabs on either side. Eventually they give way. And, though the mechanics of the shaver are fine, if the head won't stay on, it's not of much use. Would be nice if they were replaceable!<br /><br />The other 'problem' I've encountered is a leakage of something appearing to be oil under the soft rubbery plastic on the handle. It appears to me the lifespan of one of these shavers, given these two factors, is only a few years.<br /><br />But, would I buy this again? Yup. Works very well.<br /><br />NO shaver that has claimed to be a 'single pass' shaver IS - at least not for me. At 66, my beard is much thinner than at 21 - which has its benefits. But even at that, stretching the skin and multiple passes is required! This Panasonic is no exception. But it is GENTLE and of course powerful.
  4. I agree this is a great electric razor but it isn't perfect. It still leaves hairs on me after several passes so I am not sure if I am doing something wrong? I have tried with shaving cream and pulling my skin but with shaving cream you can't see if you got the hair.
  5. I have a light beard, but I still need to shave every day to try to look somewhat civilized. I used an electric shaver for several years before switching to blades about 10 years ago, which were faster and closer than my old Norelco electric razor. However, I recently developed some sort of allergic reaction to the lubricating bar that now comes on Gillette blades, specifically itching on my neck and chin. So when I saw that Amazon had the Panasonic ES-LA63-S on a \\"Today's Deals\\" sale for $99.99, I decided to give it a try. Glad I did!<br /><br />The Panasonic shaves me very quickly, very closely, and very comfortably -- better in all respects than the blades I was using. It's light and easy to hold, and the head pivots to follow the contours of my face. It charges quickly -- one hour from zero to a full charge -- and it looks as if a charge will last me a couple of weeks at least. It can be used wet, so there's no worry about dropping it in a sink full of water, and it's easy to clean using liquid soap and water (it even has a turbo setting specifically for cleaning). Lastly, the digital readout provides a lot of information, including the charge level, how much time you've used it, an alert when it needs cleaning, and a couple of other things. And the built-on trimmer is 1000% better at trimming sideburns than the single blade that's on the Gillette cartridges for that purpose. Oh, yeah - it comes with a 2-year warranty. All in all a very good buy!<br /><br />p.s. - If you try to register the razor on Panasonic's website, you may run into a problem with the serial number. The site insists that the number contain 9 to 11 digits, but the serial number on the razor is only 7 digits. If you enter just those 7 digits, the system will not accept your registration. I called Panasonic and discovered that the workaround is to add the letters SN before the 7-digit serial number, and the system will then accept your registration.
  6. Bought this as a second (travel) shaver for the ES-LA93 I have. One thing is that this one doesn't have the charging contacts on the back for use with the docking station. Beyond that, works well - as good as the other one.
  7. Very please, very close shave and great value.
  8. love it! its the third one in our family and they all say the same thing ..
  9. I've had this shaver now since December of 2012 and cannot recommend it highly enough. I used to use Norelco, but this razor beats anything I have tried before – and I have been shaving for 40 years!
  10. My husband loves this razor! It gets a close shave, and can be used in the shower. What a great purchase!
  11. I like every part of it. It works as advertised. Expensive but worth it...I had used less expensive razors that just didn't cut the mustard.
  12. Really like this razor. We use it on a disabled man who has difficulty raising his chin to shave his neck, and he has a thick, course beard. The pivoting head makes the task much easier to get a clean shave. It is easy to handle, gives a great shave and cleans beautifully. It is more powerful and closer shaving than the other four-blade razors we've used over the past several years. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it.
  13. Shaver cuts well and gives a comfortable shave, however it doesn't capture the shavings/hair well and &#34;leaks&#34; messy residue all over your sink, bathroom, floor etc. I previously had a norelco that cut as well and did not make a mess. I would avoid this model until they fix this issue.
  14. Got this to replace a Norelco Artic rotary shaver. The Panasonic gives a very close shave, almost like a blade. My only gripe is it does not hold a charge very long. I can't make it through the week on one charge. Other than that this is a great shaver. Easy to clean, and not to loud.
  15. I have utilized other electric shavers of well-known brands,this electric shaver seems to provide a closer shave.Let's see if this shaver continues to satisfy my needs for a close and comfortable shave.

  18. This shaver really does an excellent job, it is powerful, fast and it saves time for me, personally this is the best electric shaver i have ever used, it took my old BRAUN shaver about 15 minutes to do it, with this it takes 4 minutes, this shaver does not irritate my skin does not pull or tug on the hair, most of the time it shaves in just a few quick passes, it has a bigger head than my previous shaver so it covers more in less time, it appears to have good batterie life, i think it can easily give me 10 shaves, it does not come with a stand which i do not mind at all, cleaning it is quite easy, just a little soap and water.<br />The main feature of this shaver for me is IT DOES AN EXCELLENT JOB, i wish i had discovered it many years ago, i used to hate shaving before this shaver and now it feels awesome.<br />for me it's a 6 star shaver.<br />Thanks.
  19. This shaver is awesome. Not sure why there are complaints on the price of this unit. Panasonic offers a wide range of shavers at lower prices for those who can't justify spending a few extra dollars on themselves.
  20. Excellent product. Pros: much closer cut than my previous Braun Series 3. Seems to be well made, very quiet compared to other electric razors I've used, head maintains good contact with face. Cons: very large physical size.

  22. I use this daily for shaving while taking my shower. This will be my fifth Panasonic. The duel swivel head has proven useful and I like the readout telling me precent charge remaining. It provides a very close shave (better then previous model which was good). I cannot compare to regular razor as I have always used electric. I have found wet/dry razors have about a 3 year life when used daily in shower making it on the pricey side. I think it is worth it.
  23. I was using Philips Arcitec for years. I wanted a change from rotary type shaver to something else. I save time also as this shaver is fast. The instructions are clear and it feels good in the hand.
  24. I have used a rotary type razor and was somewhat hesitant to change. But, change I did and this was the best thing I have done in quite some time. I truly love the shaver.   25. This review won't convince straight razor nor safety blade users to switch.<br /><br />I have used this razor for month so I can<br />For years, both my father and I have used Philips products (the items manufactured in Holland) when there was no such thing as re-chargable razors.<br />The rotary system is fine, until you purchase the replacement heads. Then you collapse in a state of shock.<br />I replaced my old Philips Cool Shave as I was recharging it every 3 days and it was taking 8 hours a day to charge.<br />I contemplated Braun, but I read some poor reviews on this site and others as well.<br />This Panasonic model ES-LA63 is sufficient for what I required. The model above this version (ES-LA93) has the self cleaning function. That is OK, until you have to purchase the replacement cleaning solution. It is a slight incremental benefit that you must consistently pay for maintenance.<br /><br />Other comments talk about the noise that comes from the razor. It is a non-issue. Anything mechanical makes a noise.<br /><br />Wet shaves are impressive. Face and under the nose is very good in removing hair.<br />The neck (LIKE ALL ELECTRICS) require time and technique. Remember, it is just a razor. We can't all look like Daniel Craig after getting out of the shower.<br /><br />Being from Canada, the Amazon US site beats all retailers. Not The Bay, Sears, Personal Edge can beat this price, even after F/X and Duties.<br /><br />Delivery was impressive...Less than 48 hours, it was at my door.<br /><br />Without hesitation, I would recommend this Panasonic razor to any man. To all Canadians, make an example of our retailers and tell them to match Amazon.com prices. There is no reason it should retailer higher in our country.

  28. GREAT FOR CUTTING A STRAIGHT BEARD - NOT SO GOOD FOR A AREA WHERE HAIR GROWS AT AN ANGLE , I'LL GIVE IT ANOTHER WEEK
  29. At the beginning the performance was not that great, but as per other users' recommendations I decided to stick with the shaver for a little while. My skin is now sort of used to the shaver and you tend to get better results over time.<br /><br />As other users have mentioned, getting rid of skin hair around your neck is somewhat difficult so you need to stretch your skin to make it (it doesn't work all the time though).<br /><br />I like it because it is pretty comfortable for a quick shave, though I always fallback to razors for cleaner shaves.
  30. When I started shaving there were very few options available: single razor blades, straight-edge, disposables and a few electric models. I tried everything. Back then, the electric razors I tried, pulled on the hairs rather than cutting them so I gave-up on electric razors believing that my beard was just too tough for an electric to handle.<br /><br />There's no argument that the 2, 3, 4 and 5 blade razors revolutionized shaving starting in the late 1980's / early 1990's. Then came the sticker shock of the replacement blades. But that's the dream, right? Create a product that everyone needs that's disposable that they have to buy again and again. But that's an expensive trap for consumers...<br /><br />With that said, when I researched the Panasonic, I was hesitant because of the cost. Then, after doing the math, I realized that I spent more than that on the yearly cost of replacement blades and so bought the electric. To be honest, even before the first shave, I was prepared to return the razor. After my early experiences with electric razors, I didn't have high hopes...<br /><br />To my amazement and surprise - it gave me a clean and fun shave. I actually look forward to shaving every day; I haven't felt that way since I was a boy (you know, that time in every young boy's life when we were all in a rush to be all grown-up).<br /><br />I'm not going to comare electric to blades because I find that comparison utterly ridiculous - and I think the reviewers here who have done so, just like the sound of their own voice. The fact is, I'll use a blade from time to time but for daily or ever 2x daily maintenance (the touch-up before an evening out at the theatre), I'll be using the Panasonic.
  31. MY HUSBAND IS VERY PROUD TO HAVE THIS RAZOR. IT MORE THAN MEETS MY EXPECTATIONS, SEEMS REALLY WELL MADE, IS POWERFUL AND GETS IT ALL!
  32. This is a beautiful and high quality shaver. It comes with a soft, zippered form-fitting case. I don't think its leather, but looks like it will hold up for a long time. I did have a shaver about 15 years ago that came with a much nicer leather custom case. For the price of this shaver, I sort of expected one like that. Oh well.<br /><br />This shaves very gently. I've had ones that could easily cut into your adams apple or around your lips if you pushed too hard in those areas. This one is very easy to wash with a drop of liquid soap and warm running water. I find it helpful to rub some clipper oil on the inside of the cutting foil with a Q-tip after washing. It will make the blades last much longer and provide a smoother shave.<br /><br />I am 47 years old and have owned maybe 6 or 7 electrics and this is, by far, the most effective. Battery life is good. I get about 5 shaves per charge. I only use it dry, so I can't say how it works wet or in the shower, but it says it is safe to do so. It's a lot of money, but a great shaver.<br /><br />If you are having trouble with razor bumps, and/or ingrown hairs, this may help with that problem. This shaver will not cut hair below the skin surface. Supposedly, even with a razor blade, you are not supposed to cut hair against the grain for this reason. So, if you compare a shave with a blade NOT against the grain to this shaver, I think this electric does a better job. This model has a timer on it so it tells you how long it took to shave and I average right about 5 minutes.
  33. The Panasonic ES-LA63-S Wet/Dry Shaver provides an incredibly close and comfortable shave. However, it has a few minor drawbacks. Here's some of its pros and cons:<br /><br />Pros<br />----<br />- Incredibly Close and Comfortable Shave<br />The Panasonic shaves just about as close as traditional shaving blades. Compared to blades, this shaver definitely provides a more comfortable shave - wet or dry. There's no need for shaving foam, although you can use it if you choose.<br /><br />- Wet/Dry Convenience<br />I usually opt for dry shaving simply because it's more convenient, but I occasionally choose to have a wet shave for the increased comfort a wet shave provides.<br /><br />- Easy To Clean<br />You can easily clean the shaver by rinsing it under tap water while it is running. There's no need to crack it open to clean it.<br /><br />- Pop-Up Trimmer<br />The pop-up trimmer does as good a job as a dedicated trimmer.<br /><br />- Good Ergonomics<br />The shaver is comfortable to hold. The back of the shaver is rubberized to help improve your grip on the shaver.<br /><br />Cons<br />----<br />- No Charging Dock / Cleaning Station<br />This model doesn't have a cleaning station like the [[ASIN:B0021AG0Z6 Panasonic ES8249S Arc IV Nanotech Vortex Wet/Dry Rechargeable Shaver]] does. For the price, I'd expect at least a charging dock.<br /><br />- Bulky Head<br />The shaving head is a little on the bulky side, which makes it a little unwieldy for targeting specific areas.<br /><br />- Additional Points<br />The shaver is rather plain-looking. Besides an LCD screen with a battery indicator, there's really not much to write home about. The build quality is descent but the shaver looks a bit too plasticky. It falls short of expectations in the aesthetics department for a shaver that costs this much.<br /><br />---<br />Despite a few shortcomings, I like the Panasonic ES-LA63-S Shaver for the incredibly close shave it provides and for the ease with which it can be cleaned.
  34. good product for the money ($140)
  35. Panasonic makes some good products. A bit on the expensive side though. The Arc4 is a nice shaver, and does a nice job if I shave every day or two. It has trouble with my longer hairs (My facial hair grows pretty slowly, so I'm not talking very long), and requires many trips over the stubble, or even using the trimmer. The trimmer is sized right and works well. Easy to clean manually - I've not tried cleaning in water, so can't comment. Seems like more of a fuss to me.<br /><br />Since this is a wet/dry shaver, Panasonic correctly made it so you can't use it corded. Too much liability issues. Humans are NOT the smartest animal! The unit charges quickly, but I find it drains between 10 to 20% each shave, which takes about four minutes.
  36. This shaver is great replacement for my earlier Panasonic Arc 4 (ES-8249). In my opinion the Panasonic is still the best of the top of the line shavers. I've tried both of the others, the Braun 7 series and the Philips Norelco 9000 Series (though I haven't tried the Panasonic Arc 5, don't have an extra $400 lying around). Though the Braun is close to as good as this Panasonic, the rotary Philips I just can't stand, hate having to make circular motions the entire time that I'm shaving. I shave dry, if I wanted the inconvenience and mess of wet shaving I'd use a blade. I think the Panasonic shaves closer, faster than the Braun. One problem with this shaver, and the area in which it loses to the Braun is ergonomics. I thought my old Panasonic had a huge head...until I saw this one, which they've managed to take to an entirely new level. It's a little hard to maneuver around the face but still the best of the top of the liners.
  37. Now that the price of this model has dropped you get an excellent shaver at a good price point! I really like to option of using the shaver wet or dry. The shaver does shave closer when used wet. Highly recommended!
  38. This shaver works!!! Really, I have a beard that requires two shaves a day. It grows that fast. Like Tim Allen on Santa Clause. I have had all the various versions of Braun, Remington, and Noreclo. Noreclo from 1974 was very good. It cut well and lasted sometime. Of course, Noreclo was sold and the version was obsoleted. Since 1980, I usual have changed blades every month or two and shaver every year. I have also tried real shavers. The beard is so thick the blades dull while shaving. This Panasonic shaver actually cuts the beard without pull. I have not had to push into the skin to get the beard hair. No razor burns. One can just lightly shave and with each pass it cuts beard not skin. It works wet or dry. I usually pre-soak with water ten minutes before shaving. Clean up is great and actually keeps the shaver clean like new if you use the liquid hand soap. The side burn cutter works great as well. I have had the shaver for two months and have not had to replace the blades yet. I am happy!! Shave is just as good as day one!!!
  39. Well I have used it for about a month now, it does a decent job, it only works great when using it along with a liquid like Lectric Shave. It helps keep the ingrown hairs in check, shaving with a regular razor is closer (especially on the neck) but can't do it as often without problems. I can't say it's an awesome product, I had a Norelco Spectra before this and it worked equally good, but it is a better razor when used wet. I am lucky that I paid $140 for it, because at the original price of $300, it would not have been worth it!!

I just hope that it'll last me another 10 years like the other one.
  41. It is a nice and quiet wet/dry shaver. It gives shave close to a razor blade, but at the neck bones it leaves hair little bit and you may need to use a razor just for it. Long battery life, more than 8 shaves for one charge. For the price under $80 it is well worth.
  42. Purchased the Panasonic ES-LA63 in December 2010. Gives a closer shave than my rotory shaver. (Norelco) Has a little better battery life than my last foil type electric shaver. (Remington) The only negitive's are the very expensive wear parts.
  43. I have now used this shaver for sometime and it is the fourth different electric shaver I have purchased.<br />The unit was shipped quickly and received in good condition. It does not shave as well as my<br />previously purchased Remington unit but does hold a longer charge. Shaves well on sides of face<br />but leaves a lot of stubble on my neck and chin.   44. I bought the cheaper Panasonic ES8243A about 2 years ago, upgraded the blades on that one and it worked great. I needed to upgrade the outer foil but ended up buying a whole new shaver because of my positive experience, and because I can't resist getting the top model. This shaver is basically the same as the ES8243A with a couple of differences. First, this one has two motors: one to drive the blades, the second just vibrates the head. At first, comparatively, you don't notice, but a third or fourth shave you can tell. The sonic element makes the shave a bit smoother and works better on the neck and jawline than the ES8243A. Secondly, the speed at which the blades reciprocate is 14,000 rpms, compared to 13,000 for the ES8243A. This is a marginal upgrade, but I assume it helps to have a smoother shave. Overall, compared to cheaper Panasonic models, this shaver is smoother all around especially on the neck and jawline, but compare prices so that your not spending much over the ES8243A.
  45. Very good Hope to have more products to China
  46. I received this shaver last night and finally got to use it earlier today. First impressions are incredible. I had the Braun 790CC and was happy with it, but somehow came upon this shaver while looking for cleaning fluid for the Braun. The Braun cut pretty close but my face was always a little dry and dull due to the fact that I was shaving dry. When I seen that you can use shaving cream with this one and read some reviews, I was intrigued. I decided that I would take a chance on it since the price was a modest $135. My first shave was extremely close, even closer than the Braun 790CC. I'm not trying to say buy this one or that one but my experience has shown that this razor shaves slightly a bit closer. As far as cleaning, it was very easy to clean, I just ran it under some water and applied some soap and it was good to go. The Braun cleaning system was really great and I miss that aspect but I'm not complaining one bit. I know I could have paid the extra $80-90 and got the ES-LA93-K with the cleaning system but since this is a wet/dry, it's very easy to clean. One last note, I haven't shaved dry yet so if the results are different than the wet shave I will edit my post. With that being said, I expect very similar results.
  47. Good stuff, I like it.
  48. This is simply the best electric shaver I've ever used. My beard hair grows in pretty thick and I have to shave every day for my job. After four years, I grew tired of using foam and a manual razor every morning. In the past I've used a few electric shavers but none of them worked well for me. Some of them pulled my hair out, others simply passed over it and barely cut anything...but this shaver is outstanding. What used to be an annoyance every morning is now something I can take care of in under two minutes. I don't get any irritation and the shaver cuts the hairs surprisingly close to my skin. Is it as close as a manual razor? No, not quite, but what electric can really claim that anyway?<br /><br />I would recommend this shaver to anyone and everyone. It's an absoutely outstanding product.
  49. This electric Razor is amazing! It charges quickly, gives an incredibly close shave, and works wet/dry! I picked it up after I saw that it won the Men's Health Grooming Award, that helped me decide between all the identical looking razors. I have been using a Mach 3 for years and I have no desire to ever go back after using this razor, it was worth every penny.
  50. I use this shaver in wet mode only - gives me very close shaves just like a razor blade, but I don't get any ingrown hair, unlike top of the line Braun shaver or any of the blade based ones (Gillette etc etc). Now the bad part - the biggest issue I have with this is that it will not shave while plugged in - dry or wet. To me it screams planned obsolescence - you will have to pay shipping (while on warranty) and wait for battery replacement, buy new battery and do the job yourself, when out of warranty or BUY NEW shaver again. I'm sure Panasonic would explains this from electric shock perspective, but output voltage is just 6V; plus the connection looks snug enough to avoid water getting in there anyway. If not this, they they could have designed it a bit better. My point is - in 2011 this shouldn't be an issue; and these sort of things have been solved by now. Buy this shaver if you have a sensitive skin to use it in wet mode, preferably with oil based shaving creme/lotion; but expect to buy the next best new shaver from Panasonic in the near future again. Lather rinse repeat...

  52. Hands down, the best wet/dry (or any) shaver I've owned. My original electric razor was a Panasonic and lasted over 20 years with only screen and head replacements periodically. My next three were gifts, two Norelco's and a Braun. None lived up to their hype. I threw the last Norelco away and went back to a straight razor while researching electric rechargeable wet/dry shavers. When I read the specs and reviews for the Panasonic Arc IV, I decided to buy it based on my earliest experience with Panasonic (should have returned the other gifts and got a Panasonic in retrospect). The Arc IV gives the closest shave of any electric razor I've ever owned. Baby smooth feeling with minimal work, regardless of whether using in the shower or dry. I charge it once a week even though it's only down to about 30% after 7 uses. My previous Braun was a high end with base / cleaning solution and I'll never get another base / cleaning solution model again. Again, much hype and more work than they're worth. This rechargeable Arc IV is the keeper. Learned my lesson. Should I replace this one, it will be with another Panasonic for sure.

  57. I bought this with the intent to use it as my day to day head and face shaver. First, this pulls very hard on your hairs if you let it grow out more than 3 days. Next, I found it very hard to get a good shave without rotating it in every single direction; its not really a huge con on the shaver as my facial hair grows different directions but its huge head did make it a little hard to get the neck. The shave was pretty much the same as a normal shave. I didn't use it in water; I always get worried something will happen but I do clean it by running water through the blades and it did an amazing job except it does splash a bit. Lastly, I switched from a rotary shaver to a foil. I found that using the foil made my face itch and gave me lots of razor bumps which a rotary did not.<br /><br />Ultimately, I used this razor's 30 day trial before I gave it the boot and switched back to a rotary.

  60. I spent two days researching shavers. First I found out that a person who shaves regularly is better off with a foil shaver than a rotary shaver. I saw reviews, checked out this and that, and even went and looked at a few. Finally I just bit the bullet and bought the number one on consumers reports and I am really, really glad I did. It charges fast, lasts a long time on a charge, really cuts clean, like you were using a blade, does not cut or pinch and does not miss anything you send it over. It does not need lots of moving here and there and back and forth. Just run it over as if you were using a blade. And super easy to clean! My goodness! Way better than my Philips Norelco rotary (but it did last me 6 years without trouble till the top of it broke). It does not come with a stand and I wasn't happy about that, but it stays where you put it on a shelf.
  61. I have been buying electric razors for more than 45 years, and this razor is hands down the first one to live up to its hype! I have most recently tried the near top of the line Braun, Norelco and in the past Remington. I first tried this shaver on about 2.5 days of stubble, and I felt this was not going to be a fair first trial, but it just mowed right through without any pulling! Honest, this is the only shaver I have ever had that literally delivers a blade-close shave, with just one or two passes! With the Norelco and Braun I had to go over an area 3 or 4 times to get even passable results. I can use a razor but it irritates my skin and makes my beard too heavy, so this electric is a revelation. I expect it is the dual motor technology and nanotech blades. On top of the amazing smooth shave, this really must cut below the skin since my beard takes longer to re-emerge than with other razors. I did not get the fancy cleaning system, not needed, this is easy to clean with a simple razor brush; I would not use water or shaving cream, not needed, it does not irritate! I cannot recommend this razor more highly! With this razor I can see keeping it forever and just buying new blades if needed. Don't waste your money on the others or the cheaper Panasonic, this new technology has got the electric razor challenge nailed!

  64. This shaver is the finest shaver I have ever owned. It is a bit expensive but the quality of the shave makes the cost worth it. It is technologically advanced and will even tell you when the head needs to be cleaned, how long it took you to shave and what is the remaining battery strength in percentage rather than a series of lines. Can be used wet or dry but dry seems to get me the closest shave but that may just be because of my beard. I have a medium type of beard and this shaver will shave it to a very close shave without any problems even if I do not shave for 4 or 5 days.<br /><br />There are a couple of cons to the shaver. First it is big and bulky. The size makes you have to turn it a bit to get it to shave up next to your ears on sideburns and also in trimming around your beard if you have one. Second the motor noise is high pitched and will make you want to finish shaving as fast as possible.<br /><br />With that said it is still a great shaver.

  74. I owned an older Panasonic razor, but eventually the battery died and I just trashed it and went back to wet-shaving. When it came time to acquire a new one I looked at both the Braun and Panasonic but never took the plunge. When the Amazon Vine program offered the Panasonic I knew I wanted it. I've used this new Panasonic razor primarily wet in the shower. It works great there, very smooth shave, no pulling, no irritation. I just use a regular shave cream with it. I've also tried it dry, with an electric pre-shave. While the end result was ok, the shave wasn't as comfortable and my face was a little red. It faded quickly, but just wasn't as comfortable for me. The shaver itself has a huge head, but it is easy enough to maneuver it around and I didn't have any problems getting the area on my upper lip close to my nose. It doesn't come with a cleaning base, like my older Panasonic had, but it is simple enough to squirt some soap on it and activate the cleaning mode. Overall I'm not sure I would spend close to $300 for this model when the lower cost ones do the job just as well.
  75. I've tried many different electric razors over the past 15 years, whether it was from Braun, Norelco, or Remington. Prior to testing the Panasonic ES-LA63-S I had been using a Braun Cruzer. After using the ES-LA63-S for 3 weeks, I can definitely say it's the closest shave I've ever had with an electric razor.<br />The Panasonic ES-LA63-S has two motors and two blade sets housed inside a giant shaver head that contains three foils and a hair lifter/comb piece. The shaver head really is big, which is a strength and a weakness of the unit. The head of the unit tilts to accommodate the contours of your chin and neck, but you can also lock the head in place so it does not tilt. In addition, there is a pop up trimmer on the unit for sideburns and such. The ES-LA63-S has a fairly large blue LED screen on the handle that tells you how much battery power is remaining, how long your shaving session lasted, whether the battery is being charged and if the cleaning mode is on. The shaver feels solid and heavy in your hand--in a good way. The construction of it makes it feel like it will have no durability issues. This Panasonic also comes with an AC adapter and a very basic carrying case.<br /><br />Cleaning the unit is pretty easy, and is probably has the best electric shaver cleaning system that I've ever seen. To clean you place several small drops of liquid hand soap across the top of the foils and then hold down the power button in order to enter \\"turbo mode.\\" The blades vibrate really fast and lather up the foils and blades themselves. You let that run for 20 seconds, stop and then rinse. The foil cover comes off easily so you can rinse out the entire head, inside and out. Works way better than having to use those mini-brushes that inexpensive shavers come with, and it's far cheaper than having to buy replacement cleaning cartridges for some other shavers, like several of the Braun series.<br /><br />The ES-LA63-S covers a lot of surface area in one motion and cuts hairs really close for an efficient shave. The timer says most of my shaves last about 3 minutes. I tried it both wet and dry, and I prefer to use it dry after a shower. The first week that I used this shaver I noticed an increased occurrence in ingrown hairs on my face. I think my skin was adjusting to the new, closer shave though, because after that first week I haven't had any complications with my skin. The shave is remarkably smooth, however, and I think it holds up well compared to a standard disposable razor. The only limitation is the giant shaver head size. If you have neat facial hair it is difficult to trim around it while manipulating the blades due to the oversized head. As a result, I now shave most of my face with the Panasonic and then take 30 seconds to trim up the sides of my goatee with my old Cruzer. If you have complex facial hair you'll probably need to develop a similar method to maintain straight lines of a beard or `stache.<br /><br />Overall, the ES-LA63-S provides a surprisingly good, close shave. I knock it down to four stars because it's not great for maintaining facial hair patterns, and at $300, you probably want your shaver to brush your teeth for you as well. If you don't have facial hair and you can swallow the $300 price tag, you'll be hard pressed to find a better electric shaver.close for an efficient shave. The timer says most of my shaves last about 3 minutes. I tried it both wet and dry, and I prefer to use it dry after a shower. The first week that I used this shaver I noticed an increased occurrence in ingrown hairs on my face. I think my skin was adjusting to the new, closer shave though, because after that first week I haven't had any complications with my skin. The shave is remarkably smooth, however, and I think it holds up well compared to a standard disposable razor. The only limitation is the giant shaver head size. If you have neat facial hair it is difficult to trim around it while manipulating the blades due to the oversized head. As a result, I now shave most of my face with the Panasonic and then take 30 seconds to trim up the sides of my goatee with my old Cruzer. If you have complex facial hair you'll probably need to develop a similar method to maintain straight lines of a beard or `stache. Overall, the ES-LA63-S provides a surprisingly good, close shave. I knock it down to four stars because it's not great for maintaining facial hair patterns, and at $300, you probably want your shaver to brush your teeth for you as well. If you don't have facial hair and you can swallow the $300 price tag, you'll be hard pressed to find a better electric shaver.
  76. The Panasonic ES-LA63 is fairly unusual for a high end electric shaver: unlike its competitors, it does not come bundled with fancy ultrasonic cleaning and charging stations, does not have a built-in lotion dispenser... The box just contains the shaver itself, a world-compatible charger, and a soft case. The shaver itself does not have all sorts of complicated settings, either: just an on/off button and a three position switch (floating head, locked head, trimmer). Its only concession to the high end is a nifty blue LCD display that shows the amount of time in use and a remaining time estimate. The power button can also be locked by a slider to prevent unwanted activation when traveling. The trimmer is a bit of a disappointment: it's hidden by the large shaving head, so you can't really see what you're doing with it, rendering it useless unless you're doing large areas.. unfortunately it's too narrow to be really useful for that type of job. Bottom line, if you need a trimmer, buy a $20 Wahl at Target: this one won't... er... cut it. The large shaving head is also a problem if you need any sort of accuracy, because it's always hiding what you're doing. All these minor problems are eclipsed by the amazing quality of the shave: as close a shave as you would get from a mechanical razor, and absolutely none of the redness or pain you would get from an electric shaver. I have never seen this type of results from an electric shaver before. Cleaning is a breeze: pop the head cover, rinse the head and cover under the tap and air dry. CONS ---- * Large, can be cumbersome and lacks accuracy (not very good for trimming facial hair) * Useless trimmer * Expensive PROS ---- * World compatible charger * Floating head effortlessly follows face contour * Amazingly efficient and close shave without pressure, pain, redness or irritation * Easy cleaning CONCLUSION ---------- The ES-LA63 is a no-frills shaver, but it puts the emphasis where it really counts: a close, comfortable and painless shave, the best I've ever had by a long shot. I'd much rather have that than a gimmicky self-cleaning stand, especially when cleaning is such a quick and easy procedure. Very highly recommended.
  77. Excellent shaver, best electric one Ive used. Very comfortable to use and easy to clean. My only complaint would be the shaving head is a little too big and does not offer much precision. I still prefer the rotary head of the Norelcos but its more of a personal preference. The Panasonic does the job just fine, if not better. Also its pretty expensive, dont think your average joe would spend so much on an electric shaver. However its nice to see that for the price it is Made in Japan, which I would expect in higher end electronics. If you are willing spend the money the Panasonic ES-LA63-S will deliver.

  79. I go back and forth between regular razor blades and electric shaver.   80. I've used a lot of electric shavers over the years, including some of the higher end Remington, Braun and Panasonic units. I mostly used them to avoid getting nicks on my chin. However none of them have done a good enough job on my neck, so I usually used a manual razor on the neck and sides and the electric shave in the goatee area. I was both apprehensive and hopeful about moving up from my [[ASIN:B00176V2SK Panasonic ES8228S Men's Linear Vortex Nano Arc Foil Shaving System, Silver]] because compared to it, this thing is a jumbo jet. It has a much bigger shaving area, and has a higher rpm motor which hums confidently when you turn it on. It took about two weeks for me to get my face to adapt for a similar shave quality and after about a month I've found that it gives me a much better shave than any of my previous shavers. It's razor close on most of my face and it has even gotten the cross grained hairs on my neck into presentable fashion (not as close as a blade, but respectable). It is much larger than my last shaver (I've uploaded some comparison photos), so it did take some getting used to, especially on the upper lip. Overall I'm very happy with it, and even though it doesn't come with a cleaning station like my last Panasonic razor, I don't really miss it since the recommended liquid soap and water method works very well, it's easy and a lot quicker and quieter than the base station.<br /><br />PROS<br />- Works great wet or dry<br />- Gets cross grained hair down to respectable levels<br />- Easy cleanup<br />- Long Battery Life (10-14 days)<br />- Power lock switch so it won't accidentally turn on during travel (I had this happen once on an old shaver)<br />- Easy to read LCD with wash reminders, time used, and percentage of battery left (10% increments)<br />- Multi-directional pivoting head<br />- Fast and strong motor reduces the number of passes<br />- Large surface with 4 blades (but only two inside driving 2 more in the foil)<br /><br />CONS<br />- Small soft sided travel bag can't fit charger (although you won't need it for most trips)<br />- Large shaving area takes some getting used to on smaller areas like the upper lip<br />- Without the base you don't have a \\"home\\" for the unit and you do have to remember to charge it.<br />- Maybe price is a bit steep compared to others, but if you get it on sale it's a good deal.ou won't need it for most trips) - Large shaving area takes some getting used to on smaller areas like the upper lip - Without the base you don't have a \\"home\\" for the unit and you do have to remember to charge it. - Maybe price is a bit steep compared to others, but if you get it on sale it's a good deal.

For t w o hundred plus dollars I expected much more. My norelco that I have had since 2000 STILL WORKS! How about that. I've come to the conclusion that anythings quality made newer is down the hill. Really start doing some research before you by anything these days.<br /><br />This thing doesn't even work when plugged in. If you run out of battery while shaving then you out of luck. What a pile.
  86. The jury is still out! I have only used it sparingly for a month. I do like the ease of cleaning.
  87. This Panasonic ES-LA63-S Men's Shaver is a high performance shaver, but I cannot honestly give a better rating due to the high initial cost and maintenance cost. I have used a few electric shavers in my life and am using a manual blade razor.<br /><br />Pros:<br />This shaver is easy to clean compares to my older electric shavers: a simple rinse under running water or in the water will do. Many other electric shavers require more labor-intensive cleaning procedure. I believe the ease of cleaning is its best attribute. It is quiet for an electric shaver. It has a large head, but it is light and nimble. The shaver head can be set for free movement or locked. The performance is good for an electric shaver.<br /><br />Cons:<br />This shaver is sold at $300, which is the advertised price when I wrote this review (hoepfully it will come down). It is better than a typical $50-$100 shaver, but not by that much. I disagree with other reviews which claim it shaves as close as a blade razor. In my experience, this is false. I ran this electric shaver through my face 5-6 times (dry or wet) and there are still hairs above the skin. Then when I ran a blade razor across, it shaved them all off. If you are hoping for an electric shaver which can cut as close as a razor, then this is not it. I don't even think this electric shaver cut much closer to the skin than typical electric shavers. The outer foil ($60) is recommended to be replaced every year and the inner blade ($20) is recommended to be replaced every two years. This is $70 maintenance cost per year, and even if you double the duration between replacements, it is still $35 per year. Potential buyers should take this long term financial commitment into account.<br /><br />At the end, this shaver is marginally better than its competitors, but the initial price and upkeeping cost are high. This is not a bad electric shaver if you have the money to spare. However, you will not find dramatic differences between this electric shaver and a typical $50-100 electrical shaver.ypical $50-100 electrical shaver.
  88. I have been using electric shavers for my entire adult life, mostly Norelcos with an occasional foil type shaver (Eltron, Panasonic, Porsche) thrown in for good measure. I have always been aware that I was not getting the closest possible shave, but I was too lazy to want to bother with the mess of a razor. But now that I own the new Panasonic Lamdash (ES-LA63-S,) I no longer feel that I am missing out on anything. This is one powerful shaver. I can now get a much closer shave in 3 minutes than I could in 6 minutes with my most recent Norelco. No longer is it necessary to go over the same spots again and again with little to show for it, especially in the neck area. I love the fact that the battery puts out full power right until the point when it runs out of charge, not like other shavers that gradually lose power over the course of a charge. Can the Panasonic shave as close as a blade? I cannot answer that directly, because I have not compared the two. I can only say that in order to get a closer shave with a blade, I would have to remove a significant portion of my epidermis, and why would I want to do that?
  89. This is a Great Shaver ! Pretty close to a manual one My husband never uses anything other than a manual but he gave this a shot and was in for a real surprise Best of all he could use it wet Easy to charge Dual voltage so he can use it anywhere I think this was a great gift for him Expensive no doubt but worth it.
  90. I've experimented with electric razors for years. I have a pretty thick beard, and sensitive skin, and trying to find a lasting, close shave for over 20 years has been next to impossible. Shaving against the grain with a standard x-amount of blades razor is too painful, and usually precludes shaving for a day or two until the irritation goes away. I even tried a straight razor shave at Art of the Shave, and horrified the poor woman who painstakingly tried her best to reduce the mess/discomfort. Electric razors throughout the years would burn, and were awful in removing hair from my neck. In the past few years I've tried newer razors from Norelco and Braun, with the same basic results - and got tired of funky cleaning systems and having to buy special solutions for the razors. Being a sucker for yet another electric do-dad, I had to jump on the opportunity when this appeared as a Vine Voice option.<br /><br />After 5 weeks of using this razor, it has become my everyday razor for several reasons, which I hope to get across below.<br /><br />The first thing that grabbed my attention is that it's a no-nonsense razor. The box includes the razor, a nice travel pouch, a cord and instructions - no funky charging/cleaning base, no cleaning cartridges or other solutions. Cleaning instructions are to use water and liquid soap, so just about any modern day bathroom (public or private) is equipped to clean this razor.<br /><br />Next was the ability to use it with water and shaving cream - just like a standard, x-bladed cartridge razor. It isn't until the first time you really try this when you realize that is really modern shaving - comfortable, quick and effective. The razor glides over your skin smoothly, unlike the older dry shave days of electrics (I realize there have been razors that have done this for a while - this was my first time trying it), no burn, no cuts or nicks as with cartridge razors. When you seem to be losing effectiveness, a quick dip of the shaver head in running water cleans the blades and starts fresh - again, just like \\"normal\\" shaving. I had no problems with changing the angles I used to shave in order to get most (but still not some problem areas) on my neck and jawline (which are quickly cleaned up with a cartridge razor). Then a quick clean with the soap and water, final rinse and drying, and in about the same time I'd take for a normal shave, I had an easier, and closer shave with no burn, nicks or other irritation.<br /><br />I thought it was just the first day, and expected the typical electric razor problems to crop up over the next week. Each day I used it proved it to be the same experience - quick, easy, painless. The battery easily lasts for over a week of shaves (I recharge it once a week or so), and charges completely within 2 hours or so. It's a great razor for travelling - lock the head, charge it, and put it in the travel case. If necessary, bring the cord with you and you're set for a longer trip.<br /><br />Pros:<br />Quick, full charges.<br />Ability to work with water/shaving cream.<br />\\"As close as a catridge razor\\" shave<br />No charging/cleaing base<br />No typical electric razor irritation<br /><br />Cons:<br />Power button is easy to hit while shaving<br />Still misses small areas of the necke blades and starts fresh - again, just like \\"normal\\" shaving. I had no problems with changing the angles I used to shave in order to get most (but still not some problem areas) on my neck and jawline (which are quickly cleaned up with a cartridge razor). Then a quick clean with the soap and water, final rinse and drying, and in about the same time I'd take for a normal shave, I had an easier, and closer shave with no burn, nicks or other irritation. I thought it was just the first day, and expected the typical electric razor problems to crop up over the next week. Each day I used it proved it to be the same experience - quick, easy, painless. The battery easily lasts for over a week of shaves (I recharge it once a week or so), and charges completely within 2 hours or so. It's a great razor for travelling - lock the head, charge it, and put it in the travel case. If necessary, bring the cord with you and you're set for a longer trip. Pros: Quick, full charges. Ability to work with water/shaving cream. \\"As close as a catridge razor\\" shave No charging/cleaing base No typical electric razor irritation Cons: Power button is easy to hit while shaving Still misses small areas of the neck

  95. The Panasonic shaver performed well and produced a close shave comparable to the top of line Braun shaver I use. The shave head tends to be a bit bulky, but its articulating head helps to remedy this a bit. The one big advantage to this shaver as opposed to a Braun system is that it is a wet/dry and can be rinsed under the sink with relative ease. You do not need to buy cleaning cartridges - just run under water and it's done. I am not sure if the current retail price makes it worth buying over the competition.
  96. In a nutshell, very impressed. I compared this shaver (Panasonic ES-LA63-S Men's Shaver) to one of those Norelcos with triple-head circular blades. I conducted the half/half face test. The result? Panasonic: 1 - Norelco: - 0. The Panasonic provided a much closer shave; on the verge of \\"smooth as a baby's behind\\" close. What's in the box: Shaver with plastic blade cover that snaps on, battery charger (AC cord), and a pleather (emphasis on the \\"P\\" in \\"pleather\\") fitted case. More pluses: Its swiveling head contours your face and neck and it fits nicely in your hand. Even though it's a little larger than I expected, it is still lightweight and easy to use. You don't need to read a huge manual to figure it out (always a huge plus for me!). And yes, it has a trimmer on the back. Oh yeah, and it's wet/dry. A couple of things I wish were different: It probably isn't the best choice for you if you have very sensitive skin. It gives such a close shave that those with skin issues might find it irritating, at least when using it dry. Also, it's a little loud. After an average shave, you might find your ears ringing. (OK, it's not THAT loud, but pretty dang loud for a little shaver.) Finally, the pricetag is pretty steep, imo. Better accessories in-box might make it feel worth it. How about a cleaning brush, at least? Overall, it's a great shaver. I know it's not all about the accessories that come with it, though they'd be nice add-ons. It gets an A+ for the essentials: You get a very close shave, and it charges quickly and efficiently.

  100. The first thing I should say is that you can get as close as you want. Closer than a blade, because with a blade if you add pressure, you get nicks and cutes.<br /><br />Do you want to get so close that your skin will feel extremely raw? Do you want to get even further beyond where you start bleeding? Even further beyond, I've gotten so close that I've taken out my epidermis, my skin is raw to the bone and I have no hair, smoother than a babies behind; their legs.<br /><br />How quick is the shave? Well if you just want a quick shave, this thing will give it to you. I got a good shave in less than a minute. At 14,000 micro-vibrations you can basically get a good shave in a minute. Very fast, very quick, very impressive. The head is huge, so that means you can cover a lot of ground in a short amount of time.<br /><br />Do you want a comfortable shave? Dang, this thing is very very comfortable. It felt like I was rubbing my face with a cloud. Yes, the blades spin that fast that it feels like you've got some kind of cloudy heat pad on your face. Rubbing it up and down, no irritations, very comfortable. Now if you shave for a while, it will get hot. And, if you shave for a while, your skin will get raw and a little irritated. All depending on how close you want to get. Basically, you won't get any irritations if you shave quick; for those with sensitive skin, do not shave for a long period of time. This shaver is very good for sensitive skin.<br /><br />Does it clean? Yes, put liquid soap on the top, run for a few seconds, and run it under the water. The shaver comes with instructions on how to properly clean. I will also take the top off and rinse off the blades; accidentally hit the blades to the sink while they were on; ouch. It still works though. Then soak the top in alcohol if you want, or set to dry.<br /><br />The neck? \\"Conquered the skies, conquered Mount Everest, conquered the moon, CONQUERED the neck,\\" (Phillips commercial) But, the Panasonic es-la63-s also conquers the neck. I'm going to be honest, it does take a while to shave the neck, but it gets very close, I was surprised. I had to pull back some of my skin and shave in 100 different directions, but I finally got all of the neck and the only hair remaining is the Adam's apple which is too sensitive to shave to the bone.<br /><br />It has an LCD screen that tells you how long you have been shaving. And, don't worry about dropping it because it has an incredible grip.<br /><br />Last comments, don't shave in the shower, you can if you want, but my experience was that the water slowed down the blades and couldn't get a good shave. You can use shaving cream to shave though, the blades won't slow down unless you run it through water which includes the shower. Also, my hair type is fast growing hair, not very rough or tough, but still a bit of a challenge. This blade didn't slow down when cutting my hair.<br /><br />YOU GET WHAT YOU PAY FOR!!!onest, it does take a while to shave the neck, but it gets very close, I was surprised. I had to pull back some of my skin and shave in 100 different directions, but I finally got all of the neck and the only hair remaining is the Adam's apple which is too sensitive to shave to the bone. It has an LCD screen that tells you how long you have been shaving. And, don't worry about dropping it because it has an incredible grip. Last comments, don't shave in the shower, you can if you want, but my experience was that the water slowed down the blades and couldn't get a good shave. You can use shaving cream to shave though, the blades won't slow down unless you run it through water which includes the shower. Also, my hair type is fast growing hair, not very rough or tough, but still a bit of a challenge. This blade didn't slow down when cutting my hair. YOU GET WHAT YOU PAY FOR!!!

  102. This is my third Panasonic shaver that I've owned over the past many years. Without any question, this is the best shaver I have ever used. With just a stroke or two the area is cleanly shaven and I am done with my shave in about one and a half minutes. My neck has been the biggest challenge for getting a clean shave with an electric and this unit does it like a dream. It is the quietest shaver I've used and overall am very pleased. My only quibble is the overall size of the foil/shave head. It is bigger so learning how to shave the upper lip and beneath the nose was different, but it isn't that big of a problem. The ES8243A feels much closer just from using it. It's motor even sounds faster, like a V6 turbo to a V6 regular. The Arc IV is also much larger and harder to maneuver too.   107. Previously (for over 42 years) I only shaved with a safety razor and shaving cream. I had tried a couple of electric razors and was left wondering how anyone could choose it over a blade. Then I discovered how the Panasonic Razors can be used either wet or dry. And due to the 13,000 vibrational speed adverised to allow a closer and more comfortable shaving experience I decide to take a leap of faith by purchasing my first Panasonic. Well, it has now been three years of satisfying shaves. Therefore, I ordered this razor so that I may use my previous 3-year old model as a backup (one never knows when a razor will reach its limit of operation, even though it has performed very well and with absolutely no problems--it runs just as strong as the very first day of operation). One important thing: I have very sensitive skin, with a medium to tough beard, growing in a pelthera of directions (a combination that usually spells red, irritated skin). My first Panasonic Razor did so well in addressing this issue that I then ordered this razor (14,000 vibrations vs. 13,000 vibrations of the older model). What an amazingly smooth and comfortable shave (and I shave dry, not wet). I was simply amazed how much closer it shaved. In fact, I kept rubbing my hand over the smooth texture of my skin -- the results were just that pleasant. Let's face it: There is no electric shaver that shaves as close as a razor in one simple pass. After the first pass (with only slight pressure)I then feel which direction my bread grows in the particular area being addressed. I place a little more pressure on the next pass while going against the growth pattern, and repeat the proceedure (if needed) with just slightly more pressure. The biggest mistake any first-time-user makes is pressing so hard on the first pass because they want it to be the only pass. This will never work. An electric shaver is designed to give a very comfortable shave, and the above procedure does just that. I will never go back to a razor (unless, unexpectedly, the power goes out or the water supply is interrupted by some disaster), it is just that comfortable of a shave. I guess it is now very obvious to you that I AM TOTALLY PLEASED WITH THIS RAZOR (and that comes from a previous \\"Die-Hard\\" razor and shaving cream user).

  111. I have been using Norelcos for 40 years and been happy until the last Norelco which was the Senso Touch 2D. Used it for 2 plus years and never felt I could get a reasonably close shave. Even putting in new heads didn't improve things much. Also the new style Norelco has to be emptied after every shave as there is no room to collect the shavings, the charging set up is a pain and the head has to be removed to install the trimmer. Hence I decided to try a foil shaver for the first time. Only been using it a week and had no trouble adjusting. It is the best electric razor shave I've had. Close shave no burn or irritation. I use it dry and would say I have an average beard. The large shaving head is surprisingly not a problem at all. Here is a tip for ex-Norelco Senso Touch users: The Panasonic does not come with a stand, but the stand for the SensoTouch holds the Panasonic just fine.

  113. Let me begin by saying that I was only recently introduced to electric shaving after decades of blade shaving, and involuntarily at that.This was caused by a mobility problem which forced me to give up the blade and I hated the idea of electric, knowing it could never equal a razor blade. In addition, I knew nothing about electric shavers or their cost and succumbed to my first without doing any research and not caring much either. I did know that any electric would be a challenge because my face is slim and angular. So I dispatched my son to go to my local store and get me my first electric. He returned with a Philips Norelco triple rotary recommended by the store owner who has used one himself for the last ten years. Cost:$120(prices here in Canada are brutal). I hated it from the get-go and returned it under the 30-day trial policy of the store for a Panasonic GA21,a mid-high level foil shaver costing $150. It's sleek and attractive, has the self- cleaning feature, and shaves quite well. Like most Panasonics,as I now understand, it pivots from side to side instead of front to back, a design I don't understand. It's also discontinued at this point. While shaving with this razor with good but not outstanding results I started to really get into electrics and began doing a lot of research with a view to finding the best machine out there(cost be damned).The first thing that caught my attention was all the hype about the Braun 7 series, so I bought a 720(that's the one without the cleaning station).It was the silver one that's now been replaced by the new black 720-4. So I concluded that my 720(on sale for $180)was the best of its class.I loved everything about it--it's ergonomic sexy design and floating foils, for example(but not the lack of a protective plastic cap for the head--inexcusable),but was so disappointed to find it didn't shave close enough.So, regretably, I returned it before the 30 day deadline for a full refund and went back to using my Panasonic GA21. Following up on my research, I knew my next move was this Panasonic LA63,priced at just $130 at Amazon!(less than half list price of $300). Straight out of the box I loved it--everything works beautifully, the head pivots both ways with ease, the four blades and two motors feel powerful as the large head plows through my medium beard like a lawn mower.And, most of all of course, it shaves close!! Not as good as a blade but not far from it. It's comfortable as can be and never pulls as the Braun did. The big head is actually an asset as it covers more territory for a faster shave.The vibration in the head is very subtle compared to the Braun, which feels like a face massage--quite nice. And the upper lip is no problem for me; you just use fewer foils and it comes out fine. It's not perfect on the neck, but that may have something to do with the fact that my skin isn't as tight as it used to be, particularly under the chin, and so may not be a problem for younger guys. It comes with nice bells and whistles like the charge level LED readout and cleans like a breeze under running water. I suspect this unit will shave extremely well when wet, but I only shave dry. So, for me, this is possibly the best electric shaver out there, and I see Men's Health magazine agrees, as the LA63 has been voted best grooming aid for 2010. In addition, it has received other awards this year. l

  119. I know most people reading these reviews are just going to quickly skim through so I will keep this brief. First of all I've used all different types of razors and shaving techniques and would say that this is by far the most convenient and effective razor of any kind I have ever used. It does take some time to get used to but I would say after about a week or two you will know for sure whether or not this razor is right for you. It has a timer letting you know how long each shave takes and after a week or so I got it down to about 3 minutes which is convenient if you're in a hurry to get to work or whatever you do in the morning.<br /><br />Pros: The motor is faster than a lot of other electric razors and this allows for minimal contact with the skin to remove the hair. Whereas the price is somewhat higher than what I was wanting to pay, it is SIGNIFICANTLY cheaper on amazon than other retailers, seriously if you don't believe me check other websites or retail stores. I won't say where but it was 40-50 dollars less on here than it was on a similar website. The four blade pivoting head is also really nice, it seems kind of big at first but after the second or third shave you realize you can cover more area of your beard in a faster manner than with the smaller shaving heads.<br /><br />Cons: The most noticeable flaw is going to be the price, my advice is that if you're not comfortable with paying whatever the current price is look at a cheaper model Panasonic from the same product family. I personally use it for a dry shave either after or before a shower or sometimes just whenever I get around to shaving but from what I've read is that it won't last as long if you use it for wet shaves, honestly I don't know nor do I care but that seems to be said by a lot of people who've used this for wet shaves based on other reviews. So if that bothers you maybe look at a different razor. One last thing that kind of bothers me is the amount of time you spend on your neck and jawline, given NO electric razors work well on your neck or jawline but I expected this to be a little better in that area.<br /><br />Finally, you will probably will get some initial irritation to your skin on the first few shaves. Most of that will depend on what your shaving method was prior to using this razor and how long it has been since you last shaved. To prevent this you could shave every other day for the first week or two or even consider shaving at night so by the time you go to work or whatever you do during the day, the irritation will be unnoticeable. In conclusion, I would recommend this product to anyone who is looking for a clean shave without the razor burn and hassle of dealing with replacement blades/shaving cream and all that other BS every morning. Anyways, hope this helps.

  121. I read up on Amazon all the shavers, styles, and tips - BTW Thanks Guys! -and decided to give this one a try as it was on sale and everyone was talking about how the rotation speed was higher on the Panasonics. This one is 14,000rpm. I have a light beard and was previously using a Norelco Nivea with a Braun M-60 for touch up. Wet shaving took about 30 minutes for a razor smooth shave. As the title says - Love at first shave! I fully charged and took it into the shower. I used a dab of Billie Jealosy as recommended by a poster and while it did take multiple passes, especially until I figured out there is a proper angle to hold it at for the magic to happen - which they actually provide a diagram of in the instructions, but in ten minutes I had baby soft skin with zero stubble, no ingrown hairs, no need for touch up and NO RAZOR BURN. Now I'm not that sensitive, but my back neck area STILL didn't like the Norelco after several months use. The aftershave would still sting there pretty good and I'd get a tingle all over. After shaving with this, I KNEW, I mean I KNEW that this wasn't the case here as my head didn't feel like it had just been shaved and sure enough, not even a tingle from the aftershave! And trimming around my beard was easier becuase of the straight foil vs the rotary as well. If you're a head shaver like myself I strongly encourage you to give this one a try!

  124. I have used this razor now for about three weeks, about 15 shaves. I had for some 55 years used a Gillette razor and blades and occasionally a Braun electric shaver. I have a fairly heavy beard. I got tired of paying outrageous prices for Gillette blades so I wanted to give another electric a try. This Panasonic gives a very good shave. Although not as close as the Gillette , it is good enough for me. I am retired so I do not need a shave that lasts all day. In the past I could not stand a five o'clock shadow at two o'clock, but now that is no problem. The head of the shaver is rather large so getting to tight places ( eg, above the lip) is not easy. The Panasonic is very smooth running across the face; it gives a close shave for an electric; and it is easy to clean. It is better than the Braun I had. I would recommend this shaver.
  125. Wow, what a step up in electric razors, will never do back to super expensive Gillette blades. This razor works super fast, no irriation, and is sold for a great price. You will start saving money in three months versus paying $8 week for Gillette four blade razors. Battery life is also very good, lasts well over 2 weeks.
  126. I am a head shaver. I have used electric razors and blades on my head for years. I just got this razor and it is light years ahead of any razor i have ever used for face and head.   127. excellent shave takes me 5 minutes for the closest shave. no problem saying close as a razor. the large head looks like it would be awkward but it really isn't much bigger than any other and takes seconds to get used to it. have been using braun for 15+ years. tried the top norelco rotary just before i tried this panasonic. i returned it. i wouldn't spend $300 for the top braun and the specs on the panasonic appeared to top the braun. this panasonic is hands down better than all of them and half the price. the only disappointment? no simple stand. have to just lay it on the counter to charge and when not in use.

  129. Best shave I've had from an electric, ever - and at least as good as a straight razor shave. The only thing preventing me from giving 5 stars is the price. After trying this shaver dry, wet (just water), and lubricated with shaving soap and/or shaving oil (each separately and both together), the best shave came in the shower, using just a few drops of [[ASIN:B000G014V8 American Crew Essential Shave Oil, 1.7 oz]] which provides just the right amount of lubrication. I also like to use a shaving balm afterwards and find this to be very effective [[ASIN:B00127Q13K Nivea For Men Extreme Comfort Post Shave Balm, 3.3-Ounce Bottle (Pack of 3)]]. With this shaver, it takes me about 2-3 minutes to shave my face completely smooth. I am military, and have fairly thick, quick-growing facial hair. Getting a good shave in the morning is important, or I have to shave again after lunch. Normally I can't get a close enough shave with electrics, but I can with this one. It's even slightly better than the Braun 7 series which I'm now keeping at work as a backup shaver for the really long days. Battery life is pretty good. It charges in less than an hour and lasts a week and a half at 2-3 minutes of shaving per day. For travelers - this shaver has a locking mechanism on the power switch so you won't have to worry about it being switched on in your luggage (NICE!) After reading some of the bad reviews, I'd suggest you get this version and avoid paying for the charging/cleaning stand which apparently has reliability problems. A wet/dry shaver doesn't need a fancy cleaning stand anyway - just open it and run it under the faucet when you're done using it and splash some alcohol on it once a week or so to sanitize. PROS: Great Shave!! Wet/Dry. Good battery life/Quick charging. Locking power switch. CONS: Price.

  149. Takes 20+ minutes to shave. Leaves too many unshaved clumps. Cuts skin. Pulls hair. Returning ASAP
  150. I just purchased the ES-LA63-S to take advantage of the $30 rebate available from Panasonic until 12/31/2010. I upgraded from an older Panasonic model, the very capable ES-8075-S with Vortex cleaning system. The ES-LA63-S model is superior to my older Panasonic, without question. The blades seem a touch more powerful, the shave a bit closer. In addition, the slight curve present in the \\"Arc\\" foil and cutting blades do seem to provide an advantage compared to the \\"straight\\" foil and blades of my older shaver. Note that the ES-LA63-S is the exact same shaver as the more expensive ES-LA93-K; the only difference between them is that the ES-LA93-K comes in black and includes a drying/cleaning/charging base station. The truth is, you don't need this station, because the shaver is ridiculously easy to clean under running warm tap water with a little liquid or bar soap, and to air dry. The shaver features a sideburn trimmer, which works fairly well, and comes with a charging cord and black travel case. This shaver features two motors (one with horizontal oscillation; the other with vertical oscillation), a 14,000 RPM cutting speed, four foils and is made in Japan (some of Panasonic's lower-end models are made in China). The blue-backlit LCD screen tells you how much charge is remaining, how much time you've been shaving for, and when the shaver needs to be cleaned. One full charge provides about 40-45 minutes of shaving time. As with all electric shavers, I find some slight touch-up with a razor is necessary afterwards (usually on a small part of the neck), but the bottom line is that by using an electric for the bulk of the shaving, you are saving a ton of friction and irritation on your face. My personal tips to get the most out of this model: 1) Use a shaving oil (olive oil works great) and warm water and shaving cream for the most comfortable shave. The oil helps provide extra lubrication for the cutting blades as they pass across your skin. I do believe that the use of oil and a wet shave provides for a far superior and more comfortable experience than a dry shave. This is the main advantage of the Panasonic line-up over the Braun series -- the Braun models can't be used in the shower or with water and shaving cream. 2) Lock the shaving head so that it doesn't move. I find this makes it easier to control the shaver and aim it at specific spots on one's face. 3) Clean your shaver after every shave to keep it smelling fresh and clean. This takes 45 seconds at most. Remove the foil top from the shaver and rub liquid hand soap or bar soap lather over the foil and cutting blades. Wash them clean under running warm water. Place the shaver (with foil top still removed) upside down on a paper towel or some toilet paper to \\"gravity\\" air-dry. That's it. 4) Drain the battery fully before re-charging it -- this helps to prolong the life of the rechargeable battery. In closing, bear in mind that Panasonic's own literature states that anyone switching to electric shaving from a razor will take about 30 days to fully adjust to it.
  151. I have used Braun electrics for years. All eventually needed replacement because their batteries needed replacement. They are OK but loud, and take a long time to get a close shave.<br /><br />The Panasonic is a little bulky looking at first, but it's a good shape and size for the job. The shave is fast and efficient and close. A feature I especially appreciate is the display that measures remaining battery life. It's smartly done: they figure you'll get about 10 shaves from a charge (100%), and each reading is a multiple, like 60% remaining. Depending how sleepy I am, some shaves take longer, but you always kind of know where you stand. I also think that there's some reserve power at 0% so you won't end up half-shaven. This simple feature ensures that the battery is charged correctly (before it is completely empty) which should allow the battery to last much longer. Also, you know where you stand so don't need to bring a cord on trips unless you're away for a while.<br /><br />The blades oscillate super-fast, and it's he sound is a quiet, high-pitched buzz. Much quieter than my old Braun.<br /><br />Works wet or dry. I use dry.<br /><br />Recharge is quick: about an hour. Then unplug and your good for a week or so.<br /><br />Cleaning is great. There's a &#34;turbo mode&#34; -- put some soap on the foil, turn on the cleaning mode and run under water, and it basically shakes all the skuzz off, and turns off when done, about 15 or 30 seconds.<br /><br />Highly recommended.
  152. I have been buying Panasonic razors for over 25 years, with this purchase I bought a more expensive one than I normally do. The other ones were good, this one is great.
  153. The Panasonic ES-LA63S is a replacement for a Braun 7500 purchased some 10 years ago, a shaver which I have been happy with in terms of performance, but alas in absolute ignorance of the giant steps forward in technology in recent years. Having been used to the \\"5 O'Clock shaddow\\" for the last ten years I have known nothing better, however when my 7500 died just prior to Christmas 2010, my wonderful wife bought me a new electronic razor, the Panasonic ES-LA63s.....Why the Panasonic...well I chose this razor after much research on the net and having read many reviews on all the shavers available I decided on a 63s. a Wet and Dry shaver. The reason I chose a 63s and not a 93s was simply the cost, the 93s was $100 more but included a charging/cleaning station which required a constant and very frequent change of cleaning fluid,(which is expensive) and with the 63 being a wet and dry shaver and literally cleaned under the tap, the obvious question was asked....why do I need a cleaning station...simply plug the damn thing into the mains and charge it up around twice a month...simple really...no nead for another bulky box sat on the bathroom windowsill causing more clutter.AND THE 63 IS THE SAME SPEC AS THE 93 The first time I used this shaver was on Christmas morning,2010 after my shower, I shaved in the washbasin with shaving foam, I could not believe how smooth the shave was compared to the Braun (which was a dry shaver). My face was ultra smooth....\\"as smooth as the proverbial babies bum\\"..the last time I had a shave this close and to last all day was when I was in my twenties and wet shaved every morning, which left me with horrendous shaving rashes around my collar line. I am now 62 years young and honestly wish that this technology had been available in my youth..BUT I am so glad this shaver has been developed by Panasonic, it is light years ahead anything available just 10 years ago, I am very happy with this shaver and would strongly recommend it to anyonewho is used to a wet shave at present and who is thinking of trying a wet/dry electric shaver, you will not be dissapointed, you will still be feeling your smooth chin when it is time to go to bed at night, and believe me, in the morning you will be asking yourself the question....\\"Do I need to shave this morning\\". This shaver is brilliant...The only reason I do not give it 5 stars is the high cost..but in time this will come down I am sure. Well done Panasonic...I have absolutely no idea what you are going to come up with for an encore.
