  155. My last 3 electric razors have been Braun's, so I was hesitant to make a switch since the Braun's have always worked well for me. When I bought my latest Braun 4 years ago I went for the top of the line model - complete with self cleaning stand, etc. The self cleaning stand broke after 1 year and was expensive to maintain with their proprietary refills, so after the initial coolness factor wore off, that wasn't very useful. I replaced the blade and foil about every year with my Braun and that kept it cutting very nicely. It would be easy to say that this new Panasonic cuts so much better but that wouldn't be a fair comparison since I am comparing a new Panasonic blade to my Braun's blade, which was about 1 year old when I replaced it. And even with my older Braun, putting in a new [...] blade made it feel almost new again. The biggest pros for me of this Panasonic over the Brauns are: 1) Price - to get a top of the line Braun it would have cost twice as much as this Panasonic model, which I picked up for eight nine dollars after rebate. If performance is equal I'm not going to pay twice as much because I'm loyal to a brand. 2) Surface area - this Panasonic has a much larger surface area on the razor head, which means I can shave faster. I shave every day so to cut off a couple of minutes has been quite nice. 3) Wet or Dry shave option - I didn't buy the Panasonic for this reason, and I still use the dry shave most of the time, but it is a pretty nice option to have. And the fact that it can get wet makes cleaning much easier as well. Overall I've been really pleased with this razor after a month of use and haven't missed my Braun one bit!
  156. Excellent, works perfectly!
  157. I have shaved with cordless shavers all my life (I'm 73) and have used Remington, Braun, Norelco, and Panasonic. Each time I made a purchase it was for a claimed faster, smoother shaver with a longer lasting battery. Each time I ended up with a shaver that performed about the same as the last one. My last two shavers have been Panasonic because I find them the most comfortable. When my last one quit (no longer would hold a charge), I looked at Panasonic's ES-LA63-S. Panasonic's MSRP is $300, Amazon had it on sale for $94 and Panasonic had a mail-in $30 rebate. We all love a bargain and at this price how could I miss? For the first time I got a shaver that IS faster, smoother, and has a longer lasting battery. Lithium Ion batteries are a definite step up and hold a charge longer. My last shaver would do 5 to 6 shaves on a charge. The ES-LA63-S does 8 to 9 shaves. The old shaver took 7 minutes for a close shave. The ES-LA63-S takes 5.1/2 minutes. The high speed cleaning mode is quick and effective. I put a little dish soap in a small cup with warm water and run the shaver through a couple of cleaning cycles, rinse it, and it's done. The ES-LA63-S is a product that delivers as advertised, The only negative is that the shaver is battery only. It can't run on the charging cord. However, it will charge enough for one shave in 5 minutes which isn't too inconvenient when you forget to charge the battery. This is the best shaver I have owned and I recommend it.

  171. Charge the shaver when the power is 0%, not 10%. It helps to extend the life of the battery (and the shaver).<br /><br />I shave about 1 min a day, and the battery level drops from 100% to 10% in 2 weeks. After that, the battery remains at 10% for 10 weeks and drops to 0%. So don't get fooled by the battery indicator. :-)
  172. purchase for my son. not really sure yet on the durability. it seems kind of bulky on the head but really have never used an electric shaver, he's still getting used to it -- time will tell
  173. I purchased this shaver from Amazon. Before, I was using one of those 3-circle bladed units. While it worked ok, it always cut my skin especially around the nook of my mouth (where upper lip meets lower lip). This shaver, however, is the best shaver I have ever used.<br /><br />I hate using the old school shaver with foam and all that. I simply do not have the time or patience to deal with it. So electric shavers are the only units that interest me.<br /><br />After using this product for several months, this Panasonic unit has many clear positive features. First, it has great battery life. The screen on the unit even let's the user know how much juice is left. It also charges fast and indicates when it is done by a blinking blue light. This thing is also comfortable to hold; it is not too heavy and is slightly curved to easily fit into your hand.<br /><br />But the most important aspect of any razor is how well it works. Like I said, I have sensitive skin that would easy get cut and become dry with my old unit. I have not been cut by this unit one time and the pivoting head makes shaving as easy as it can be. Clean up is easy too. For the most part, all the hair clippings were caught by the razor head to avoid messes (only slight spillage). I always clean my razor after every use, but the little screen tells you when you need to clean the unit. And cleaning is easy, you just simply unclip the razor head and rinse with cold water. There really is nothing to it. The one-touch ON makes this unit easy to use too.<br /><br />When turned on, this little unit just feels powerful. The buzz that it recreates is really something that needs to be felt. It is very strong for its size and overall works very well.<br /><br />My only complaint about this unit is the clipper on the back. You need to use some force to get it to pop out and it is quite small. It is nice that you do not need to attach something extra to make this shaver into a clipper, and the smaller size allows for more accurate control, but I would have liked it to be a little wider.<br /><br />The unit also comes with everything you will need including a little travel pouch and AC adapter. It would have been nice if it included an extra razor head (which you should change every year or so) but for the price, I guess I shouldn't complain.but I would have liked it to be a little wider. The unit also comes with everything you will need including a little travel pouch and AC adapter. It would have been nice if it included an extra razor head (which you should change every year or so) but for the price, I guess I shouldn't complain.
  174. I have the same one in Black. Wifey got this one for me about 7 months ago. I have never owned an electric shaver so I was impressed how close it shaves. I use to buy the Gillete triple blade 8 pk razors, about $10 p/pack. Pros Quick and close shave Convenient for people on the go Worth the investment Cons Takes about 30-45 mins for the dock to clean the shaver. I think its waay too long. Beard hair comes back out about 1/2 day earlier compared to razor shaving. I probably need to do the Wet Shave to get a close shave tho. The trimmer totally doesn't do it's job, unless I'm using it wrong. But I don't really care because I'm more concerned with the overall shave. Instead of buying the expensive Gillet razors I buy from the 99 cent store now to do all my trimming. I totally recommend it!
  175. It's ok for me,and I think it's better than 760cc.
  176. Panasonic shaver is the best for me. The battery does last much longer than Braun. Panasonic just redesigned the head and it does contour to the face much better than the regular straight head like the Braun shaver.
  177. Although I have used electric razors for about 12 years, I was not much of an electric razor fan preferring a traditional razor shave with heated gel or cream. Based on that, I tried this product with a great deal of pessimism. However, Panasonic won me over but an obvious high price.<br /><br />This is a foil shaver (compare to rotary) that works wet or dry. From what I can tell, this is the most advanced rechargeable shaver not only in material (although there is plastic used in the shaver), but also in technology though I dispute the necessity (and cost) of an LCD screen. The shaver is very quiet with no vibration. It is very easy to handle and feels as if some ergonomic design was considered. The LCD screen displays current charge level of the battery. However, the charge for me (at this point) lasts for over three weeks of almost daily use. The shaver provides an extremely close shave due to a floating head and does so without pulling any hair. Its worth noting that the heads work both horizontally and vertically allowing you to shave in any direction. Nevertheless, the end resulting shave is not as close as using a traditional multiblade razor (such as a Quattro) with cream. Since I prefer a dry shave, I cannot adequately comment on shaver performance in the shower. The side burn trimmer works fantastic on mustaches as well as sideburns.<br /><br />The shaver comes with a decent carrying case (vinyl) with a durable zipper but only holds the shaver and not accessories. My box did not include a cleaning brush or stand which I find odd. However, since the shaver is wet/dry, you can clean it under running water.<br /><br />Clearly this is an excellent shaver. However, at this price, you would expect it to be.
  178. Just from browsing some of the other reviews I see that most people agree that this shaver is excellent. It gets up close and anything it misses a quick brush with the precision trimmer will knock it out. In addition to that it has some nice amenities, such as a wobble head that makes it even easier to get around the curves of your face. An LED light that says how long you have been shaving and the amount of battery life left.<br /><br />All and all, an excellent electric shaver. But $300?!<br /><br />If you're like me, seeing that price tag better mean this bad boy does something no electric shaver in the history of shavers has ever done before. Unfortunately, I can't say that is the case. Before I was using another Panasonic shaver, the [[ASIN:B000VKZMHK Panasonic ES8109S Vortex Wet/Dry Shaver with Nano Technology and HydraClean System]], and while it has a few less blades, I honestly can't tell much of a difference in performance. Both charge up as quickly, have LED lights, is wet/dry, gets a really close shave while feeling extremely gentle.. yet the Vortex is 1/3 the price. Hmm..<br /><br />So all in all, I couldn't give this a bad rating, because it is excellent. If you get it, you will like it. I promise. However, if money is an object, I wouldn't hesitate to shop around for a similar (cheaper) product that is just as good.
  179. Razors are somewhat personal. What works for one person isn't necessarily right for another person. I don't have one of those tough beards that needs a chainsaw to shave. I have the opposite problem that my whiskers don't stand up enough to get into the cutting area of most electric razors without repeated passes. I have tried many electric razors by Braun, Norelco, etc. and finally found a Panasonic electric that was very effective. I liked that one a lot and when it finally died after years of service I got a Panasonic ES8249K Arc IV Nano Vortex Wet/Dry Rechargeable Shaving System which was the replacement for the earlier model and really liked it. Then this razor came out. I like it even better than the previous Panasonic I had. It is better at getting the corners, the edges and the flats than the previous razor which I was very happy with. I can shave in about 30% less time with this razor. I use it dry as the wet just makes by whiskers even less likely to be in the right place on the razor.
  180. A good razor if it was in the next pricing tier down from where it is. Considering the lack of a cleaning station, and it's utterly useless trimmer, it lacks the \\"wow\\" feeling that you should get from a razor of this class.<br /><br />Pros:<br />-Cuts close with no skin irritation<br />-charges fast, holds charge for a long time<br />-clear LCD displays remaining battery life<br /><br />Cons:<br />-No cleaning station. Some other Panasonic razors come with a base station which automatically cleans and charges the razor with the touch of a button, but this model lacks this feature, and requires manual cleaning.<br />-the razor head is HUGE. It feels a little bit like shaving with a brick. You can't see what's going on while you're shaving, so this razor is best suited for people without beards/mustaches.<br />-the trimmer jams easily. You have to move it VERY slowly or else it jams up.

So I do have the shaver - shaves great (dry) and no cleaning solutions necessary. I don't cut myself (cost a fortune in new white dress shirts) and life is good.

  183. Three years ago I purchased a Braun 7000 razor which considering the price, has been pretty disappointing. It didn't shave any closer or more comfortably than a Norelco which I had used for years (updating every couple of years). When the Braun's blades needed replacement and the chrome finish started to peel off, I began looking around for something better. The reviews on the Panasonic indicated that it was superior to Braun at about half the price. So I gave it a shot. It has indeed been superior to the Braun in every way. And I don't have to buy cleaning solution every couple of months at a steep price. (Considering it's only denatured alcohol.) If you have the double whammy.....tough beard and sensitive skin, give this one a try.

  186. I bought this razor a bit over a month ago, and it was my second electric razor. I bought my first one about 20 years ago, used it for a few weeks, and went back to a blade. At the time I was convinced that no electric could match a blade. This razor changed my mind about that. My face is so incredibly smooth after I shave with it, it is incredible. I shave in the shower, so water resistance is a must.<br />A little lather, and a two minute shave, and I am good to go. A charge lasts about 3 weeks. I would also say that using a shaving gel and an aftershave gel makes the shave better. There was a little irritation for the first week, but that is all gone now. I recommend this product.<br /><br />EDITED TO ADD:<br />So after 6 months, the razor died. I use it to shave in the shower, and it looks like water damaged it. I am lowering the rating from 5 stars to two, because a razor that costs $140 should last longer than six months.
  187. This is the best electric shaver I have ever had. Far better shave than an old Braun 5000. Charges in about an hour and lasts 2 weeks. Not readily available in the UK so I had to order from the USA. Price was 30% of the UK price for a [[ASIN:B002N5MHLK Panasonic ES-LA93-K Men's Shaver]] which I think is a waste of money as the only difference is that the LA 93 comes with a cleaner, so they can sell you expensive cleaning supplies . The LA 63 is very easy to clean with a bit of liquid soap and tap water, once a week. Cleans perfectly. The only niggle is the on/off button is poorly placed - I often switch it off inadvertently while shaving, but you can set the lock to prevent it happening.
  188. I'll just repeat what everyone else says on the up side. This shaver gives the best cut of any current shaver.<br /><br />That being said, how could they make a shaver that won't run direct off the cord? Could it be that tough? Sometimes, you'll use the saver and it'll be near dead and you set it down and run out the door. That evening, you don't remember to put it on the cord to charge, so next morning, it's dead or dies while you are using it. Not a problem if you're anal retentive and up an hour early, just charge it up. But if you're like the rest of us and running behind, dancing around teenagers in the bathroom, etc. having a shaver that can't run plugged in is a big time negative.<br /><br />Seems like this was an oversight. Hard to believe it can't be set-up that way. Most every other shaver does. Which is why I have to keep my old braun in the drawer for emergencies. Bad news.
  189. This is decent shaver, when it worked. I never was able to get very close shave, but shave quality was acceptable (mediocre). It has been more than six month. If this is how Panasonic stands behind their products, I will never buy anything from them.<br /><br />Update (6/2/2014): I got a new replacement shaver from Panasonic. It took them almost a year to do this. I updated review from one to 3 stars. I would still not recommended this shaver to anyone, but at least the company stands behind their products.   190. It work very good and clear very conveniently. I brought it with $119.99 but now the price is $99.99. I lost $20!
  191. Be aware this model has the motor and stuff in the head so it will not fit the cleaning cradle of the others. Been using this for over a year now and still shaves decently well dry, better wet. (Actually to save time these days, I just shave in the shower. Takes about 3.5 min which is really nice since I come from using a straight razor.) Doesn't shave as closely as straight razor (well nothing does), especially around the neck area where it meets the jaw and by the ears, but I guess that's mostly due to the wide head. However, the time savings makes it tolerable. Haven't needed to replace anything yet, including blades. I run the battery down until it starts flashing 10% left, then charge it up. After a year of use this way, it still appears to retain its charge just as long as it always has. As others have mentioned, would be nice if it came with a stand for drying. The locking mechanism is worthless, easier to just hold it with your fingers. And the trimmer is decent at longer hair like sideburns, but inevitably it's simpler to just use a straight razor to ensure a clean edge. I give it 4 stars because of the time savings. 3 stars in terms of closeness of shave and actually getting most of it done instead of leaving strange patches like other electric shavers do. UPDATE: 2013-01-08, well, the lcd screen crapped out about 2 months ago. some of the blue letters appear, but fractionally, so that you can't actually read anything. it all still seems to work, but you can't figure out the status. UPDATE: 2014-01-19, So I bought the replacement blades and foils and wow! I should've replaced them sooner! Definitely like brand new again. It's always hard to judge when to replace since everyone's hair is different and treatment of the shaver is different, but I'd say on average use, about 6-8 months warrants a replacing. The only con is the price: each replacement set runs about $30 on the low end to I've seen as high as mid $40s. UPDATE: 2014-04-28, Well the battery just doesn't hold a charge like it used to anymore. I searched online and found the appropriate replacement battery. Swapped it out and the thing works well again. Be aware that you need to reseal very well to prevent water intrusion!! UPDATE: 2014-06-30, Even though I replaced the battery with the OEM Panasonic model, the shaver doesn't hold the charge as well as the original In as little as 4 shaves, it needs recharging again. Disappointed. I took it apart to swap again, but the replacement batteries are now running about $30 min. UPDATE: 2014-07-30, I bit the bullet and bought a new one. LV61 arc5
  192. Got this as a Christmas gift for husband and loves the new shaver. It's been 5 months and the shaver is still working nicely. It gets a nice close shave and gets around the tough edges.
  193. I finally pulled the trigger yesterday and bought the Panasonic ES-LA63-S over the Norelco 1250x/40 which was the other contending shaver.<br /><br />I have been a Norelco man since the past 10 -12 years now so it was a tough choice for me to move to a foil shaver over a rotary. Ultimately I decided to go to a foil shaver because I wanted to try something new and because I read quite a few reviews that said foils are closer shavers then rotary. I also read quite a bit of very good reviews about the Panasonic shavers. Honestly I think they are both very comparable and the Norelco is probably even a bit better in built quality, but in the end I didn't like being tied to a base for charging the shaver and I didn't like the fact that my past Norelco's came with mediocre trimmer. I felt I should give foil shaver a chance.<br /><br />I bought this shaver yesterday and used it today for the first time. I was really impressed with the smoothness of the shave. One thing I noticed right off the bat was that the hair that was being cut by the Panasonic was so fine it turned the water/shaving cream into a gray paste while the hair from the Norelco's I have had in the past have been tinny chips but not fine powder like. I have fairly thick hair and it grows in all directions on my neck but the shaver took care of everything in one run. No issues for me like some of the other reviews I read.<br /><br />Since I was already an electric shaver user, it didn't take time for me to get accustomed to the shave. It felt very natural and comfortable. I did not have any redness or irritation from the shave and my skin didn't get dry.<br /><br />Cleaning it was a breeze and personally don't think the automatic cleaner is necessary for a $100 more. The only thing I wish the shaver came with was a base so I can have a place to stand instead of laying it flat down when drying.
  194. I've used electric shavers for a number of years now. I've found using a blade is too rough for my skin. I've used this razor both wet and dry and for me personally the wet method with shaving cream provides the closest shave. It is slightly more time consuming, but I enjoy the ritual of it.<br /><br />My beard isn't particularly thick - I can grow a mean goatee, my beard is acceptable - but not as thick as the mustache and chin area. This shaver works as well in the thick parts as it does anywhere. It is powerful and well built. For $130 bucks with shipping it is a no brainer.

  196. I've been a Norelco user most of my adult life (I'm 57). I even tried an expensive Grundig once and sent it back. Didn't like it. This Panasonic is by far the best shaver I've ever used. The biggest advantage seems to be the RPM speed. It is just so clearly more powerful and that speed makes for a faster, cleaner cut. The engineering is great, too. The thing swivels and rotates and makes the Norelco individual shaving heads moot. It's a breeze to snap off the head and blow out the hair.<br />And because it's waterproof, you can pour a little liquid soap onto the heads, watch it foam up and then rinse it clean as a whistle. Don't need to do that every day but, say, once a week and you're good.<br />I'm used to dry shaving and an electric so there was no adjustment there. I thought I might like using shaving cream, which you can do with this shaver, but I found it difficult to pull my face taut and get a clean line at the sideburns and mustache so I gave up on that. I haven't even tried using it in the shower. I'm good with dry shaving.<br />An anecdote? On Sunday afternoon, after not shaving since Friday morning, my beard stubble was itchy so I just did a fast pass on my face and loved the result. I would have never done that with my previous shavers. This thing is just that comfortable - I don't dread shaving anymore.

In all my years of shaving I have always felt that an electric was a compromise from using a blade. Well have now been corrected.   205. The electric shaver vs razor battle has been back and forth for me since I was 16. I have owned several electric shavers to include a Norelco rotary blade electric razor, Panasonic foil blade shaver, and most recently the Braun 8595 razor. These shavers would work well for a while, but I just would not get the close shave I wanted, and I would end up going back to the conventional way of shaving while spending hundreds of dollars on disposable blades. The Braun shaver was probably the best out of all the Electric shavers I owned to this point, but the fact that I had to buy the cleaning solution for it frequently became tiresome. It is frustrating because I have sensitive skin, and electric shavers give me no irritation,and I do not get razor burn when I use them. In the profession I am in I am required to look professional, so shaving is scrutinized closely. In order to get the close shave I need, I have had to use a combination of my Braun shaver and Mach 5 razors because I do not get the shave I need from an electric shaver alone. I have to spend a decent amount of money on expensive shaving creams and after shave balms to help with that close, irritation and razor burn shave. The electric shavers work well in my face area, but always fail in my neck. I have used electric shavers to shave my face, but use Mach 5 razors to shave my neck. Because of my sensitive skin, my neck is always irritated after I shave. With this said I finally broke down and became willing try the latest technology in electric shavers because the cost and time put into shaving were becoming a burden. Armed with the desire to have a close, quick, inexpensive, and irritation/razor burn free shave, I began looking at reviews from various sites including amazon on the latest electric shavers. The most important factor I wanted in a new shaver is its ability to give me a close irritation free shave on my neck as this has been my problem area for years. I looked at all brands to include Braun, Phillips, Panasonic, and Remington. Because I currently owner a Braun Shaver, and based on the positive reviews of the Series 7-760cc, I began leaning heavily to purchasing that shaver. It wasn't until I read and article on line about Panasonic's Arc series shavers about how it was designed to shave problem areas such as the neck and chin that I began looking into the Panasonics more closely. The more reviews I read on the various Arc series shavers, the more I began to see that these razor may be what I have been looking for all these years. I ruled out the Braun based on the price and having to deal with the cleaning solution again. I narrow the search down to two shavers, the Panasonic ES8243A Arc IV and the ES-LA-63 Arc IV. Both have overwhelming reviews and both are rated and 4 1/2 stars. The LA-63 is about $50 more, but still considerably less expensive than the Braun. Based on what users have said in their reviews, I felt the LA-63 would suit my needs in shaving. I bought the LA-63 two weeks ago. In its first task, I had not shaven in a week and had a considerable amount of facial hair. The Braun I had had issues with snagging my hair when it got too long. The LA-63 had no such issue and shaved very smoothly, plus I used it in the shower where as my Braun could not be used wet. The shaver shaved very quickly too, taking only 3 and 1/2 minutes. Under my old shaving routine, it would have taken about ten. I was amazed at how smooth my face was after I was done shaving. The best part is that I had little irritation and no razor burn. I did experience some irritation, but this was expected as there is a period of adjustment whenever a new electric razor is used. The shaver also cleans easy because you can use hand soap and do not have to rely cleaning cartridges. The 5 minute quick charge is also a nice feature. Though there were many positive features, the shaver let me down in one area, the neck. The shaver could not clean up all of my neck and left several patches of hair. I tried going over these areas several times, but only caused my self irritation. I had to used a conventional razor to shave my neck area. This was a big disappointment because one of the reasons I bought the razor was the Arc series shaver was designed to tackle the neck hair. I did not want to give up on the razor yet. I figured I would give it some time and try shaving wet and dry, and use different types of shave creams. The results were that I still got a close, smooth shave on my face, but the neck still was a problem area. Shaving dry did help get a little close with the neck, but it still was not perfect. It was about to give up on this razor when I discovered Aramis Lab Series Electric Shave Solution. Using this product in combination with the LA-63 gave me that close shave on my neck I need without razor burn or irritation. I now have no complaints about this razor and it is the best electric shaver I have ever used.
  206. I bought the ES-LA63-S in May 2010 from a local store, and the comfort and closeness of the shave far surpassed the Braun Series 7-790cc Pulsonic Shaver and numerous Norelco shavers that I had used previously. I especially liked using it wet with standard shaving cream, which provided a shave that was 99% as close as a Gillette Fusion razor. I liked it so much, I bought one from Amazon for my wife to use on her legs and she likes it much better than the Norelco unit she had before. Unfortunately, after four months, my ES-LA63-S developed problems with the display where most of the segments were illuminated all the time, making it impossible to read the state of charge or any of the status flags. It did work OK right after charging, but after using it the next day, it was back to the mixed up display. So I called Panasonic Customer Service and got directions to completely discharge and recharge for 8 hours. (As before, it worked after charging, but returned to the scrambled display after the next use.) The agent told me if that didn't help, to return it for exchange. So at my expense, I sent it UPS to the Panasonic Exchange Center in Texas, where it arrived on Oct 5th. Two weeks later, I received a replacement shaver: an ES8249S! I don't get how they think this is a comparable unit (lower list price, only one motor, and with the annoying charging/cleaning station). If this is comparable, why do they even bother making the ES-LA63-S? They enclosed a form letter apologizing for the substitution in order to provide the \\"highest quality and most timely service\\". They also included a URL for their customer satisfaction survey, which, needless to say, didn't get a glowing response from me. I'll see if I hear back from them. I'm not sure if I have any recourse, other than to write reviews like this!
  207. So far so good. I haven't had the razor but a few weeks; but for the money and the cost of Gillette Razor blades how can I go wrong.
  208. For the price I was expecting to be blown away. Lesser than that, I was expecting it to replace my cheaper and older Norelco rotary. It did neither. What the Panasonic has is build quality and speed. I give it two stars for that. I shave dry and I don't have much facial hair, but my strands are thicker.   212. Bought this in early June '11 as a replacement for Braun's most expensive model. Was a Braun fan for 20-plus years, until that last one fell apart exactly 13 months after purchase. Too many small, weak, plastic parts used at stress points. In addition, the Braun required expensive replacement fluid cartridges in its cleaning system. The Panasonic, thus far, works exactly as advertised. It shaves as well as the Braun, possibly slighter better than. The best feature is water cleaning - a relief after the time consuming, complex, noisy, and constantly-expensive process of the Braun. As a bonus: the battery charge on the Panasonic seems bottomless. I highly recommend this shaver.

Don't wait, purchase this product and start enjoying your daily shaving experience!
  215. ok does not get all under the chin
  216. The 5-star review might be a little misleading. Every Panasonic shaver I've owned (all triple-blade models) has given me a 5-star shave, and all give as good a shave as the ES-LA63. I didn't expect much (or any) improvement in shave quality because there wasn't a lot of room FOR improvement. I've owned the ES8224, ES8043, ES8807 and an ES7103 (which I got at for $35 a year ago). The ES8807 is my all-time favorite shaver...small, precise, and easy to navigate...that shaver \\"just works\\" for me. But I saw the ES-LA63 drop to an absurdly low price of $93 from Amazon and couldn't resist. The one negative with Panasonic for me has always been the Adams apple area because the middle trimmer blade sits up higher on Panasonics, causing irritation (and even cuts) in this area. I think the ES-LA63 is a little better (I assume because the vibrating head raises the hair and doesn't require as much pressure), but that is the only noticeable difference. Bottom line...if you can still get the ES-LA63 for $93, go for it. It's their top-of-the-line, latest and greatest model. But if the price jumps back up to $150 or even $130, you're better off getting a cheaper triple-blade Panasonic like the ES-8103, which is currently a steal for $53 at Amazon. Finally, Amazon had a limited offer of free 1-day shipping on this shaver. I wasn't in any hurry so a week would've been fine, plus I didn't think there was any chance they could deliver on the one-day promise. I placed my order the evening of 12/21, and to my amazement, my doorbell rang the evening of 12/22 and there was my shaver. If only cable companies, electricians, and plumbers could be this reliable.
  217. I HAD PROBLEMS WITH MY BRAUN 7 SERIES & NEEDED A REPLACEMENT. I APPRECIATED THE POSITIVE REVIEWS & PURCHASED THIS PANASONIC. THIS IS THE CLOSEST SHAVE I HAVE EVER HAD WITH AN ELECTRIC RAZOR. & THE PRICE IS MUCH LESS THAN THE BRAUN (BTW - I SENT THE BRAUN TO BE REPAIRED - THEY SENT IT BACK FIXED AT NO CHARGE SINCE IT WAS UNDER WARRANTY, HOWEVER I HAVE NOT USED IT SINCE ITS RETURN SOME 2 WEEKS AGO. DEF RECOMMEND THIS PANASONIC.
  218. I purchased this on a Black Friday deal in 2010, the list price was a little much for me. My airline has recently lost my last electric (a hair pulling torture device made by Norelco). I almost sent the airline a thank you card. I have been using this shaver almost every day for one year, it is without a doubt the best I have ever used. Previous electric shavers: Purchased in 2000: Braun bar style, sub par shaving and battery life. I swore off electrics for years after this razor Purchased in 2005: Norelco three head, I forget the model number. This was a very good shaver, used it for years. Purchased in 2009 (Old Norelco died, what a good razor): Purchased new one, 8/9 Something series, almost $100, expecting something as good as the previous. What I got was a hair pulling torture device. If you went more then 1 day without shaving, it would punish you by randomly pulling hairs out while shaving. I tried new blades, same problem. I barely used this razor. Purchased in 2010: Panasonic ES-LA63 Pros: - GREAT shave, closest shave on a electric, bar none - DOES NOT PULL STUBBLE!!! (I cannot say this enough) - Wet/Dry is nice, especially for cleaning - Lots of shaving surface, shaves quickly - Good blade life (got a year from the last set) Cons: - Cannot run while plugged in, this is inconvenient if you need a quick shave and the battery is dead - Like all electrics shavers I have used, it struggles when stubble is long (2+ days) and on stubborn neck hair - Blue LED is bright (i.e. flashes when charged) which is annoying at night - Expensive! Overall, this is the best electric razor that I have ever used. I had originally thought the list price was a bit much, however I must admit that I would pay the list price ($120 right now). If you have sworn of electrics, I would suggest you give this razor a try.
  219. I bought this shaver in 2015. I've bought several different models of Panasonic wet/dry shavers in the past. This one was by far the most expensive.<br /><br />It has also been the biggest disappointment. While my shaves were noticeably closer than with previous wet/dry shavers, here I am less than five months later with a non-functioning shaver, clearly due to a product defect and not from any damage I have done to it.<br /><br />A couple of weeks ago, it had appeared that a little water was someone getting into the LED read-out. It began to display incorrect information, for instance, lighting up all of the indicators at once so that I couldn't tell how much charge was left. Within the past couple of days, the LED indicator stopped working altogether, displaying nothing, although the back-light still seems to work. And now the shaver won't even turn on.<br /><br />Another complaint: I realize there is a little more RPMs with this model than others, but the battery life was unacceptably low. With previous, less-expensive shavers, I could count on going at least a few weeks in between charges. With this model, I've been lucky to get more than a week on a single charge.<br /><br />Very disappointing, especially considering that less than five months later, I'm stuck with it. No refund, no return.

Panasonic touted some newer technology, a nice design, and garnered good ratings, esp. here on Amazon's review (thanks guys!) I chose this model--this is one without the cleaning/charging stand-- because I did not see any advantage paying an additional one hundred dollars and then having to purchase cleaning cartridges. So far this shaver excels in speed, comfort, and closeness, including longer neck hairs. Dry shave was good, smoother and faster than the Norelco, with less irritation. The wet shave with a gel foam rivals a blade in closeness, but going \\"wet\\" sort of negates the convenience factor.Maybe I will try it in the shower. Cleaning is easy, so do not bother with the upgraded series. The trimmer works well, but is more awkward than the one on the Norelco. I can not comment as yet on battery life and recharging characteristics. Time will tell
  224. I also have a Braun 9595 and like it as well. However, I think this might even be better. I was planning on using it as a travel shaver, but like the Braun it's a bit heavy. It shaves close, doesn't hurt, and and easy to clean.

  240. I regularly use a blade razor for the majority of my shave and then use an electric shaver to clean up the nooks, crannies, and tender spots. I mention this to let you know that I've been using an electric for years so I have a good basis for comparison. The 2 critical features of an electric shaver to evaluate, in my opinion, are closeness of the shave and ease of use. The closeness of the shave for this razor is fine, it's as good or better than my current shavers, which are a Panasonic and a Braun (one for home and one for travel). Unfortunately, it's not as close as a blade shave. I've yet to find an electric shaver that shaves as close as a blade and after testing this shaver, I'm still looking. I will say that it is very comfortable to shave with however. It's quiet and smooth, no pulling of the whiskers. We'll see what happens when the blades get dull but until then it's completely painless to use. This applies to both the wet shaving and the dry shaving. I found no appreciable difference in the closeness of the shave between wet and dry. The ease of use is above average. The handle is comfortable and fits well in your hand. The lcd display is easy to read and has some good info and some useless info. It will tell you how much of a charge you have left and when it's time to recharge (useful). It holds a charge for quite awhile. I've been using it for about 3 weeks now and it's still operating on the charge it came with. It will also tell you how much time used on the current shave (useless). The blade head of this shaver is huge. It's about the size of a tangerine which makes it pretty useful for the big areas of your face but pretty unwieldy for the areas like under your nose and around your sideburns. There is a pop-up trimmer for sideburns that works well, although I have a tough time getting it to line up straight. Overall it's a pretty good shaver but loses points for the size of the blade head and for the very high price. I can't imagine why anyone would want to pay that much for an electric razor. I wouldn't recommend this unless it was about $200 cheaper.ld want to pay that much for an electric razor. I wouldn't recommend this unless it was about $200 cheaper.
  241. Electric shavers ---------------- If you buying an electric shaver for the first time, skip this section and read the next Electric shavers basically come in 2 types - Rotary (philips norelco) & foil (braun & panasonic) Rotaries are good for cutting longer hairs let us say you skip to shave over a holiday then start shaving on Monday morning. Foil shavers are faster and easier to adapt to, since they are very much like your gilette razors, but there are a few downsides - foils are difficult to clean since the hair gets trapped in the inner chamber and foil shavers give you more burn compared to rotary blades. This is a foil shaver About Panasonic ES-LA63-S ------------------------- First of all, I am apalled by lack of product description by Amazon/Panasonic for this product on this product page (atleast as of Nov'2009). There is a very informative comparision chart between all the Panasonic foil shavers on this page: I would suggest that a buyer needs to browse though this product comparison list before jumping into a buy decision: http://www.amazon.com/Panasonic-ES8109S-Vortex-Technology-HydraClean/dp/B000VKZMHK/ref=sr_1_6?ie=UTF8&s=hpc&qid=1257820434&sr=1-6 Shave Quality : Rotary shavers have never been able to offer me the kind of close shave that I have been able to get through this particular foil shaver. I have tried cheaper foil shavers before, but almost always it has left me with razor burns. East of use : The flexible heads make it very easy to shave around the neck. If you are graduating from a Gilette to this one - you will find that this is much easier to adapt to than a rotary shaver. Someone even after 3 years of being with rotary shavers, I still get a bit fearful as I take my rotary shaver around the neck, but not with this Panasonic foil shavers Hygiene & Safety : Why is hygene all the more important in an electric shaver ? You see the blades are so much close to your skin and obviously they do scrape offlive matter into an enclosed chamber along with the hair. Now, if you these blades were not to be hypoallergic, they would encourage growth of these live matter along with bacteria. But the Panasonic ES-LA63-S comes with hypoallergic blades which ward off growth of such bacteria and keep it clean, of course you have to do your due diligence of rinsing the blades in hot water and cleaning it. Panasonic should have bundled the hydraclean system along with this shaver instead of creating a new model ES-LA93-K priced at $100 more than this. Other features : Not too worried about the other features such as battery life - it is not a mobile phone to be held in hand for hours together - almost ALL the shavers in the market today offer a charge to last for a couple of days, which is good enough. -- Another important thing is to dual voltage operability if you travel to Asia/Europe and this shaver can work with dual voltages -- 14000 rpm : the faster the foil vibrates, the more efficient it is in giving a clean shave on the very first run and this is currently the fastest in the market Comparison to Braun : Sorry, I do not have a clue as to how Braun shavers are - they make foil shavers too. Remington and Philips make rotary shavers. But I did do some research on foil replacements and found that Panasonic foils are less expensive compared to Braun foils - obviously Panasonic shavers will cost a lot less to maintain over the years Value for Money : An investment in a good electric shaver really pays over time - no price is small to wake up each day in the morning, get a clean shave in a minute or two and walk out confidently. Not with a $20 shaver or even the most expensive rotary shaver will you get this kind of a feeling - I can tell you from my own personal experience. I did not realize this until I started using the a quality foil shaver like this.
  242. The Panasonic ES-LA63-S gives an incredible shave, no doubt about it. It's not often I give 5-star reviews, but this razor earns it despite the price.<br /><br />After opening the package, charging for a measly 1 hour, it was ready to go, and I took it into the shower with me that night. I shave in the shower so this is nothing new, and I had been doing so with a \\"lesser\\" Panasonic wet/dry shaver, the ES8249K Arc IV Nano Vortex, which includes the cleaning system. Worrisome when receiving this considerably more expensive shaver was that it did NOT include the cleaning base into which the razor is inserted. But, for that night, I didn't think about it. I lathered up with shaving cream, switched on, and received, simply, the best shave I have ever gotten. That's no hyperbole - this razor managed to out-shave the razor I previously thought gave the best-ever shave, relegating my Arc IV to counter-queen status for a while.<br /><br />I followed instructions and shaved for several weeks with the new razor alone, then tried the Arc IV again just to make sure. What I noticed was surprising. It's not *after* the shave that the difference is so shocking. It's the shave itself that is surprising. The ES-LA63-S shaves smoother and easier than the Arc IV, but the resulting shave is similarly close. My wife can't tell the difference, in fact. But the during-shave experience is sharply different, and for those who have \\"difficult beards\\" or sensitive skin, I think this is the razor for you. I have noticed, as one who suffers from, since switching over, less irritated skin and less missed hairs. It manages to shave extremely close without burning at all.<br /><br />On the flip side, there's the price. This razor is considerably more expensive than even my Arc IV with cleaning system, which isn't cheap. But I wouldn't complain about that - it's a fantastic razor that also includes a great self-cleaning system. However, with that cleaning system comes the repetive cost of cleaning filters. If they do the job, and they do, I won't complain. But the razors themselves are equipped with Turbo mode created just to clean it of anything that dirties it, so this cleaning system does seem a little unnecessary. Just pour some liquid soap on the head, hold the power button for a couple of seconds, and it will jump into Turbo mode for about 20 seconds. Remove the foil/head cover, add more soap, put it in Turbo again, and you're done. With the Arc IV's cleaning system, it would go through a 2-hour cleaning cycle and I'm not really sure what is going on that takes so long. Is Turbo mode harder on the razor than the cleaner would be? Only Panasonic knows, and time will likely tell us who lack the cleaning unit the answer.<br /><br />One minor quible: I simply do not understand why the digital readout is not visible while the razor is being used. The Arc IV's display remains lit while it's on, displaying both the time the razor has been in use as well as the battery power remaining. The ES-LA63-S' display goes blank, only to re-light once it has been turned off. I simply don't understand the point of that. If it's to preserve battery life, it seems a minimal trade-off. I'd prefer to have the information available while I'm using it.<br /><br />Speaking of battery life, in just over 3 weeks of pretty much every other day use for approximately 4 minutes each time, it has been recharged just once, and it required one Turbo-mode cleaning in that time as well. If you're looking for a low-maintenance wet-dry shaver and don't mind the high cost of admission, I don't think you can go wrong with this razor.s. If they do the job, and they do, I won't complain. But the razors themselves are equipped with Turbo mode created just to clean it of anything that dirties it, so this cleaning system does seem a little unnecessary. Just pour some liquid soap on the head, hold the power button for a couple of seconds, and it will jump into Turbo mode for about 20 seconds. Remove the foil/head cover, add more soap, put it in Turbo again, and you're done. With the Arc IV's cleaning system, it would go through a 2-hour cleaning cycle and I'm not really sure what is going on that takes so long. Is Turbo mode harder on the razor than the cleaner would be? Only Panasonic knows, and time will likely tell us who lack the cleaning unit the answer. One minor quible: I simply do not understand why the digital readout is not visible while the razor is being used. The Arc IV's display remains lit while it's on, displaying both the time the razor has been in use as well as the battery power remaining. The ES-LA63-S' display goes blank, only to re-light once it has been turned off. I simply don't understand the point of that. If it's to preserve battery life, it seems a minimal trade-off. I'd prefer to have the information available while I'm using it. Speaking of battery life, in just over 3 weeks of pretty much every other day use for approximately 4 minutes each time, it has been recharged just once, and it required one Turbo-mode cleaning in that time as well. If you're looking for a low-maintenance wet-dry shaver and don't mind the high cost of admission, I don't think you can go wrong with this razor.

  244. I have been using Panasonic shavers for more than ten years. I switched to Norelco and Braun and always came back to Panasonic. It gives me the most comfortable and closest shave. I have seen the gradual evolution of Panasonic shavers. This one is the best so far. The advantages over the current Panasonic shavers are 1. Pivoting shaving heads: The one I have can only rotate in one direction. This one can rotate in two directions. It does give you a closer touch, and hence a better shave. 2. Four shaving blades: It is one more blade than what I have. Surprisingly, it works better and requires less glides in the same area. 3. LCD display: This is more of a convenience feature. It tells you how much time is used in this shave and how much power is left. It is not a revolution of Panasonic shavers, but it is a big improvement over the already great products. I like to use it wet because it is less irritating and gives a closer shave. I usually wet my face before I brushes I teeth. So the beards are soft when I shave. I need to apply soap or shaving foam for a smooth shave. My experience is that soap gives you the closest shave, but shaving foam is more comfortable and refreshing. You can try both to see which one you like. Panasonic shavers are \\"directional\\" shavers. You need to glide the shaver against the growth of the hair to be most effective. You can try to feel the directions of the growth of the hair before and after the shave. After several trials, you will be good at it. I would not spend three hundred dollars on a shaver. But if I had known it is this good, I would not mind spending three hundred dollars on it. After all, you use it everyday. If it gives you a more refreshing start each morning, I would say it is well worth it. Some reviewers say it is lacking a cleaning system for an expensive shaver like this. Well, you have to spend anther one hundred dollars for ES-LA93-K. It has a cleaning sytem.

When asked about a possible design flaw for the unit (waiting now for the fourth replacement) under warranty, Panasonic now states that they have had some many returns they cannot keep up with the replacements. I have been waiting close to two months for the replacement. I asked if they could replace with a different unit model that does not have this problem and am awaiting this replacement. I recommend the razor (it is very good) but spare yourself of the cleaning station issue.

  254. Very happy with this purchase.. It arrived quickly from o/s and is a great razor.. Very close shave. My skin is not irritated as with rotor razors..
  255. It's Okay. Have had others before, the price was very good, but could shave faster with the old razor. I will continue to use it, but when in a hurry, use the old razor.
  256. I purchased this for my husband - upon his request. According to him, this works well dry or wet. Since the skin on our faces is sensitive, he finds using a bit of soap or lather when shaving doesn't irritate his skin too much. The Panasonic shaver works well and he feels gives him a good shave.
  257. I use Panasonic ES8243A, but my brother bought this model and I tried it. Panasonic ES8243A is very good shaver, but LA63 is better. I recommended this shaver.
  258. easy to use. bought it on sale. husband disability so this electric razor much easier than razor blad. and he says a close enough shave. not as close as razor though. but light to handle. quite user friendly!!
  259. I purchased this mainly for shaving my head.....the decision was between this and a rotary version but had read that the latter created more irritation. I wanted an electric shaver as I was experiencing razor bumps if I wanted to shaved my head every day using a gillette blade. I must say that using it for a month, I have found that I could shave my head every day without having any bumps.<br /><br />Compared to the blade, I must admit that the LA63 is almost as close as the gillette but takes longer to get my head clean shaven. A full charge lets me shave a full week before having to recharge. My recommendation is not to perform any shaving without some form of lubrication.... a pre-electric is great way to get a close shave without irritation. Wet shaving works great but I can do that with a blade.
  260. clean shave, easy to clean, easy to charge. A little to expensive but if last long time it would be worth it

  264. It's okay for an electric razor. I've used it for a few weeks. It gives a decent shave, but to be honest I can get a closer and better shave with a little battery operated (uses two triple A batteries)razor called Microforce which I bought at Wal-Mart for $10.00. It even came with an extra foil. If I had it to do over, I wouldn't have spent the money on the Panasonic ES-LA63-S. I would simply buy a replacement Microforce when it became necessary.   265. That's a Shaver I just needed!
  266. Prior to purchasing the Panasonic ES-LA63-S, I used Gillette Fusion ProGlide in combination with &#34;Nivea For Men&#34; shaving foam. The Gillette blade delivered a perfect closeness and made my skin feel very soft. However, because my skin is quite sensitive, I sometimes got red spots and cuts on my face when conditions were not optimal. I could mitigate this problem by shaving under warm shower and applying the foam for a longer period beforehand, but this whole procedure took a lot of time.<br /><br />A decade ago I had owned an electric shaver from Panasonic, but the results didn't come even close to a neatly executed blade shave. At some point I stopped using the electric shaver and relied on the blade only. Thirteen years later, as technology has made a substantial advancement, I reconsidered buying an electric shaver again and I expected it to perform better than my old one.<br /><br />So I compared the technical details and reviews of some high-profile models, and the new Panasonic ES-LA63-S not only had very good ratings, but was sold at a price much lower ($150) than originally. So I thought to give it a chance.<br /><br />After using it for two months, I can conclude that I made a right decision by buying the new Panasonic shaver. Here are some of my experiences that I want to share with any potential buyers:<br /><br />During the first weeks, shaving dry delivered better results than my old Panasonic shaver, but the difference between Gillette Fusion ProGlide was still significant. The new Panasonic model can be used in a dry and wet mode. I think this is a big plus, because I have found that using the shaver under the shower produces a noticeably closer shave than using it dry, especially when I apply the foam in small quantity. Another reviewer has noticed this as well. After two months of using this shaver on a regular basis, I can attest that the dry method works better than it did initially: The shave is closer and it takes less time to complete it. The manual states that the skin needs about a month to adapt to a new shaver. I was skeptical about this statement when I read it first, but now it seems that there is some truth behind it.<br /><br />The question of interest for anyone is: How does the electric shaver fare against Gillette Fusion ProGlide for me personally?<br />I would say that when used wet with the shaving foam, the Panasonic comes as close as 95% to the blade. I consider this as a very good result. The 5% &#34;deficit&#34; is only going to be noticed after one day, when hair growth can be already noticed after using the electric shaver, whereas petting the skin after using Gillette ProGlide still feels quite soft. However, that advantage comes at the cost of higher risk of irritations and cuts, which so far I have never had with the Panasonic shaver. I gladly accept the lack of irritations over the nuance in difference between closeness. Using the shaver dry produces a result of 85% these days when expressed in above numbers, which is still very good to me considering the time savings. Since I have owned the Panasonic shaver, I have never used the blade for my facial hair any more - only for hard-to-reach body and neck hair. Again, Gillette Fusion ProGlide is still the champion in the closeness category, where the Panasonic shaver is just almost as good when used in wet mode. However, given the lack of problems with skin irritations and the time savings, I would say that the Panasonic shaver has proved to be a better option for me overall.<br /><br />The other advantage of the electric shaver is that it retains its closeness over a longer time period than regular blades (which need to be exchanged for new ones more frequently). Even though the electric shaver requires a higher initial investment than a blade shaver, I think that the expenses break even at a point when the electric shaver still performs well. Cleaning the electric shaver is not a problem at all: Just put some liquid soap on the blades, activate the motors and rinse it with water. This will keep the shaver clean and will make it a pleasure to smell. The other model that comes with a cleaning station is not really needed in this regard.<br /><br />Other reviewers have already criticized the battery life on this razor. I can indeed concur with that because I have found that a full battery charge provides energy for just about five 6-minute sessions (this is how long it takes for me to get a neat shave). This is not a lot, but on the positive side, the time to fully charge up the battery is short, too (just about an hour).<br /><br />Here is my comprehensive list of pros and cons:<br /><br />+ Can be used in both dry and wet mode.<br />++ Closeness almost as good as with Gillette Fusion ProGlide when used wet.<br />++ No skin irritations and cuts<br />+ Easy to use and easy to clean<br /><br />- Short battery life (but it charges fast).<br />- When fully charged, the display blinks until the plug is removed, which can be annoying (although not a big deal).<br />- The motor is a little noisy, but not nerve-wrecking.<br /><br />That's it for now. I think this shaver has deserved five stars given the highly appreciated positives and the fair purchase price. Should anything be added to my experience, I will update this review.
  267. I have changed my rating to one star and would give it less if I could. In six months I have had to replace the shaving head twice. I shave daily with shaving cream and have not abused the shaver in any way yet the head foil develops a hole (and it grows) that makes it unusable. I have replaced the heads with genuine Panasonic heads from Amazon, yet the company agent says I must buy them from Panasonic directly at a much higher cost plus shipping - a ridiculous request. The shaver does a good job, but I certainly wouldn't recommend it due to the lousy foil head.
  268. I first purchased the Norelco Rotary for around $150.00 and was completely disappointed with its performance. This Panasonic is excellent quality and does a great job. The best electric razor I have ever purchased.
  269. This razor is the best electric razor that I have owned. It provides a comfortable, close shave (although the neck area is still a bit problematic) and is extremely easy to use. Cleaning can be accomplished quickly and with minimal effort. I much prefer the simple soap and water rinsing that this razor periodically requires as opposed to the docking station with its messy and expensive cleaning solution. The flexible head follows the contours of my face well, and its large size reduces shaving time. The symbols on the electronic display are easy to identify and understand and the controls are comfortably placed. The price of the razor is rather expensive, but I feel that it is well worth it.

After 7 years the battery finally wore out, so I needed a replacement. Read a lot of reviews of this and other models. The head appeared large and looked awkward, and a couple of reviews said it was difficult to get at \\"small areas\\".. However, I have not found that to be a problem, and I am shaving more closely, smoothly and quickly than ever before. This is my 3rd Panasonic shaver.

  273. After about 10 years of using Panasonic ES725, I bought this one. It looks cool, works pretty well, and I believe it gives you very short shave. But I found from the first day that it would never be better than my old Panasonic ES725. I don't know why both Braun and even Panasonic have not been able to beat a very old model. The old ES725 gave me super close shave. Gillette Mach 3 was worse. Of course ES725 was not perfect. It missed long hairs (I used the trimmer to make them shorter and then shaved again). With ES725, I spent less than a minute for a very close shave without much irritation for everyday shaving. For closest shave (very smooth skin, I don't feel any texture), I spent more time though it gave me slight irritation. With this new Panasonic, I get almost always some irritation for just decently close shave. To get the closest shave, I spend many minutes and significant irritation. So, do I recommend other product like Braun? No. Braun never gives me close shave (surely, it depends on personal preference). One more thing. I also found that shaving quality depends on some luck. The perfect match between a foil and blades is required for super close shave. If you change your foil, the quality would drop or be improved. But that's something that you cannot control. It is just luck. So I want to believe that the current combination of my Panasonic is not perfect and I hope it will somehow settle down over time. ============================ Update: 12/26/10 After the review, I happened to try 'wet' mode. I used Gillette shave gel and found the shaving was very very comfortable and refreshing. I had never enjoyed 'wet' shaving with my old Panasonic, because it was not very good for it, though it was possible. Anyway, I'm very pleased with 'wet' mode and I've been 'wet' shaving ever since, though it still is not as close as my old one. Anyway, I increased my rate from 3 to 4 stars.
  274. This shaver cuts smoothly and is powerful. Time spent shaving was also reduced. I had no trouble shaving between my nose and upper lip. The head really snugs close to my face. One word of caution is to not spend too much time cutting in one place. You might get a slight burn on your face.
  275. Pros - very close shave (have only used it dry so far), rivals a blade. It takes a few passes but the end result is smooth. It has a little trouble with longer hairs that lay flat, but the built in trimmer is sufficient to take care of them, and then the shaver can deal with them. The trimmer is a little light for full blown hair trimming but will get the job done if you don't bite off too much at once. Charges quickly, maintains the charge for a long time and is good for weeks of daily shaving before a recharge is needed. Display gives percent charge remaining, and after shaving it tells you how long you spent shaving. Cleaning it under a faucet is quick and easy. I would expect a buildup of debris after a while, but haven't had it long enough for that to develop.<br /><br />Cons - No charging cradle, and the shaver won't operate while it is plugged in. For the price I would expect a charging cradle. And since it won't run while it is plugged in, when the batteries go bad, it will be useless. The readout is a bright blue backlit LED that flashes while it is charging. I mean it is BRIGHT. I fit didn't flash it could easily double as a nightlight.<br /><br />Overall, I am pleased with my purchase and would probably buy one again.
  276. My boyfriend had been using disposable razors for 25+ years. His most recent favorite was the [[ASIN:B000052YHS Gillette Mach3]]. I had always wanted to buy him an electric shaver as a gift, but I knew how he felt. So when I asked him to give the [[ASIN:B002N5MHLU Panasonic ES-LA63-S Arc IV Multi Flex Nanotech Rechargeable Shaver]] a test, I was met with resistance. He said that over the years he had tried shavers like this and could never get a close shave, so he was happy with his disposable. Of course he was willing to try for me, so I asked him to give it a full weeks use, both wet and dry.<br /><br />The first day he used it dry, as he was running late to work and needed to clean up as much as possible. He wasn't immediately impressed with the closeness of the shave, but he did like that there was no irritation and it was easy to clean. I felt his face, knowing how it usually feels after a shave and it was nice, but I had to agree that the disposable did get closer.<br /><br />The next morning he decided to try it wet, in the shower. We have one of the no-fog mirrors, so it was easy enough for him to do and again clean up was a breeze. This time he was surprised; using the shaver wet provided him an incredibly close shave. As good as a disposable, but quicker and less mess. Was this going to be \\"THE\\" razor that would eliminate the favored disposable?<br /><br />He continued to use it, long after I had asked of him and still uses it to this day. Occasionally he does revert back to his disposable for vacation, but this shaver converted my non-believer. No longer can he say that it's impossible to get a close shave from an electric shaver. I highly recommend this for any man to buy for themselves or for someone wanting to give one as a gift.

  291. I had used Norelco electric shavers for many years, and they typically would last 2-4 years before failing in some way. The Panasonic ES-LA63-S had received several good reviews, and while it was a bit more expensive than what I had purchased previously I thought I would give it a try - hoping for something that would last a bit longer. The shaver seemed well-built and substantial, and has a nice display giving charge status and time spent shaving. It seemed to me to be less comfortable than the Norelco, but not bad. The biggest disappointment came when after about 6 months of use, the display on the screen started to malfunction and show incorrect values. Then the battery started to weaken and only held a charge for a few shaves before requiring recharging. This week, after just over 10 months of daily use, the unit died completely. It is still in warranty, so I expect to receive a replacement for the out-of-pocket costs of paying to send the shaver to the service center. I ordered a new Norelco to use while the Panasonic is being serviced. I doubt I'll buy another Panasonic shaver.

It's a much closer shave than my Norelco could ever give.<br /><br />Then, this one was on sale with rebate for a great price. I'll never get another Norelco and will probably stick with what works, Panasonic. It pretty much gets all my face hair, but isn't as awesome at getting everything on my neck, guess that is what the manual razor is for.<br /><br />Updated! - The LCD on my shaver went bad. I looked and there is a two year warranty and I've only had it around 1.5 years. I sent it in for $10 shipped vis USPS, about 10 days later I received my replacement. It was a brand new Panasonic ES-LA93-K, so they upgraded me! Well, it appears the upgrade is only the base station, but better than nothing and now I have a brand new shaver! I can use the base to give it an extra clean every month. I like the black much better too.
  307. I've been using this about 3 times a week for the past few months. Was hoping that the growth of my hair would have adapted to them by now. However, it seems that I have to spend about 2-3 minutes (shows on the counter) and a go over a few times before I catch all the hairs. The most problematic region is just under the chin and near the neck. Overall, the shaves are very nice and close. Feels just as smooth as using a razor (I use the Gillette Power Fusion Razor) but was hoping to cut down time shaving with the electronic one which hasn't happened.

  324. I bought this mistakingly at a retail shop, thinking that its better than the Braun series 7 Pulsonic and discovered that its no better than my Braun series 7 older model fitted with the newer Brain series 70s optifoil for the past one year. The braun foils is better designed, longer lasting and stays sharper longer for braun series 7 older model users, u just need to upgrade yr foil to the newer optifoil. WHile its true this panasonic shaves better than the older Braun series 7 with pulsonic smartfoil, it isnt any better than the new Braun series 7 optifoil. And also consider this fact the Braun optifoil model was released in 2010, compared to this panasonic which is 1 year before.I amnot sure if panasonic has over the year made improvements on their foil quality but Braun sure did. Initial impressions after my first shave with the new Opti-foil on the older Pulsonic 790cc. There is no question in my mind but that the newer designed Braun foil is a dramatic improvement over the older design. The shave, which lasted between 5 and 6 minutes was one of the closest dry shaves from an electric that I have ever received and even better than the older smartfoil braun. The neck area shaves better than the panasonic.and besides the panasonic tends to lose its sharpness after a while. I was particularly impressed that it easily cut all of the more difficult to shave areas (jawline and neck). There was no irritation after the shave was completed and four hours later my face is still completely smooth. I would rank this shave as equal to the wet shave with the Panasonic Esla 63S \\"without\\" the mess and cleanup. Given the fact that Braun did not announce any speed change in their newer shavers, I can only assume that the \\"intensive\\" setting is identical to the \\"only\\" setting on the older shavers. And since Braun recommends that the newer shavers be used on the intensive setting for the best shave, I see no advantage to purchasing a newer Pulsonic or Panasonic esla63S And besides that, the Braun foil is smaller in size and is easier to cut because of its small head compared to panasonic. Put aside all the technical jargon, utimately its the foil which matters most

With this one, I have to stretch my skin to get the longer hairs while the earlier model had some sort of hair catcher that just lifted them up. The only other issue is that the trimmer is difficult to open. Other than these two issues, the razor holds a charge for up to two weeks, is easy to use, and does not irritate my skin. I would purchase it again.

  330. I ordered this razor yesterday, and it arrived this morning. Super fast two day service. I have tried many razors from cheap Gillette double edge blades, expensive Merkur double edge, Shick, Norelco, Braun electrics. And being the adventurous type, I thought I'd add this razor to my many shaving experiments. It arrived about 10am with a 10% charge. I plugged it in and left the house. I returned just before 12 noon, and the razor was completely charged. I hadn't shaved yet, so I took it to the bathroom, loaded my face with coconut oil and shaved with my new razor. It makes an odd noise, but it's not loud nor disturbing. It's a little more weight than I'm used to when I shave so that was noticeable. The shave took 4 minutes and 10 seconds according to the razor, and it was as good a shave as I've had with blades. No irritation to speak of. The head is a lot more bulky than my little manual razor, so that will take some getting used to. I'm also not used to having to stretch the skin tight ahead of the razor. But these are minor things. After the shave, I put a little hand soap into the grill on the razor, ran it to make a foam, then rinsed it in warm water. Then I opened it up and it was clean inside. So. The razor is heavy, but not too bad. The head is large, but it moves all over, so it works well. The noise is not bad either, and the shave was very good for my first time. I expect I will get better with experience. All in all, this razor was well worth the price. I compared it with the other brands before deciding on Panasonic, and then I compared this model with the others. There are others that perhaps will do as well, but for the price, this one came out on top for me.

  333. I've been using Panasonic shavers for nearly 20 years and have used numerous variations on their wet-dry shavers. This is the second one of this model I've had (ES-63). I don't believe it is possible to get a closer shave than when this is used wet. I get such a close shave with this shaver in the morning that I don't have 5 o'clock shadow. I've tried several other brands of shavers including Remington, Norelco, and Braun shavers (several of each) but I keep coming back to the Panasonic. I've also tried several models of Panasonic shavers from inexpensive ones in the $50 range up through their top of the line $400 ones. The ES-63 seems to give me a great shave in about 3 minutes and works as well as the most expensive ones. The blades and screen have lasted about 8 months before needing replacement. The one I got two years ago had the computer screen go out after about 6 months, but it just tells you how long your shave was and how much charge is left, and it has never been an issue for me not being able to see it, although I prefer having it work. (I probably should have returned it under warranty, but I didn't). Oh, I also have tried a few multi-blade manual razors but found the Panasonic electric was as good or better than any and a lot easier to use. You don't need special shaving soap. I wet my face using a regular bar of soap. When done shaving I just rinse the shaver under the tap for a few seconds. I don't like having to shave, but the Panasonic makes it a quick and easy process.
