  338. It is not very often that I buy something that is just incredible. This shaver is totally incredible. I have used nothing but Norelcos my entire shaving life (25+ years). Some were better than others. And then I bought an Arcitec. Biggest piece of crap I've ever owned in my life. I was so disgusted with Norelco for ripping me off with that $200 piece of junk that I bought this razor. Norelco has never made anything even close to this Panasonic. Everything about this thing is so well designed and thought out that I am still amazed every morning while I'm shaving. Even after using it for nearly two months now. It does have a pretty big head, although not as big as I expected after reading the reviews. You can allow the head to move and float with the curves of your face and neck or you can lock it and angle it yourself. This is by FAR the best and closest cutting razor I've ever used. After nearly two months, it has yet to ever miss a single hair anywhere on my face or neck. It does take a couple passes and you need to hold your skin tight, but that is the same with all electrics. It takes me between 2-3 minutes to completely shave. As a test, I went an entire weekend without shaving just to see how this thing would handle a good bunch of growth. No tugging or pulling like I've always gotten with rotary style Norelcos. Just completely smooth skin on both my face and neck. And it only added an extra minute to the shaving time. By the way the razor tells you how long you spent shaving each time in minutes and seconds, I don't own a stop watch. I tried a wet shave with it once. It was nice and probably more comfortable than dry, but it reminded me of why I've always used electrics. Very messy in my opinion. The razor did actually irritate my skin for the first week or so. Not real bad but rubbing my hand across my face and neck would give me a prickly kind of feel under my skin. It did stop and now there is no irritation at all. I am left with only amazingly smooth and fast shaves. Cleaning this thing is totally effortless. You pop the top off, put a few drops of hand soap on the blades and turn it on turbo mode. After a few seconds of it foaming up, you simply rinse it under running water and it is spotless. It is so easy that I do it every time I use the razor. After nearly two months it is just as clean as the day it was new. I'm so glad I did not spring for the extra $100 to get the cleaning station. The battery charge lasts a long time. I get about three weeks of everyday shaves out of a single charge. The LED display is great because it tells you how much more battery power you have left. It is also the only battery razor I've ever had that the motor does not slow down as the battery goes down. It runs the same speed all the way down to when it tells you it is time to recharge. About the only thing that could make this a better razor would be if you could run it with the power cord if the battery ever went dead. It is battery power only. So if you are looking for the most amazing electric razor ever invented, I think I can safely say, you have just found it. How good is it? I give it TEN stars!!!
  339. Background: Been shaving with blades for many years, but the cost of my preferred blades has increased over time to the point I started to look around for alternatives. Last year I spent roughly 140 on blades. Looking at the cost of an electric it seems that I would save some money (although not a lot) over a two year period including one replacement head. Time will tell. So, on to my thoughts about the LA63-S Arc IV: The Good: Shaves much faster than my traditional blades. Fairly close shave when compared to my memory of using a rotary style shaver 15 years ago. Battery lasts about 10 days for me, better than I expected. Like the shave time duration feature - but likely because I love measuring things. Can shave wet or dry - I seem to get a slightly closer shave when dry - but the wet shave is more comfortable to my skin. The Weak: Not as close as a blade. The LA63 shave lasts about 14 hours, then stubble becomes noticeable. I suspect this is typical of the electric shaver class - perhaps a bit better. Head does not glide easily over my face - I have to concentrate to not press too hard or it will burn. The Ugly: Nothing really - at least not in the first month of use. Additional thoughts: Usage technique may matter a lot - and as I am new to foil shavers I might not be doing it \\"right.\\" But so far the most effective technique (for me) is to use gentle small circling motions on the difficult area's of the face: under the nose, across the chin and jaw bones and around the adams apple -- rather than long sweeps across the face. And less pressure is better - press too hard and you not only fail to get as close as you want, you might \\"burn\\" your skin.
  340. Panasonic shavers are great and good value for money. Doesn't shave a couple of hard spots on the neck but they are hard with a razor as well. I would recommend this product for ease of use, very quick to clean, good battery and a good shave.
  341. I found the three top of the line electric shavers - Braun Series 7, Panasonic es-la63, and Phillips Norelco 3D - to be so similar as to recommend any of them as excellent shavers, but each has its strengths and weaknesses. Too many reviewers are only comparing the closeness of the shave, but that's only one factor of several that may be most important. Here's my breakdown:<br /><br />Closeness - Let's start with the most popular category. If all you care about is how close you can shave, then I rate the wet-shaved Panasonic and Norelco even, BUT ONLY when coupled with a shaving oil/gel combo such as [[ASIN:B005ACNPLO Remington Alphagel Sensitive Shave Gel 5 oz. (Pack of 2)]] (there's a cooling menthol version as well). Another way to accomplish the same thing is by using [[ASIN:B0023XF60Q SHAVE SECRET SHAVING OIL- THE BEST SHAVE EVER! 18.75ML]] topped with [[ASIN:B0032ANCUU Edge Shave Gel, Senstive Skin, 7-Ounces Cans (Pack of 6)]]. These provide the closest shave possible, but, of course, it's messy, takes a lot of extra time, and can be a general pain. There's no advantage in closeness to using non-oil shaving cream by itself. Going dry-shave, I may give the tiniest of edges to Panasonic over Braun and Norelco, but all three are awfully close - to each other and in quality of shave.<br /><br />Speed - If you're in a hurry and want to get in and get out with a dry-shave as quickly as possible, the Norelco wins. The Panasonic is next followed by the Braun.<br /><br />Comfort - I don't have sensitive skin, but the Braun wins out (unless going wet-shave with the oil/gel as described above). The Braun has three speeds so you can go slower for sensitive areas and intensive on less-sensitive places. I just leave it set on intensive all the time and have no problem. The Panasonic is next followed by the Norelco third. The wet-shaving Panasonic and Norelco are the most comfortable of all if you want to put up with the oil/gel prep and clean-up time.<br /><br />Cleaning - Any auto cleaning system is easier than manual cleaning. Just pop in the shaver and press a button. That said, the Braun is the only system with alcohol in its cleaner to sanitize as well as a detergent to clean and oil to lubricate. Norelco's apparently has detergent and lubrication. From what I've been able to tell, the Panasonic solution is only a detergent. Manually, the Norelco is easiest to clean and you can duplicate the auto clean by pouring some of its [[ASIN:B002DHVAZW Philips Norelco HQ200 Jet Clean Solution]] in a dish or mug and whirring the shaver in it for 30 seconds after shaving. The Panasonic and Braun can be rinsed off under a faucet. The Panasonic's special cleaning speed makes it slightly easier to manually clean than the Braun.<br /><br />Maneuverability - If you have a moustache, goatee, beard, long sideburns, or whatever this is a very important category. The Braun is king here with the Norelco second and the larger-head Panasonic last.<br /><br />Noise - You can hardly hear the Norelco at all. The Braun is a little buzzy and the Panasonic loudest although not irritatingly so. Still, a sleeping spouse nearby will appreciate you using the Norelco most.<br /><br />Travel - The Norelco is last in this category because you'll need to bring the charging stand with you. The Norelco soft case does not hold the stand so that's a bit of a drawback. The Braun's harder case gives it top honors over the Panasonic's soft one, but the Panasonic has an on-off lock that the Braun lacks. Perhaps the Braun doesn't need it because the case is harder, and also because the Braun is the only shaver that can run while plugged in with a depleted battery. The other two require a 5-minute charge to give you a few minutes shave. A fully-charged shaver gives you about 50 minutes in each.asier than manual cleaning. Just pop in the shaver and press a button. That said, the Braun is the only system with alcohol in its cleaner to sanitize as well as a detergent to clean and oil to lubricate. Norelco's apparently has detergent and lubrication. From what I've been able to tell, the Panasonic solution is only a detergent. Manually, the Norelco is easiest to clean and you can duplicate the auto clean by pouring some of its [[ASIN:B002DHVAZW Philips Norelco HQ200 Jet Clean Solution]] in a dish or mug and whirring the shaver in it for 30 seconds after shaving. The Panasonic and Braun can be rinsed off under a faucet. The Panasonic's special cleaning speed makes it slightly easier to manually clean than the Braun. Maneuverability - If you have a moustache, goatee, beard, long sideburns, or whatever this is a very important category. The Braun is king here with the Norelco second and the larger-head Panasonic last. Noise - You can hardly hear the Norelco at all. The Braun is a little buzzy and the Panasonic loudest although not irritatingly so. Still, a sleeping spouse nearby will appreciate you using the Norelco most. Travel - The Norelco is last in this category because you'll need to bring the charging stand with you. The Norelco soft case does not hold the stand so that's a bit of a drawback. The Braun's harder case gives it top honors over the Panasonic's soft one, but the Panasonic has an on-off lock that the Braun lacks. Perhaps the Braun doesn't need it because the case is harder, and also because the Braun is the only shaver that can run while plugged in with a depleted battery. The other two require a 5-minute charge to give you a few minutes shave. A fully-charged shaver gives you about 50 minutes in each.

I used to dislike having to brush the trimmings out my my old razor after each shave - now when the \\"wash\\" indicator comes on I clean the thing under running water with liquid hand soap and it's shiny new.   350. I've been using Norelco shavers for about 23 years. A few years ago, I tried the then latest Panasonic and didn't like it. I recently decided to try again and bought this shaver.   352. My prior razor was a Panasonic model 8249. I'd give it 5 stars. I purchased it a few years ago when Costco stopped carrying the razor blade I had been using, the Gilette 2-blade Sensor Excel. When Costco stopped carrying the 2-blade Gillette, I was faced with the choice of buying much-more-expensive 3-blade+ razors or going to an electric razor. I chose the electric route. I then chose the Panasonic 8249, mainly because it could be used in the shower. I was very pleased with the 8249. It shaved about as well as the Gillette blades, close and smooth. After a few years, I needed to replace the foil and blades of the 8249. I saw that this new model, the LA-63, cost not much more than the replacement foil and blade. Since the price was not much different, instead of replacing the foil and blade on my 8249, I figured I'd \\"upgrade\\" and ordered the LA-63. The LA-63 is a nice shaver but there is more drag than with the previous, 8249, shaver. By drag, I mean that the shaver does not glide smoothly across the face. I suspect that the extra drag is because the shaving area, the part the touches the skin, is larger than that of the 8249. I have no problem with the new shaver and it does seem to shave a bit closer. Nevertheless, I believe the 8249 is better because it has less drag. I shave in the shower and can reduce the extra drag by using more water to lubricate my face. Still, even with extra wetness, the shave is not as smooth as with the 8249. Would I buy the LA-63 again? Yes, without hesitation but if the 8249 were available, I'd buy it. To me, the slightly closer shave of the LA-63 doesn't compensate for its extra drag.
  353. This is the best electric shaver I've used. My experience includes two Brauns (5 and 7 series), one Norelco rotary, and another Panasonic (ES8103S). What I like about it: mainly the super-close, super-comfortable shaves, but also it's easy to clean with soap and water without having the bulky cleaning bases and fluids, it has a comfortable, easy-to-hold grip, it massages the face with its vibrating head (which I believe also helps whiskers stand up), and effective sideburns trimmer. I've used it dry, with water and with Williams Lectric Shave - best shaves are with water or Lectric Shave, but it gives nice shaves dry. It does a nice job on those neck hairs below the jaw. Bottom line: it's the closest to a blade I tried and it's darn close!
  354. I use this shaver for my head.<br /><br />Pros: Works excellent dry or wet shaving. I highly recommend dry shaving for those areas. Does not get around my ears very well. I have to use a razor for that.
  355. I purchased this item because it had 4 heads or blades. What a mistake. Head is huge. Pay attention to that because doing your upper lip is a chore. It is just too big. For a buck fifty it went back. I got the three head model, $84.00, and i couldn't be happier. It is easier to use, the head moves in and out with pressure, and that is a great feature. Also, The head is smaller. I mean, its still a three head but it is comfortable to use. It cuts great, i would say as close as a blade. It maneuvers around your neck with ease and is very well balanced and comfortable in your hand. I think this is the best shaver i ever had. My last shaver was a braun and to be honest, it was ok. but, Avoid this beast.
  356. After so much research bought this for hubby since he has a thick hair. So far he has been satisfied and his skin doesn't get irritation when using it.
  357. Been looking for a razor I can use in the shower to shave my scalp. This one is great! Very little buzz vibration and no razor burn. Shaves as smooth as a razor with just soap instead of shaving cream. The marketing group missed the boat in not touting this for men's scalps. Great value.

  362. Every time I try an electric razor I usually have this initial burst of enthusiasm followed by disenchantment and an eventual return to a Mach 3 power wand. My last bout with a midline Norelco ended the same way. I liked it in the beginning but over time I really missed the closer shave I got with a blade(s). I 've been using this for a litlle while and it's certainly the most expensive razor I've ever held let alone used. It seems nice and substantial in your hand and gives off a pretty good air of quality (though I was expecting a little more pizazz to be honest.) I use it wet in the shower and I usually do a quick wipe of shampoo or bodywash rubbed into the beard to prep. It's a better shaving experience than I've had with any other electric razor to be sure. I have somewhat sensitive skin but experienced no real irritation except occasionally at the bottom of the neckline. Otherwise it gives a nice close shave, comparable to a blade shave. I'll continue to use it for a while at least and see if it can ween me off of my triple blade addiction. I didn't see a big deal about the lack of dock or charging station myself though it apparently was an issue for others. Pricing aside, it's a very good quality device that definitely delivers a pretty good shave.
  363. These are my impressions of the Panasonic shaver after nearly a month of use. I've previously used Norelco rotary shavers and Gillette Fusion manual razors. This is my first experience with a foil shaver.<br /><br />DESIGN: The shaver is almost entirely silver, with an LCD screen on the front. The screen shows what percentage you've used, and has icons which tell you if you need to charge it or clean it. There is a power button on the front, as well as a lock button (so it doesn't turn on accidently). On the back, there is a setting where you can lock the head from moving. The back also has the pop-up trimmer. The shaver has a rubber material on the back so it doesn't easily slip out of your hands when wet. I liked the weight of it- it felt substantial without being heavy. There is a clear plastic piece that covers the top foil part.<br /><br />PERFORMANCE: Performance was excellent and I received the closest shaves I've ever experienced. On my cheeks, sideburns, upper lip, and chin, the closeness of shave was terrific. In just a matter of two or three minutes, my face would be baby skin smooth. However, I will say it didn't do as well of a job with my lower neck area. I would have to spend extra time to get all the hairs on my lower neck to be shaved.<br /><br />I was able to shave in any direction without skin irritation. Even after I was finished, my skin felt no irritation and there was no need for any aftershave lotion or balm.<br /><br />One negative issue was that the shaver was louder than expected. If you shave in the morning while your wife is sleeping, I could see this as a potential unintended alarm clock.<br /><br />CLEANING AND MAINTENANCE: To clean this, you put liquid soap on the outer foil portion and hold down the power button for a few seconds. It goes into a sonic vibration self-cleaning mode. Then you remove the outer foil and do the sonic vibration again for the inner portion. I found it to be easy to clean. I would recommend doing this at least once a week. I didn't clean it for the first two weeks and the foil had a pretty bad odor to it. Per the manual, you also need to replace the outer foil every year and the inner foil every two years.<br /><br />ACCESSORIES: For a shaver in this high price range, I found the accessories to be severely lacking. I would expect a stand for paying this price, as well as a decent hard case that fits both the shaver and the charger. Instead, you get a very small soft case that only fits the shaver, and no stand at all.<br /><br />There is no doubt that this shaver is an excellent performer and will provide a very close shave. The only issue is the high price point. You could probably spend a lot less money and get a shave that is close enough.didn't clean it for the first two weeks and the foil had a pretty bad odor to it. Per the manual, you also need to replace the outer foil every year and the inner foil every two years. ACCESSORIES: For a shaver in this high price range, I found the accessories to be severely lacking. I would expect a stand for paying this price, as well as a decent hard case that fits both the shaver and the charger. Instead, you get a very small soft case that only fits the shaver, and no stand at all. There is no doubt that this shaver is an excellent performer and will provide a very close shave. The only issue is the high price point. You could probably spend a lot less money and get a shave that is close enough.

The rotary \\"lift-and-cut\\" ones produce a perfect rash every time. The other top ones have either been disappointing in results, or make my face feel like a shop project.<br /><br />After reading the other reviews here, I decided to try this one, and so far it's a WOW.<br /><br />THE GOOD<br />Closest shave I've gotten with an electric (without including skin!).<br />THE BAD<br />Once rinsed, there's no easy way to prop the head up so air circulates. Many nooks and crannies, takes a looong time to dry.<br />THE ... WEIRD?<br />Ergonomics. The head pivots well, better than you might think. It feels like you're moving a floor polisher around, but it's not hard to get used to. Sometimes I just hold it by the head, which seems to give me a better feel.<br /><br />and ... THE EXTRA-WEIRD<br />For a couple of years I've been using Nivea for Men Sensitive After Shave Balm. No alcohol, only mild scent, chamomile (whoopie ...) --- after I shave. Nice stuff, just enough moisture, not sticky, greasy, or gooey. I had particularly dry skin one morning, so I put the Nivea on BEFORE shaving with this machine, leaving a thin film. Absolutely incredible shave. WAY better than using this with Edge, or dry. For me.<br /><br />To each his own. Your mileage will probably be different.

  392. I had seen comparisons between the ES-LA63-S and the Panasonic ES8243A (which I own also) and wasn't too sure that I would see a tremendous difference, but decided that since my foil/blades needed to be replaced on the ES8243A, that I would give the newest model a try. People had said that the ES-LA63-S does a better job on the jawline and neck since it has the extra degree of freedom, and boy were they RIGHT! I noticed it right away! The locking feature, brighter LCD screen, and extra 1000RPM are a nice touch, but that doesn't justify the upgrade enough for me like the extra movement does.<br /><br />I have owned the Norelco Advantage, Panasonic ES8109S, Panasonic ES8243A, and now the ES-LA63-S, and never have I gotten such a close, comfortable, non-irritating shave from an electric for my sensitive skin. The rotary Norelco shaver really irritated my neck, and the other two Panasonics were certainly better than the Norelco, but I always had trouble with irritation on my neck since I had to go over the same area multiple times to get all the hairs. The ES-LA63-S puts an end to all of that! It not only hugs the neck and jawline so well, but feels somehow more gentle than its predecessors despite the increase in RPM. Shaving with the other two always took me 6 minutes or more wet or dry, but I can do a more thorough, less irritating job with the ES-LA63-S in around 2 minutes less time! I much prefer wet shaving to dry shaving also, and use Shave Secret oil because it allows me to see what I am doing in case I need to go back over a certain area and provides me with a slick protective barrier as well. I feel like the ES-LA63-S is \\"rolling\\" across my face because of the freedom of movement rather than my having to force the shaver along like it felt with the others.<br /><br />So I would HIGHLY recommend this shaver even compared to its very similar looking predecessor - ES8243A - with the same looking \\"4\\" blades. It was a HUGE upgrade despite what it may seem from the pictures. WELL DONE PANASONIC - THIS IS THE KING OF ALL SHAVERS!ONE PANASONIC - THIS IS THE KING OF ALL SHAVERS!
  393. After just one use, I wasn't convinced that this new Panasonic four-blade shaver really outperforms their excellent three-blade models.<br /><br />This morning, though -- my second shave -- this shaver went to work like the little robot bodyguard Mr. Zurkon in Ratchet & Clank, mowing down my whiskers the way Mr. Z. mows down bad guys. Except that the shaver did its work silently and with far less attitude!<br /><br />Seriously, this is the best electric shaver I've ever had, and I've had many over the years. I can tell you that in my experience, the Panasonics with their high-speed linear motors outperform the Brauns, and the Panasonic curved blades and foil screens do a better job than the circular heads on the Norelcos.<br /><br />With a built-in timer that shows you how long you shaved, this shaver accomplished its task in just 90 seconds -- that must be half the time my old three-blade Panasonic took to cover the same area.<br /><br />Otherwise, the trimmer on this model seems to work with less pulling than the one on my last Panasonic. And no, you don't need a cleaning/charging base to keep your shaver running fine. Just put a drop of liquid soap on the head, activate the ultra-high-speed \\"turbo\\" mode, and rinse the shaver head clean under running water.<br /><br />I get the best shave dry, using the CVS pre-electric-shave lotion (the white, gooey kind -- Mennen has something similar, but a bit more expensive). Just apply some of that, let it dry -- then let Mr. Zurkon do his job!<br /><br />This isn't the cheapest shaver on the market by a long shot, but I will venture to say that it's the best. Highly recommended.<br /><br />ADDENDUM: I understand that Panasonic now has a FIVE-blade model, which could be even better (I haven't tried that one myself, as Mr. Zurkon is still working fine). So -- it is possible that this model no longer offers the VERY best shave, just a VERY good one...

  395. For me, performance trumps features, battery endurance, size, shape, etc. And on performance alone this shaver gets 5-stars! It replaces another brand, now 6-years old that admittedly was not a, \\"pricey\\" example of the craft. I am extremely impressed with the closeness of the shave that this razor gives: clearly closer than my other shaver and close enough to a blade (which I now use less & less) that the difference is negligible, even judged 4-5-Hr after the shave. The manufacturer asks you to give it 30-days so your beard will \\"adjust\\" (align?) to the new shaver, but I was sold on the 1st use!<br /><br />I've not used it wet, though I have rinsed & cleaned it in cold water. It is easily cleaned and required (and got) NO special treatment for drying.   396. Bought this razor after my last one (also a Panasonic - Vortex Hydraclean) died. Bought the last Panasonic in December 2006, so almost four years. This one does not have a cleaning station, but I really consider that a plus. It cleans easily with a couple drops of soap then running under water. I always shave in the shower (wet), so I cannot comment on the dry capability, but this shaver cuts quicker and cleaner than any other shaver I have used. I get a good close shave in 2-1/2 minutes - even on my neck. It is much bigger than any other shaver I have owned, but that has not been a problem. I can get close to my sideburns and nose without a problem. Originally used it with the head locked, but have switched over to keeping the head floating. Seems like I get better contact. Battery life is not as good as my last Panasonic, but is still good. Looks like I will get a little less than two weeks (not shaving a couple days during that period). Overall highly recommended. April 2011 Update: Screen on shaver malfunctioned. Still worked, but screen was unreadable. Contacted Panasonic via their online customer service and sent the shaver to their facility in McAllen, TX. Took about a week, but they sent me a refurbished unit. So far so good there. Not great thit failed so quickly, but they were responsive and got me up and running.

  400. My Braun was 6 years old (2 on the current foil and cutter blades). It seemed like a good time to replace it with this shaver while less than 1/3 the recommended retail price. Unpack it: Damn that's a big head. Plug in the charger. A little awkward: the shaver end is polarized +/- and only goes in one way, but it's not entirely obvious. Takes an hour to charge and won't run off the cord. Oh well, figured it'd warn me (it does have a very cool LCD display) in time to keep from depleting the battery. Worst case I could get a \\"quick charge\\" in five minutes. (The old Braun would run directly off the cord when you ran the battery down.) 1st shave: Panasonic dry, it irritated my skin. Some bleeding. Stubble remained (I'm 52 been shaving with electrics all my life, I'm not new to this stuff!). Figured I'd give a wet shave a whirl next try. The shaver is lighter than I expected given its humongous size. The shaver head is ridiculously large. It really only has 2 foil blades with a long-hair cutter in the middle and an extra permanent foil cutter next to it that some designer thought would be a good selling point \\"Arc IV!!!\\". I could barely see myself behind the shaver head! (ok that last bit is exaggeration, but the thing is unnecessarily huge.) 2nd shave: Panasonic wet (soapy lather). I felt like a grown up lathering up my face and buzzing away. No irritation, but running my tongue over my mustache area I felt stubble. (sorry for the visual). Rationalized maybe I needed to \\"get used\\" to it. 3rd shave. Panasonic Wet. Started questioning what I was doing; after all the point of an electric is to skip the shaving cream ritual, isn't it? Still had stubble. After drying off I got out the old Braun and quickly finished what the panasonic failed to do. 4th shave. Braun, Dry. Taking the same care I took with the new shaver to do a thorough job, the 6 year old Braun did a much better, smoother job, with no stubble remaining, with no fussing around with shaving wet.The old Braun has 3 cutters and its head is shaped like a racing car's grill compared to the Panasonic Buick grill. 5th shave. Braun. Packed the panasonic up for return to Amazon. Sorry about that. Think about it people: The Panasonic is discounted more than 50% to an actual price point less than equivalent quality Brauns and Norelcos. I admit I fell for the gimmick that I thought I was getting a three hundred dollar shaver at a fraction of the cost. I figured it'd be an improvement over a very used Braun. It wasn't. You get what you pay for. Granted, there are a lot of skin and beard types, but having used a couple Norelcos, one Remington, 2 Brauns, I know what to expect from a shaver. The switch to Braun 15 years ago was a completely better experience than what I had before. This time the switch to Panasonic was a step in the wrong direction. It might work well for you, but don't sell yourself on the idea you're getting a deal.
  401. I have been a devoted Braun shaver since the early 1970s. My last Braun shaver, one of the more recent models, was burnt out by faulty wiring while on vacation, so I started looking around for a new one. I have been disappointed by Braun over the past few years. I saw the quality of their shavers slipping and am not a big fan of those base cleaners that require you to keep investing in their products through the life of their shavers. I read the reviews of the Panasonic shavers and after nearly 40 years decided to jump ship. I am delighted with the Panasonic ES-LA 63. It is about $100 cheaper than the Braun, gives me a better and closer shave, seems of better quality, is much quieter, and now I can dispense with those costly base cleaners. I simply clean the Panasonic every other day by using liquid hand soap and running it through its cleaning cycle under the tap. Braun is spending too much on advertising and too little on product quality and performance. Don't be fooled. I have had my Panasonic for a couple of months now and couldn't be more pleased. I have never taken the time to write a review on Amazon, but I am totally sold on this model shaver and wanted to pass it on. Way to go, Panasonic!
  402. After a month using the ES-LA63-S, I wonder how Panasonic's competition stay in business. I use it with shaving cream (wet) and it's just as good if not better then my Fusion blade and the smooth shave last longer! I had an older Panasonic I used wet and it was good but, didn't do well on my neck. That is not the case with this model, it shaves great every where. I have a Remington I paid over $200 for and it's a piece of junk, not even close to the Panasonic. If you are serious about getting a new electric shaver, get this one. Hands down, it is the best, period!

  406. I have been a Norelco rotary razor user ever since I could grow facial hair (almost 40 years). My dad used Norelcos and I followed his lead. Never had tried a foil-type razor until I came across the ES-LA63 and read all the good reviews. Talk about a difference! My beard grows rather quickly, and I would have to pass the Norelco over my face to freshen it up before going out in the evening. No need with the Panasonic! From the first day I used it, I could tell that I was going to love it. Takes a few days to break old habits of shaving patterns after using a rotary shaver for so many years. The shave got better every day, and the time to complete the shave got less and less. I'm down to 3 minutes or less now. No issues with skin irritation or cuts whatsoever. I always shaved dry with the Norelco and continue to do so with the Panasonic...can't imagine getting any closer by shaving wet with the ES-LA63. Only beef I have is not with the razor - it is with Amazon's shipping time. I realize this product comes with Super Saver Shipping (sent via Postal Service - not the fastest). But Amazon took 4 business days to ship it out. They used to do better than that.
  407. Over the years I've mostly been an electric shaver guy. I've had mixed results with blades, including a satisfied run in recent years with the [[ASIN:B003987CL0 Gillette Fusion Proglide Power Razor, 1-count Package]] and preceding Fusion Power line of blades. This satisfaction was heavily diminished by the ever increasing price of blades ($45 for 14 at a warehouse club), and I once again decided to go with a more permanent solution. While I've had good results with Norelco and Braun offerings, I've been most satisfied with Panasonic, so that's mostly why I went with this shaver.<br /><br />I opted to get the best shaver I could for the $$$ by forsaking any charging station/cleaning apparatus, and thus far I couldn't be happier. The Arc IV is a funny looking shaver, abandoning the cleaner lines of previous designs for a more ergonomic (well if you exclude the challenges created by its immense head) approach. The large head includes four cutters, but only two traditional blade blocks. There are three foils, and a fourth row of blades for larger hairs, and the whole endeavor moves quite nimbly across my face. The only real challenge is in relation to the size of the head, but you quickly learn how to wield this shaver like Thor would Mj&ouml;llnir (or perhaps a bit better)!<br /><br />For those of you new to electric shavers, give it a week to ten days to allow for your skin to adapt to the shaver and vice versa. You should get good results right off the bat, but it will get better once this break in is completed. For those of you new to Panasonic shavers, it will work fine dry, but give a good wet shave a try. You won't be disappointed. You won't need any special goo, as just about anything (including a light bit of shaving creme/gel) will do. This seems to yield a much closer and more satisfying shave. Once done, simply rinse the bits of hair and any shaving medium off, shake it dry, and it'll be ready for the next shave. An occasional bath in a bit of soapy water will keep it nice and clean (it has a hyper fast cleaning setting). One last tip, while this works well either wet or dry, a damp shaver (say one cleaned an hour or so before using) can be irritating on a dry face, so either wait until its dry or go all wet.<br /><br />As far as other details, it's all good. Charge times are modest; battery life is good; it locks off for travel; and its been a charm to use. I don't think there's a better shaver out there, but between Amazon's and Panasonic's (30 day trial period) return policies, you don't have much to lose.p it nice and clean (it has a hyper fast cleaning setting). One last tip, while this works well either wet or dry, a damp shaver (say one cleaned an hour or so before using) can be irritating on a dry face, so either wait until its dry or go all wet. As far as other details, it's all good. Charge times are modest; battery life is good; it locks off for travel; and its been a charm to use. I don't think there's a better shaver out there, but between Amazon's and Panasonic's (30 day trial period) return policies, you don't have much to lose.

  410. As I have aged, my facial hair has become progressively more difficult to shave. Through the years, I've tried most of the top brands of shavers with varying success. For a while, I heard Braun was the best and owned about three of them, but was never happy with the length of time it took me to shave or the closeness. One of them had a battery that failed as soon as the warranty ran out. The last one came with the cleaning system that requires frequent purchase of pricey cleaner.<br /><br />About ten years ago, I ran across a Panasonic shaver at Sharper Image that they guaranteed to be the best, so I fell for the hype and bought one. It proved to be the best shave I had received up to that point and it is still working today. I was sold on Panasonic. But when I read about the reviews on the new ES-LA63-S on Amazon and their excellent price, I decided to try it out. I'm very glad I did.<br /><br />Yes, you'll find glowing reviews of other brands - particularly the more expensive Braun - but I can say that I have never had a closer, more long-lasting shave, nor have I been able to shave more quickly than with this Panasonic. I'm even shaving with gel now for the first time ever. You can virtually go two days between shaves. And the neck area below my chin has always been a problem area with whiskers needing to be cut and recut from a variety of angles. It usually takes me as long to cut that area as the entire rest of my face combined. No more. My neck is shaved smooth just as quickly as any other area and I can complete a very close shave in no more than four minutes. Cleaning the shaver is a breeze as well - no need to buy gimmicky cleaner refills.<br /><br />Now my greatest problem is what to do with all the extra spare time I now have away from shaving. You will not be disappointed with this product. Best ever.

  412. I have sensitive skin, so I get razor bumps easily. The price for both is about $46. That's expensive. I'll update this review once I purchase them.<br /><br />CONCLUSION:<br />============<br />This may very well be the best option for those with sensitive skin. I still have to try the Braun 7, but I believe Panasonic is in a complete different league.<br /><br />RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THOSE WITH SENSITIVE SKIN:<br />==============================================<br />1) Shave DRY at night before taking a shower<br />2) Wash you face with a soap like the Neutrogena soap bar<br />3) Apply a moisturizer (after shower)<br /><br />This works for me, I don't get razor bumps any more and my face looks great in the morning.

  415. I purchased this to replace a Braun 7000 series. It shaves much much closer than the Braun ever did. The cutter head and foil technology is very similar to the Braun's. If the Panasonic has a shortcoming, it is the size of the internal battery. My beard is light and shaving only takes around 120 seconds according to the display. After five days or 10-12 minutes of total shaving time, the display indicates the battery charge is down to 50%. These numbers have been constant for the eight weeks I have owned the shaver. Knowing that LI-ion batteries do not like being fully discharged, I plug in the charger every five days or so. Not a big deal I suppose and the shaver is fully charged within 30 to 45 minutes. Note to Panasonic: The handle is somewhat skinny ever for my small hands so you could increase the battery size and still have a handle that fits the hand. With this one change you would have a great product.

Both seem to work very well. This shaver shaves as close as or negligibly as close as my razors. I love the fact I can rinse it and dip it in water. I can shave without the mess and the possibility of getting a good nic. You can get a little nic but it wouldn't require a steptic pencil. I highly recommend this product.   428. When I bought this, I was thinking of going cheaper again, but am glad I spend the extra bucks ($100 on sale). This shaver gives me the quickest, cleanest shave of all 5 electric shavers I've owned. Like all of them, it does best on the face, not the neck, but it still shaves the neck better than the rest. Plus it's made in Japan. And I like the display. On the downside, I'm pretty sure the beard trimmer is next to useless (it works, but it's hard to use). My first two shavers were Norelco's which were OK, but eventually died (switch on the first, batteries on the second). Then I bought a Panasonic made in Japan ES762, my #2 favorite shaver, which I used for 10 years until the batteries died. I replaced it with a Panasonic ES7109, which was OK, but not as nice as the ES762. When the ES7109's batteries died, I was able to revive the ES762 by getting some affordable NiCad batteries with tabs from Digikey. I will be keeping the ES762 because its beard trimmer is good, and it's nice to have a backup, but it's showing it's age (~16 years old); for example, it's no longer waterproof. So when I saw the ES-LA63 on sale, I bought it, and hope it will last as long. As mentioned at the start, so far I've been very pleased with it. Update: still the best shaver I've used. Unlike the ES7109, it will quickly shave away 2-3 days growth. My old ES762 has been lonely.

  450. Purchased this shaver in Nov 2012. The shaver itself is very good on my fairly light beard and especially when compared with a Norelco. About two weeks later, I received a call from Panasonic telling me that the unit would be replaced and to expect it in 5-7 working days. Now, some 9 WEEKS! later, and after several phone calls and spending literally hours on hold, I was told that they were out of stock (same excuse they had given me four times previously) and that they would refund the price of the shaver. I don't have a problem with that decision but surely it should/could have been made much earlier in the process. Most companies would have just upgraded me to the next higher model and been done with it. As it is, Panasonic has lost a customer. Although I really liked the shaver, I'll be changing to a Braun.

  458. This is a nice shaver, beats the comparatively priced BRAUN shavers I used before (the last one just fell apart on me, so I decided to switch after reading about many others complaining, I guess Gillette/Procter&Gamble has finally managed to drive the Germans into the ground). Got three years of nice shaves when the LCD panel started going wonky. After 4 years it started cutting out under load on the 6th day of shaving for 4 minutes each, so I am guessing the battery isn't holding more than 50% of the original charge anymore. Those two problems got the rating down from 5 stars. Since amazon.com offers these at such a good price I ordered a slightly cheaper model from Panasonic, the RAMDASH-3, which is much sleeker and lighter (but less sophisticated, i.e., no swivel head). I switched to electric wet shave when abandoning BRAUN, and I think the units cannot prevent some wetness from getting inside, and that is probably why the LCD panel went (it would still indicate when the charging is completed).
  459. I have used a rotary type for many years. But lately have not been happy with the results. So I thought I would something different. Am very pleased with my Purchase itgives a great shave..
  460. After 30 or so years of shaving this is the first electric shaver I've used. The shave is not razor close but it is close enough to get by without my looking unshaved. What I do like about it is the ability to dry shave, which is especially good when the water is running cold and I'm in a hurry.<br /><br />The order process and delivery all were up to Amazon's usual high standards.
  461. With all the hoopla the advertisement has about this razor and all its fancy gadgets, it STILL doesn't cut as smooth as a 4-blade razor & shaving cream. I experimented with both since I shave BOTH my face & head. After using the Panasonic ES-LA63-S 4-blade electronic fully charged razor, I STILL had to over several parts of my face & dome with a regular razor to get the stubble that this electronic one missed! A whole lotta hype for a whole lotta money and it ain't worth it. Got myself a refund from Amazon.
  462. Either my beard is too tough and growth too intense or electric shavers can never be a good replacement for the traditional blades. I do not appear to have evolved sufficiently from our ancestors and suffer from a hairy body which extends to facial hair too. All my life I have experimented with different shaving gels, blades and shavers and I thought I had finally found a good electric shaver. However, after 7 months of usage I am going to revert to my earlier blades, but, this is easier said than done because the growth of the hair on your face changes and it takes a while to go back to manual blades. Positives - the upper part of the face (upper lip and chin) get a much much closer shave than any blade Negatives - 1) you still need shaving gels as dry shaves leave large patches of hair and are painful 2) The lower part of your face (neck and area below the jaw line and chin) still need to be shaved by blades as no amount of trying shaves that area cleanly 3) shaving time increases from 6 minutes to 20, and, on the days when you need to clean the blades and foil it takes 30 minutes 4) you need to keep going over the area again and again to get a close shave 5) while the upper lip and chin are smoother than they have ever been, somehow I look much darker after I have started shaving with an electric shaver. 6) If you decide to skip shaving for even one day then the next day when you shave is an extremely painful and lengthier experience - electric shavers are not meant for people who do not shave daily Nothing against Panasonic - this review is meant for electric shavers in general
  463.   473. Have had this for awhile I'm guessing going about a year and a half now soon. I have to say it was hard at first switching from those popular brand name blades to a electiric kind. At first it was rough and my very sensitive skin was not happy. It felt awful after every shave. I didn't give up as I've read & been told you need time to adjust to such a difference. So I gave it time and am happy to say I got used to it not to long after the switch.<br /><br />The shaver still works great and I took my time reading countless reviews on Amazon and many other places included all those mens ratings online. I will pay for a quality product but didn't want to over pay either. This item was being sold for a good amount lower at the time then what it was first advertised. So at the lower price I took the plunged at the still high price for just a shaver. I will honestly say it's worth the money and I'm sure the price should be lower by now as time goes on.<br /><br />I mostly use the shaver dry but have used it wet with shaving cream but I just don't seem to like it wet. From going to a blade with shaving cream/gel to dry you would think I would want to use it with the wet function of it but I don't. I will say clean up is very easy as I just run it through water and it gets clean fast. That was a big reason why I wanted a wet & dry shaver as it's just so much easier to clean. It still works great and I highly recommend this shaver & brand. It charges very fast too! It also keeps the charge for a long time. That was another big selling point for me as I don't like those 12 hours charging times for only 1 hour use. Who would be crazy enough to deal with that?

  498. This shaver gives the most comfortable and close shaves that I have ever gotten with an electric. Since I have sensitive skin, I have used a Norelco Nivea Shaver for years. When I checked out replacement blades for the Norelco last month, I found that the price had more than doubled to OVER $100, just for blades! The Nivea lotion cartridges that it used have always been pricey as well (about $30 for a 3-pack which lasts about 2 1/2 months).<br /> So, I thought for over $100, I may as well get a new shaver. After a LOT of research, I had read nothing but stellar comments on this Panasonic. So I decided to give it a try.<br /> Pre-shave lotion: I have never liked the smell of 'Lectric Pre-shave lotion', so I decided to try the Rite-Aid equivalent (Renewal for about $3). It does not have an overpowering smell that clashes with my after shave lotion. Using this first, the Panasonic glides over my skin, and gives an extremely close and comfortable shave! I have not had a smoother, closer shave since I switched from a blade over a decade ago! The Panasonic leaves NO red-skin or irritation on my face or neck! I've been using for about 3 or 4 weeks now, and am VERY pleased with it.<br /> A couple of days ago, the display showed the icon that indicates it needs cleaning. Once again, the Panasonic has a very simple AND economic method for cleaning. Just squirt a little liquid hand soap on the top, run it in Turbo mode for about 30 seconds, then remove the foil and rinse it out with water. Simple and economical!<br /> The bottom line: I am very pleased with this shaver. Comfortable, CLOSE shaves, easy maintenance. I would buy it again in a heartbeat!!

  504. I have always had a hard time shaving due to thick beard that grows quickly for me. I have always used an electric shaver with 2 blades or a 2 or 3 blade manual razor. My last electric shaver was a Panasonic ES8103S which worked to remove most of my facial hair after 2 passes, but it took 5 minutes or more sometimes and I always had to use manual shaver too.<br /><br />The Panasonic ES-LA63-S is a sharper and faster electric shaver than I've tried ever before. The face of the shaver is twice as wide as I've used before and is a bit awkward to use, but I've gotten used to it now. Around my adam's apple & the joint why jaw bone is below my ear don't shave very well, but that's the case for most electric shavers I've tried. I use this shaver perpendicular on my mustache area and not vertically which seems to help. Otherwise my mustache area cuts me above my lips a lot. The shaver cut my skin all over for the first few times, but it went away with time and it doesn't cut me at all now.<br /><br />I have to clean the shaver by taking of the head of the shaver and wiping the hair out of the blades with a stiff brush every 3-4 days otherwise it won't cut. But, I've had to do that with every other electric shaver too. I have to clean the shaver sooner than other shavers, but it has faster moving blades and seems to remove more hair than other shavers. I sometimes have to do 2 passes with the new shaver, but not every day. It shaves faster than other shavers & is fastest one I've ever used. I gave it 4 stars, because it's not perfect, but it's very good & removes all my hair with thorough use. I'm satisfied. I was going to get the braun series 7 shaver with the vibration feature, but it seems too hard to clean.

Shockingly smooth in fact. The razor is behind a metal grid, so how is it possible that it shaves so smooth? the marketing material has some mumbo jumbo about how the mechanism pulls up hairs to make the cut which allows for a smooth shave, but it also sounds like magic to me.<br /><br />If you're like me and on a razor, but wondering what an electric is like, this is a pretty good one to start with.<br /><br />It's durable<br />Battery runs for a good 40 minutes or so<br />It's waterproof<br />It charges fast<br />Shaves real smooth<br />Is easy to clean and maintain (get spare blades now, might as well)<br />Has a travel pouch to help protect it some.<br />Battery indicator is pretty useful.<br /><br />Since this is the only one I've ever used, I'm probably not the best judge of how good this is compared to others, but it's hard to imagine being disappointed with something this effective.

  534. TL;DR: A great electric razor. I recommend to buy.<br /><br />I came from a Braun 7 series. I decided against another Braun because the company was purchased by Procter and Gamble and the replacement foils I purchased were of terrible quality.<br /><br />So I came across this electric razor after reading countless reviews. I like in line razors instead of three round head razors.<br /><br />Let's start with Pros and Cons.<br /><br />Pros:<br />Great foil and close cut.<br />Great Dry shave. Better than my Braun<br />Fast charging. 5 minute charge will give you 10 minute shave if in a bind.<br />Nice design and small as well as light.<br /><br />Cons:<br />A bit loud. Not as loud as my old Braun but loud<br />Can't shave while charging.<br /><br />My first week of shaves. The shave is quick and cuts very close. My skin is not pulled and I don't use shaving cream or the like. I would like to get some Kiss My Face shaving gel to try out and see how that treats my skin as well. The shave gets the areas in one motion with little need to go over an area twice. I grow a pretty fast beard and even after a weekend of no shaving this cuts right through.<br /><br />Good shaver and I would recommend.
  535. We gave this item as a Christmas gift only three months ago. Already, the rechargeable batteries have stopped holding a charge.
  536. BEEN THINKING ABOUT REPLACING MY OL' PHILLIPS NORELCO AFTER TEN YEARS OF SERVICE. READING OTHER ONLINE REVIEWS OF THIS PRODUCT AND DECIDED TO GET ONE. PRIME SERVICE DELIVERY HAD IT HERE IN NO TIME. CHARGED IT UP, WHILE ALLOWING MY STUBLE TO GROW JUST A TAD BIT LONGER. TURNED IT ON AND WENT TO TOWN. WOW!!! WHAT A SMOOTH AND CLOSE SHAVE. I KEPT FEELING WHERE THE STUBBLE USED TO BE AND THERE WASN'T ANYTHING THERE. YOU GOT TO TRY IT. SIMPLY AMAZING!!

  550. ****October '15 Update****** Do NOT Buy *******<br />The shaver sputtered and died within 3 months.   561. I have used a handful of low and high end rotary razors for the last 10 years, embroiled in skin irritation and frustration. So I decided to give up shaving for a year, until accepting the need to look a little more presentable, so I bought this razor. I can now get a wet shave in 3 minutes without irritation or clogging up the razor. What wizardry is this? I have to use a lot of shaving cream (enough so that passing the razor over my skin still leaves behind shaving cream), but this razor can handle that no problem. And the enormous shaving surface gets the job done quickly. I have curly facial hair, so it doesn't get every single hair, but I just use the beard trimmer on those few stragglers. 5 gold stars. Update: 8 months later: Still love this thing. I wet shave with barbasol cream in 60-90 seconds and have no problems with irritation! Still works quickly, cleans well, and holds its charge. I still use a beard trimmer to cut the tough-to-get hairs to avoid irritation.
  562. This replaces my Panasonic ES-8243, which is still very good. (Blades were wearing out, and I decided to try the new shaver just for the fun of it.) The LA63 does give a very close shave, but it has an even wider head than the 8243, and feels a bit bulky. It also retains the somewhat awkward flip-up trimmer on the back side. That's one aspect that Brauns do better, but overall the Panasonics give a better shave and are easier to live with. All of the better performing Brauns come with the silly cleaning system, which wastes money and counter space. With the LA63 (or the 8243) it takes all of 20 seconds to run it in some warm soapy water in the sink, and then it is perfectly clean.

  574. Best electric razor made.
  575. (UPDATE 11/20/13 - To research complaints about battery drain, I went ahead and did a battery drain test AFTER the display on my shaver showed \\"10%\\" of juice left. It ran for a FULL 35 minutes beyond this point before conking out. I think what's happening is the display drops in 10% increments after each use, giving users the misleading impression that they've got little charge left especially when they hit the \\"50% left\\" mark. Based on my \\"battery drain\\" test, this is NOT true. The battery in this shaver is GREAT, holding a charge that lasts well within the 45 minutes touted on a single charge.)<br /><br />=========================<br />ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOW.<br />=========================<br /><br />* Until now, I've always believed electric razors could NEVER come close to beating hand-held blades. But this Panasonic comes very close - so much so that I rarely use a straight blade anymore!<br /><br />* Disclosure: I do NOT work for Panasonic and I am NOT being compensated in any way for this review. But this [[ASIN:B002N5MHLU Panasonic ES-LA63-S Arc 4 Mens Electric Shaver]] is pure, unadulterated awesomeness, blowing every competing Norelco and Braun shaver out of the water!<br /><br />* Very few people can afford $300 for this machine. But when it comes up for sale for under $150, which is often - you should snap it up because it's worth EVERY penny - and THEN SOME.<br /><br />* Unlike other electric razors, this Panasonic cuts so close without nicking up your skin that you won't believe your eyes and you won't believe your fingers when you run them over your face after each shave. Neck hair will take longer to shave - but NOT too much longer compared to other electric razors. (And I have coarse dark hair which grows quickly.)<br /><br />* A blue LED light clocks each session. When you turn it off, it tells you how much battery life is left, i.e., 90%, 80%, 70%, 60%, etc. You'll get about 45 minutes of shaving on a single charge - or about 10 days worth of shaving without reaching for the re-charger. (BTW, the reason this shaver won't work with the cord is common sense! Who wants to be electrocuted in the shower with the cord attached?)<br /><br />* Cleaning is a breeze. Just press the buttons on the right and left sides of the head - and the foil framework comes off easily. Turn your shaver on and hold the power button down for at least two seconds. Your shaver will go into a \\"cleaning mode\\" whereby its blades will vibrate like mad, providing the cleaning equivalent of jumping to light-speed in a \\"Star Wars\\" movie - without rattling like the Millennium Falcon. Just run tap water over the blades and all hair cuttings will vibrate off into your bathroom sink.<br /><br />* I've tried this shaver in both wet and dry modes and its performance is superb. However, shaving in wet mode with a thin cream such as [[ASIN:B004DU3V2M Kiss My Face Moisture Shave Key Lime Cream]] is supersonic awesome. (Note, shaving \\"wet\\" makes cleaning easier because you'll have less facial oil when you clean the heads after every use.) Unlike Norelcos with rotary blades which pivot a little, the head on this Panasonic pivots up and down AND side to side, hugging your face in every direction. It has two (2) motors. One cuts up and down and the other cuts from side to side. It's great at getting rid of 99 7/8% of my neck hair and the nubs in both corners of my mouth. (More about that \\"1/8\\" difference later.)<br /><br />* This shaver comes with a travel pouch and a locking switch (to prevent it from going on while traveling) - as well as a blade cover. It also has a pop-up trimmer for bushy sideburns and mustaches. The head can even be locked to prevent pivoting while shaving.<br /><br />* Now, about replacement blades. Do the math. Panasonic still wins. If you have to change blades every six-months-to-a-year - well, no offense, but you've got a genetic profile of a werewolf. Most people with \\"standard\\" beards won't have toreplace the blades on this machine for WAY MORE than a year, and I have a tough, coarse beard.<br /><br />* The money you'll spend for two (2) [[ASIN:B001159UMM Panasonic WES9068PC Men's Shaver Replacement Inner Blades]] - is TINY compared to the cost of replacement blades for other electric razors. This Panasonic takes two (2) replacement blades - which doubles to four blades - because two additional blades are built into the outer foils - which hook into the base of the replacement blades. Note that the outer foil unit - [[ASIN:B002N5MHLA Panasonic WES9165PC Men's Shaver Replacement Foil]] - does cost more to replace, but you won't replace it often (unless you break or puncture it) - because the two blades built into them are designed to cut thicker hair. These blades are comparable to what's found on a trimmer for sideburns, but the foils protect you from getting nicked or cut. (And I don't know anyone who's ever replaced the bigger blades on a trimmer.) Don't get me wrong. You WILL change the two-bladed foil unit eventually, but in the long run, you WILL still save money compared to what it costs to buy one 18-multi-blade blister pack locked up in plastic cases in stores. If you want to save even more money, buy the foil and the two blades TOGETHER - which are available in the [[ASIN:B002N5MHL0 Panasonic WES9025PC Men's Shaver Replacement Out Foil and Blade Kit for ES-LA63-S]]. Buying this \\"kit\\" should save you around $20 to $30 than buying these items separately.<br /><br />* I'm taking away a \\"half-star\\" (even though fractional-stars aren't allowed here) - for one reason. While this is the BEST electric razor I've ever used - note that in my first paragraph above, I said \\"this Panasonic comes very close\\" to beating a hand-held blade. After a wet shave (which I recommend over dry if you're not in a hurry) - I run my fingers over my cheeks, jaw bone and neck. They slide like a sled on snow across my face and jaw line - and over 99 7/8% of my neck.<br /><br />* But there are always one or two tiny spots on my neck this razor won't completely get. Now, you might ask, \\"well then what's the point of buying this [[ASIN:B002N5MHLU Panasonic ES-LA63-S Arc 4 Mens Electric Shaver with Dual Motor and Multi-Flex Pivoting Head]] if it's not as good as a blade?\\"<br /><br />* This is my response: Shaving is one of the most aggravating and time consuming chores men face EVERY day. The type of finish you will get with this [[ASIN:B002N5MHLU Panasonic ES-LA63-S Arc 4 Mens Electric Shaver with Dual Motor and Multi-Flex Pivoting Head]] is EQUAL to using a hand-held blade for, let's say, four minutes. Think about it. During my hand-held \\"blading\\" days, unless I was headed to a special event - I did NOT spend as much time to get at every cotton-picking nook and cranny on my neck, especially the area below my ears. I could still FEEL tiny bristles, but I could not SEE them. When 100% smoothness was required, I spent more time WITH A HAND-HELD BLADE to get at those nooks and crannies anyway. Hence the \\"touch up\\" conundrum. Today, I STILL keep a hand-held two-blader nearby if perfection is my goal. But most of the time, I don't bother.<br /><br />* One last thing. Don't mess with electric shaving kits which come with \\"immersible tubs\\" filled with expensive cleaning solutions. Panasonic recommends just liquid soap and water to clean the heads. (After shaving in wet mode, I don't even bother with soap. The residual suds from the [[ASIN:B004DU3V2M Kiss My Face Moisture Shave Key Lime Cream]] and a strong blast of tap water while the heads are in \\"cleaning mode\\" does the job for me. If I want to clean after shaving dry, I just use a blast of tap water, no soap.)<br /><br />* Yes, the $300 price tag is steep and yes, you get what you pay for. But this Panasonic is almost always on sale for below retail. For all these reasons, this [[ASIN:B002N5MHLU Panasonic ES-LA63-S Arc 4 Mens Electric Shaver with Dual Motor and Multi-Flex Pivoting Head]] still gets a STRONG four and one-half stars./><br />* But there are always one or two tiny spots on my neck this razor won't completely get. Now, you might ask, \\"well then what's the point of buying this [[ASIN:B002N5MHLU Panasonic ES-LA63-S Arc 4 Mens Electric Shaver with Dual Motor and Multi-Flex Pivoting Head]] if it's not as good as a blade?\\"<br /><br />* This is my response: Shaving is one of the most aggravating and time consuming chores men face EVERY day. The type of finish you will get with this [[ASIN:B002N5MHLU Panasonic ES-LA63-S Arc 4 Mens Electric Shaver with Dual Motor and Multi-Flex Pivoting Head]] is EQUAL to using a hand-held blade for, let's say, four minutes. Think about it. During my hand-held \\"blading\\" days, unless I was headed to a special event - I did NOT spend as much time to get at every cotton-picking nook and cranny on my neck, especially the area below my ears. I could still FEEL tiny bristles, but I could not SEE them. When 100% smoothness was required, I spent more time WITH A HAND-HELD BLADE to get at those nooks and crannies anyway. Hence the \\"touch up\\" conundrum. Today, I STILL keep a hand-held two-blader nearby if perfection is my goal. But most of the time, I don't bother.<br /><br />* One last thing. Don't mess with electric shaving kits which come with \\"immersible tubs\\" filled with expensive cleaning solutions. Panasonic recommends just liquid soap and water to clean the heads. (After shaving in wet mode, I don't even bother with soap. The residual suds from the [[ASIN:B004DU3V2M Kiss My Face Moisture Shave Key Lime Cream]] and a strong blast of tap water while the heads are in \\"cleaning mode\\" does the job for me. If I want to clean after shaving dry, I just use a blast of tap water, no soap.)<br /><br />* Yes, the $300 price tag is steep and yes, you get what you pay for. But this Panasonic is almost always on sale for below retail. For all these reasons, this [[ASIN:B002N5MHLU Panasonic ES-LA63-S Arc 4 Mens Electric Shaver with Dual Motor and Multi-Flex Pivoting Head]] still gets a STRONG four and one-half stars.
  576. It is my first electric shaver. I think I prefer blades. They get a closer shave. With this, it seems I am shaving every day. With a Mach3, I can get away with shaving every other day
  577. I had used the previous version of this shaver for about 3-4 years, until the battery got to the point that it wasn't holding a charge very long, and it needed a whole new foil head again. Rather than buy the parts, I decided to upgrade to this one.<br /><br />The previous one I had also included the charging cleaning station. I found that to be more of a pain to use than anything else. The charging station was nice, but I found myself not using the cleaner that often, and not willing to continually purchase the cleaning/filter packs.<br /><br />This one is just the shaver, and I much prefer it. The cleaning station is not worth the extra expense up front or down the line. I simply take a little dish soap and run it through the shaver every couple weeks, and let it dry. Works fine and saves me money.<br /><br />This one does do a better job at cutting my facial hair as well. I have fairly thick and rapid growth, and it cuts smoothly with no snags or pulls. It still requires a couple runs over the same spot to get it all, especially if I don't shave for a day or two, but it is not that bad. The end result is very smooth though, and I experience little to no facial irritation, which is something I would have from time to time when using a blade.<br /><br />I do use Remington pre-shave powder sticks, but not every time. That seems to make a difference as well. I typically shave right after I shower. I have tried it wet, and it does work well that way too, but my eyesight is no longer good enough to shave without the use of glasses. Thus I cannot shave in the shower, and when I use shaving cream outside of the shower I still need glasses to see in the mirror, and end up getting cream on my rims during the process. Thus for me this shaver provides the absolute best dry shaving experience I have ever had.

This model is fine, but I think you can save a few bucks and go with the next model down without seeing any real difference in performance.   583. Anyone who wastes another dollar on ANY Norelco shaver will be kicking themselves after purchasing this one. Norelcos are overpriced, terrible for your skin and are usually in the garbage or in for repair within two years. This Panasonic is the BEST shaver Ive owned in 25 years. I highly recommend.
  584. Needed a razor that wouldn't cut while I was on a blood thinner. Past experience with electric was not as good as blade. I'm having much better luck with this wet shave. Still not as good as a blade but getting better with more use. Great for knocking off stubble when in hurry.
  585. This is the third (may be fourth) Panasonic shaver that i have had as I like to shave whilst showering. My previous shaver was the Panasonic five head shaver and it was an improved shave over the previous models however it stopped charging.<br />I reviewed the latest shower suitable electric shavers and decided to purchased the cheaper Panasonic four head model. I was pleased with the quality of this shave.<br />After some months the five head began to charge again. I was then able to compare the quality of the five head and the four head models. I could not determine any difference. Based on this my view would be to go with the cheaper model and maybe chance the blades a little more often however as the blades last around a year this is not a big cost.<br />With regard to costs - from time to time I have used traditional disposable blade shavers and by, my calculations, the purchase cost of the disposable blades over a two year period is about equal to the purchase cost of the Panasonic with the replacement blades required over that period.<br />With regard to shave quality - I find that the Panasonic shave is closer and notably less damage to the skin. I use a good quality shaving cream Crabtree and Evelyn - not a foam - which is very cost effective as only a small amount is necessary with a pot lasting up to six months. A foam is not required because the shaving action causes to cream to foam as the shaving progresses.<br /><br />I have noted some comments on battery life, or perceived lack of it. I would support the statement that there are about five shaves per charge and that the shaver can not be used whilst connected to a power supply. I seem to recall that older Panasonic versions lasted longer.<br />I have also observed that all reviewers state that the Panasonic has a closer shave than other brands, even blade shavers and with less skin damage. I have used<br />other brands and this observation I firmly support.<br /><br />So the question would seem to bethe purchase criteria priorities - close shave or charge convenience.<br /><br />The answer would seem to be in the discussions on battery charge management.<br />From the discussions would seem that the answer is to keep the charge maintained as high as possible.<br /><br />On the premise that removing the beard is the purpose of shaving then it would seem that using the Panasonic and charging it after each shave delivers the best outcome. From the information offered on battery life management it would seem clear that at the least, this does not harm the battery.
  586. best shave I've ever had from an electric razor. good battery life. easy to clean
  587. Panasonic have won gold in the design and shaving results from this shaver. This is the closest shave Iv had with any electric shaver over many years and is identical ( for me ) to a wet razor shave. I only use it dry and 3 minutes later smooth skin ! Really good. as I shave every day I don't know how it would handle a 3 day growth but with patience I guess it would do an excellent job.
  588. I tried a battery shaver a long time ago it was a waste of money the shave was not close to the skin. I have been using Gillette Mac 3 for the past 6 years I was very happy with it close shave I shave only 2-3 times a week. Now I have a job where u must shave everyday so it started to get annoying . So I decided to try again with this ES-LA63 all I can say is wow . I have been using it for 2 months now everyday and I love it it does take a little more time but it is well worth it . I use neutrogena cream it gets the closest shave. To get the closest shave I use up and down motion and left to right after. I have very sensitive skin and I never had an issue .
  589. I have very thick facial hair that also grows very quickly. I have been using different Gillette cartridge razors for last 14 years. However, I got tired of paying hundreds of dollars for cartridges and switched to DE razors. I like shaving with the DE razor! The DE razor provides a good quality shave, and razor blades are really cheap. However, the shaving process can take up to 15 minutes, and I do not always have this time. I needed something that I could shave with in less than 5 minutes. As a result, I have decided to purchase this shaver as an addition to my DE razor.<br /><br />Initially I was very skeptical that any electric shaver could deliver a good shave in a reasonable amount of time. I used a Braun shaver about 14 years ago, and I was very unsatisfied with its performance, and this was a reason why I switched to Gillette. However, after reading all the good reviews for different electric shavers, I have decided to give them a try with a hope that electric shavers' technology has advanced since my last Braun.<br /><br />Based on my research, I have decided to purchase this Panasonic shaver. I believe that this shaver has the best combination of price and quality. The quality of my first shave with this shaver was OK but not good. However, I read manual, and I knew that it should take my hair about 30 days to adjust to new shaver, so I did not expect much from my first shave. After just two weeks the quality of the shave improved significantly! So, this 30 day requirement is not a gimmick.<br /><br />I have been using this shaver for over a month by now, and I can say that this shaver can deliver a good quality shave especially if I do wet shaving. I have to admit that this shaver cannot give me a super smooth ﬁnish that I can get from my DE razor. However, the quality of shave is comparable to what I can get from G Fusion with a cartridge that has been used for 3-4 times.<br /><br />Some Pros:<br /><br />- I can get rid of my very thick facial hair inless than 5 min.<br />- I have never had any irritations after shaving with this shaver.<br />- It is very easy to clean, and the process takes about 30 seconds. So you do not need to spend money on cleaning cartridges. However, if you do prefer to use a cleaning station and cleaning cartridges, you do have this option.<br />- You can shave 10 times (5 min each) on full charge.<br />- It charges fast! In order to prolong the battery life, I follow recommendations on batteryuniversity.com and charge the battery when it has 50% charge left.<br />- It is cheaper to shave with electric shaver than with cartridge razor.<br />If you use this shaver every day for a year and trash it after this, each shave will cost you $0.24 (I got my shaver for 89$). However this shaver will most likely last for more than one year, so cost per shave could be even lower.<br />DE razor cost per shave = $0.02, given that you trash a blade after 5 uses.<br />G Fusion cost per shave = $0.62, given that you trash a cartridge after 5 uses. Gillette's promise that one cartridge can last five weeks is laughable unless you shave once a week.<br /><br />- The charger is 110 / 240 V, so you do not need to have any additional chargers if you travel abroad.<br /><br />I have not discovered any significant Cons yet!<br /><br />Overall, I am very satisfied with this product.
  590. I know this electric shaver is very highly rated, but my experience with it was not good. After a lot of research, I selected this razor largely based on amazon reviews. But after using it for over a month, I decided that it was subpar. I only used it wet in the shower, trying multiple shave creams. But after giving it much time, and fiddling with all sorts of techniques, I found it took longer to get a poorer shave than what I get with my gillette fusion proglide razor. I had much more irritation with the panasonic than my experience with my traditional razor. The panny did an awful job shaving the neck area. I would often step out of the shower, look in the mirror and then have to shave the missed areas with a traditional razor....really, what's the purpose ? I don't have a difficult beard by any stretch. This shaver was a complete let down. I don't like writing negative reviews, but I need to be honest since this is not an inexpensive item. Perhaps it works great as a dry shaver - I'll give it the benefit of the doubt and 2 stars.

I've experience no razor rash.<br /><br />I've used it for about a month now, so still too earlier to tell if I'll cross over to foil permanently.   604. I am not going to be able to add much to the other 635 reviews. I've been shaving for 35 years.   606. I have tender skin, and all of my previous attempts to use electric razors have resulted in irritation and burning. So I've been wet-shaving in the shower with brush-and-lather and a blade for years and years.<br /><br />But I'm trying very hard to reduce my water usage. Also, wet-shaving in the shower when traveling can be a challenge. So I thought I'd give electrics another try.<br /><br />I have a mustache and goatee, and am mostly bald up top. I go for a smooth shave, but don't mind some light stubble, so a good close blade-shave can last be two or three days.<br /><br />The Panasonic does not irritate my skin, which is wonderful. But it doesn't shave as close as a blade (I use Gillette Mach II), although it's more than adequately close. I'd say that I need to shave again a day sooner with the Panasonic than with the blade. But it uses no water, takes about 4 minutes, and doesn't burn my skin, so it's all good.<br /><br />I like how easy it is to clean, just rinsing it under water.<br /><br />I'm impressed with the battery. I'm getting a good 30 minutes or more of runtime per charge. We recently took a 3-week trip, and I brought just the shaver without the charger, and it lasted the whole trip (shaving every third day or so). The LCD readout is useful.<br /><br />So, pretty much everything I could have wanted with no issues worth mentioning. No comment yet on blade replacement because, at my rate of use, I expect that to be a couple of years away.
