  618. Well like the subject states, this was my first electric shaver in 25 years switching after switching from Gillette Powerglide 5 blade razors. There are hundreds of reviews going over the features so I'll just add what I drew from my experience.<br /><br />- The most important tip above all tips is to read the manual before you use it.<br />- When switching shaving methods for any razor, allow 30 days before you judge the shave. When I first started using it it was horrible, took me 8 minutes and I had to go over it several times and I had patches of stubble and wanted to return it. After a month, I'm down to 3-4 minutes and it is almost as close as my 5 blade shaver and I am totally pleased over all.<br />- The shaver works much better wet if you pre wash and use some shaving lotion, I really liked the Kiss My Face product.<br />- I also found it worked much better using Williams Electric Pre shave lotion to soften the whiskers before applying shaving cream if I don't shave for a few days.<br />- Use short slow, light, smooth and even strokes and go both directions until you can no longer hear it cutting any whiskers. You will not get it to shave closer by pressing harder. Electric shaves will never feel as close as a blade shave because it does not take off a layer of skin (which is healthier) It does however pull the whisker up and shave under the skin for a better shave if you do it right. They also recommend stretching your skin with your spare hand, but I personally don't find it practical to do so when your using lotion it just makes it a mess and hand slippery.<br />- There are a couple of spots that I can never quite reach. So I use my cheap beard trimmer with it's foil single blade shave attachment to get around my adams apple area, there's just no way any full size electric shave is going to fit so the point is to use a smaller blade of choice. The Norelco beard trimmers with this attachment are dirt cheap, can find one like my Norelco for under 20$.<br />- Rinse the shaver off after each use, use some electric shaver lubricant and clean it good every two weeks.20$.<br />- Rinse the shaver off after each use, use some electric shaver lubricant and clean it good every two weeks.
  619. great shave, great trimmer. for the price i love this thing. be careful when putting the head out the window to blow off the excess hair because the foil guard will fall out!!!!<br /><br />i have a very coarse beard and have to replace the cutter every 6 months, but i think that is a fault of my own and not the razor. best razor i have used yet and ive had the best norelco and braun.
  620. Given a 4 star rating instead of 5 due to the location and angle of the trimmer, which makes it difficult to see what you are doing when working on the bikini area. However, the battery lasts a long time and has a indicator that lets you know how much time you have left before needing to be recharged. It also works well with shaving the legs, giving a really close shave. Also, my husband likes to use it on his face, and he has never been a fan of electric shavers.<br /><br />Recommend this product for men, and also for women who want a more powerful shaver that lasts longer than those designed for women.

  631. Ok, this is only my third electric shaver in my life. I have a Norelco 8894 XL jet black rotatory. I had it since 2004, and it gave a very good shave, no complaints. Recently, I lost most of the recharger indicator and the on/off button is starting to come apart. However, it still strong and working. So the hand writing on the wall said buy another one soon so we come the Panasonic ES-LA63-S. I started exploring reviews and recommendations and it pointed towards a few models. What I did was made a satisfaction index by adding the 5 and 4 votes then divide by total number of purchases. So actually the other model was the blue model with less features, higher priced and sightly higher satisfaction index. The ES-LA63-S had the more features and when it came on sale it became my choice. So I got it about a month ago. It came with a charger and decent length chord, and a nice form fitting travel pouch, no cleaning brush or stand. It had a small charge in it. So a light went off and said do a shave off between the Panasonic and Norelco. So I shaved one side with the Panasonic and the other side of face with the Norelco. Now I have small features and so the area is slightly smaller then the average male especially under the nose. So proceeding I noted that the Panasonic besides looking awkward due to the size of it shaving head was actually easy to handle and maneuver especially around my mouth, under my nose and cliff chin, done in two minutes. I repeated with the Noreloc which took more time mostly due to the smaller head and less blades. It actually took a little more work to get the difficult areas. Upon finishing with both I checked my face and the Panasonic shaved side was definitely soft and very smooth. The Norelco shaved face side was only smooth, not very smooth, not soft feeling, however, good enough to look at. In all the reviews I checked out noise levels and only got subjective reports. So I decided to check out the decibel readings with a good decibel reader. The Panasonic checked in with a steady 77 decibels with the reading taken only a few inches off the head. I did the same procedure with the Norelco and got a 65 decibels a few inches from the head. So neither reading is damaging to the ears, in fact it is around a loud voice. Now annoying factor is a separate issue as it isn't very musical that is another story. I wasn't annoyed at all, it has a pleasant hum. Also I have fairly tender skin and I can't really use a blade on it without a rash. My skin experience using the Panasonic is my skin has very slight burning feeling, no skin coloration change, and over time I expect it will go down. I don't use wet shave and so that is for you to check out. From what I read most users got a even closer or more comfortable wet shave then dry shave. Hey it depends upon you personal tolerances, tastes, and goals. The only other thing don't shave as it running out of power, ouch! I learned the hard way when it stops then has you by the short hairs, it hurts when you pull it off your face, LOL! So if you are one of those that believes you need to bleed the power dry don't do it on your face. So everything works fine, lots of power, easy to clean, and it just lays on its side on my sink. Who needs a stand? Idea for a stand, just buy one of those glassware art objects that can support it head down and you good to go. Maybe if I think about it I may get a six month or one year check in how it goes. Good hunting, my hunts over, bagged my game. Oh, why a 4.5? Because there is always one that is better out there. : ^ ))good decibel reader. The Panasonic checked in with a steady 77 decibels with the reading taken only a few inches off the head. I did the same procedure with the Norelco and got a 65 decibels a few inches from the head. So neither reading is damaging to the ears, in fact it is around a loud voice. Now annoying factor is a separate issue as it isn't very musical that is another story. I wasn't annoyed at all, it has a pleasant hum. Also I have fairly tender skin and I can't really use a blade on it without a rash.   646. I have a tough beard that grows very fast. I also get crazy ingrown hairs. I have never been able to shave every day. Basically I've spent my life (I'm now in my forties) like a cast member from Miami Vice. Most recently I had gone to old style &#34;safety razors&#34;, which were about the best compromise of quality, price and comfort. However, I still could not shave daily without a great deal of discomfort.<br /><br />I have tried shavers before and my father was a big fan. Between hand me downs and gifts I've tried top-end norelcos several times but they were always hard on my skin, under my chin, and left scores of the thickest hairs I grows scattered around my face.<br /><br />Recently I did some research and I saw that this model and the high-end Brauns were rated highly on a couple of sites. I like that this one was priced right and it is good wet too. I've had it a week now. I'm getting an unbelievably close shave, I can shave as often as I like (daily or even more) and I've done it wet and dry. I prefer wet when I have a minute to lather up, and when I do so the closeness of the shave is unreal. Dry, I've tried a couple of pre-shave products and it's really quite pleasant and doesn't dry or irritate my skin.<br /><br />Really and truly, if you have ruled out these things because your beard is too tough or you've had bad experiences before, you need to give this a try. It's really amazing and so much less painful and expensive (in the long haul) than anything I've tried before.<br /><br />TIP: Don't use this if your beard already has several days growth. You'll get best results with a day or two of growth when you first use it and then you can play around with what works for you.

  655. Added 3.24.10<br /><br />I've discovered this shaver works best with liquid body soap or hand soap instead of shaving cream. With shaving cream you might end up with hairs missed especially in difficult areas such as around your adam's apple. In fact, with shaving cream I basically had to shave twice, and oftentimes I ended up taking out the blade razor to clean up what the electric shaver missed, but using the liquid soap I've had no problems whatsoever.<br /><br />Liquid soap is also what you're supposed to use per the instructions to clean the foil and blade.<br /><br />-------------------------<br /><br />Addition to my original review:<br /><br />It pays to read the instruction manual. Unlike prior electric shavers I've had, this one doesn't need new parts very often--my Norelco for instance costs me about the same in new rotating shaver blade heads alone as my disposable cartridge blade shaver and requires a their own brand of shaving cream without option. In fact, according to the manual, I only need to replace the foil and blades once every year or two! So cost-wise, this shaver is not only better but costs less in the long run.<br /><br />Also, once I became used to using this shaver it has been giving me shaves just as good as a razor but without all the problems. Even when I haven't shaved a couple of days, it mows down the extra stubble.<br /><br />The is the first electric shaver that actually works as advertised, in fact better.<br /><br />Lastly, the sonic cleaning feature really works as well too. No special cleaners required; just put some hand soap on the foil and turn on the sonic clean under the tap; then open it up and do the same for the blades without adding soap--it comes out looking like it had been polished.<br /><br />The shaver even has indicators on its display for when it's time to clean and when it's time to replace the foil and such.<br /><br />BOTTOM LINE: Worth the money if you want an electric shaver that wont disappoint as others are prone to do.<br /><br />--------------------------<br />My original review:<br /><br />What I especially like as an American man who has suffered many electric shavers over the years that have come to me as Christmas gifts is the fact that this one allows me to use the same shaving cream I like using with my standard cartridge blade shaver instead of something specially made for the particular make and model.<br /><br />I realized it might spell the quick doom of this very expensive shaver to try it, but I just had to, so I used my shaving cream from The Body Shop rather than whatever might be recommended and the shaver did just fine. I drowned it in water with the shaver on and it didn't break down. In short, I've given this shaver about as much abuse as I could and it just kept on going, a month later as well as it did on the first try.<br /><br />The durability of the parts has been outstanding as well, possibly because I was able to use shaving cream with it that protected face and shaver alike.<br /><br />I also like the cool gadget aspect of the design.What I especially like as an American man who has suffered many electric shavers over the years that have come to me as Christmas gifts is the fact that this one allows me to use the same shaving cream I like using with my standard cartridge blade shaver instead of something specially made for the particular make and model. I realized it might spell the quick doom of this very expensive shaver to try it, but I just had to, so I used my shaving cream from The Body Shop rather than whatever might be recommended and the shaver did just fine. I drowned it in water with the shaver on and it didn't break down. In short, I've given this shaver about as much abuse as I could and it just kept on going, a month later as well as it did on the first try. The durability of the parts has been outstanding as well, possibly because I was able to use shaving cream with it that protected face and shaver alike. I also like the cool gadget aspect of the design.
  656. [[VIDEOID:mo3RMHSRNYYYOWO]]Pros:<br /><br />* Closest shave of any electric shaver I've ever used in my entire life.<br />* Large, flexible head with multiple shaving foils is flexible and shaves my cheeks as closely as a straight blade does.<br />* Waterproof and very convenient to use in the shower.<br />* Easy to clean.<br /><br />Cons:<br /><br />* VERY expensive!<br />* Still can't beat a straight blade when it comes to shaving my neck.<br />* Large head with multiple shaving foils makes it hard to shave precisely, which makes this a bad shaver for shaping beards and sideburns.<br /><br />Conclusion:<br /><br />For the price, it should do a better job with the neck. Because it's the best electric shaver I've ever used, I will give it four stars, but it's far more economical to get a cheaper Panasonic and a straight blade.

  658. This is the best shaver I have ever owned. I have been a rotary head guy for years and hated that with my sparse and fine facial hair I spent more time ripping the hair out than cutting it. This unit has been a godsend. It cuts very close and does not tug or pull at all. I have also yet to feel any significant razor burn or have an blemish outbreak following.<br /><br />I would say for 90% of guys though, the Arc3 would do just as well. I find that most of the time at nearly every angle I rarely engage the 4th foil. That said, this shaver is awesome and at the price I paid it was worth the investment over the Arc3 if only for 3 hairs a swipe.<br /><br />I have not used it wet, nor do I really intend to, but if I do I will update. I am on my 5th shave and the battery is still at 60%, so for those light weight business travelers who want to leave the plug behind, you will be happy with the battery life of this unit. I would expect it to make it easily through a week long business trip without a charger.<br /><br />Also before you get discouraged, if you are a rotary guy going foil for the first time, as with most foil shavers be sure to vary the angle of approach to best match the angle of the hair. You may think it is not working well until you do.
  659. After using a blade (or 4) for over 35+ years, I decided to go electric. Best thing I ever did concerning shaving. I thought I couldn't get as close as a blade...WRONG. It will get as close as a blade. No skin irritation. I don't mind shaving (after a shower at night and then) again in the morning. The ES-LA93 comes with it's own bowl for cleaning & storage, but is it worth $100. more? For me no. I got a really good price from an Amazon dealer, so this one was even more attractive. It's a wet/dry shaver so I use shaving gel then shave. Very smooth. I'll use this until it dies. Then buy another. No more blades for me.
  660. First, I have a tough fast growing beard. So even with a blade I get a five o'clock shadow. For the past 10 years I have been shaving primarily with electric razors. My first was a high end Norelco and since I had nothing to compare it to I thought it was okay. Until recently I've relied on my Braun 8995 for about the last 4 years. It did a great job and along with the self-cleaning unit worked flawlessly until I accidentally knocked the shaver off the bathroom sink. By the way I did have a dinner shadow but also have a Braun M-70 that I used to clean up. TheM-70 is an incredible low end shaver that accept for being a bit tough on the face gives a great shave. That brings us to now. I thought about getting another Braun but they seem to have gone up in price and I wanted to move away from self-cleaning units. Not because they don't work but because I felt a littlel guilty using chemicals and having non-essential waste to discard. That brought me to the Panasonic LA-63. I charged it when I took it out of the box and tested all functions, shave, clean, sonic clean, lock and trimmer. All worked according to specifications. The shaver is big but quite comfortable in my hand. The head is big but I found it easy to manage all around my face becuase of the 360 mobility. I was pleasantly surprised how close the shave was. This was also the first electric shaver that did an adequate job on my neck and chin. I can't say it's as close as a blade but the differences aren't worth talking about. Comparing to a blade shave where you go with the grain, as recommended, the panasonic for me was as good, but comparing to a blade shave against the grain, which I had to do, the differences aren't that great with the blade winning by a hair. By the way when necessary I still use my M-70 for late day clean-ups. If this shaver is durable and lasts it's clearly the best I've had to date. Higly recommended. Don't pay $300, there are plenty of internet deals at half that price. At this cost the shaver is an excellent value even though it is not cheap.

  662. I bought this razor to replace my 5th Norelco Rotary shaver I have owned in the last 20+ years. I bought it after doing allot of research on electric shaver, both rotary & foil. Plus different brands: Norelco, Panasonic, Braun, Remington & such. The features of this razor far out number the other brands! The Wet/Dry Feature AND the Easy Cleaning are the things that most appealed to me. After using it for a few days I noticed it was a closer shave than a rotary style! It is much smoother (especially when shaving wet!) And did not leave bumps on my neck like I get with a rotary or a blade razor. I would have given it 5 stars if not for (2) things. #1) A stand would be nice (for when it's drying) i.e.: a cheap plastic one. #2) I still use a blade razor to leave a cleaner side-burn line. The razor will do it but 2 seconds with a blade leaves a cleaner line. Overall I would highly recommend this razor! But don't take my word on it; Do your Home Work & see it is a better choice over a Braun or Rotary Style like Norelco.
  663. Update 7/17/17; Update 12/1/12; original review 10/9/10. Update about 7 years later... I'm still using this razor, though I've changed the foil and blades a number of times. At this point the digital display is dead and the razor head is stained with soap/shaving cream that won't come off. But it still works, holds a charge for a long time, and gives a good shave. * * * 12/1/12 After two years I replaced this razor. Could you get more life out of it than two years? Definitely. Why did I replace it? 1. Mold, despite regular cleaning regime. * After about 18-20 months, this razor started to get black mold on/in the plastic under the foil cover, on the part of the razor where the blades are attached. This part of the razor is a light color plastic, so it could be easily seen. It does not rub off; it is in the plastic and like a stain. I should add this problem emerged even though I ALWAYS took off the foil cover, rinsed the foil cap and blade area of razor after use, and left the two parts out on the counter to dry. I can only imagine that not doing this cleaning routine (a quick rinse and putting it in a drawer) would leave one with a very moldy razor. * I tried cleaning the mold with a bleach solution, soap, and hydrogen peroxide. Helped but didn't get rid of it. I'm sure the mold was also within the razor in areas that I couldn't see. * I think this was mostly a cosmetic issue, but I didn't like the idea that there would be mold near shaving blades and my face. * If you have a black version of this razor you probably have the same thing happening, but you don't see it. It might be a good idea for everyone to give their wet razors a dunk in hydrogen peroxide or a bleach solution once in a while. 2. I upgraded to a model with a cleaning stand. * As noted below, I didn't really like that this razor didn't come with some kind of stand. I knew that I wouldn't put a wet thing in a drawer, and if I was going to leave it out on the counter, it felt like it should have a stand. * Because of the mold issue, I upgraded to a model that would have a stand and the cleaning function. I am hopeful that the cleaning function will eliminate the mold problem with my new Panasonic razor. * I will write a review of the new razor, but let me just say here that the stand is big, not very elegant, has very bright flashing lights (you won't want it near your bedroom at night), and very noisy for about 5-10 minutes (sounds like a train, and in a quiet room feels as loud, no joke-- my wife hates it). Summary-- Panasonic makes a great razor, but this mold issue was an unexpected disappointment. 10/9/10. This is an excellent shaver and I've switched happily and probably permanently from blade shaving, only wishing I had switched years ago. But years ago (say 15 to 20) I had used a few different rotary Braun and Norelco electric razors that didn't do a great job, and gave them up for blades. This one works differently, whether it is the ultrasonic or the blade style and motion, so if you think you have tried an electric shaver by trying only one kind, I've learned that you have to try all the different types. This one might be the one for you. I shaved for years with Mach III blades, but even using high quality shaving cream, I came to hate shaving, that knife on my face, which I have to do every day, with a dark beard. This razor give a close shave and it is painless. I continue to shave wet, with no difference than with my blade, and have had no irritation, even with the very first use (so don't be put off by that &#34;you have to get used to it&#34; warning). I actually look forward to shaving now, or at least don't mind it at all. Granted, I still have my Mach III handy, to clean up a few missed hairs, but I do not mind the &#34;extra step,&#34; since I get a closer shave than I ever have, and without pain and any cuts. (My routine includes Art of Shaving or Body Shop shaving cream, excellent products, a small amount of cream lathered on with a damp shaving brush.) Shaving is quick with this razor. Its rapid ultrasonic motion creates more lather when you use shaving cream, which makes the shaving even smoother. It takes a few minutes, and you don't have to worry about getting cut. Maybe you can get the same shave with one of the lower priced models, but I am so pleased with it that I don't resent the price. I sometimes wish that I had bought a model with a stand however.
  664. Decent product but it takes much longer to shave than bladed razors. For my face, it doesn't do a good job cutting all the stubble under my chin.

  682. I have owned 4 of these shavers (gave one to my son). The shave quality is superior to anything I have used in the past. No question it has one of the closest most comfortable shaves, virtually identical to triple or four blade razors. No nicks no cuts with this cordless shaver.<br /><br />Here's the beef I have. All 4 shavers experienced the exact same problems: 1. the LCD display goes haywire after about a year or so and... 2. the power button sticks and causes the razor to stay on despite attempts to turn it off. In addition, one razor experienced the LCD issue and when pressing the power button the shaver kept cycling between cleaning mode and shaving mode on its own. This shaver is not built to last.<br /><br />I really like the comfort and closeness of the shave. That is why I kept buying it even after all the issues. However, after the 4th one died I bought the Panasonic ES-LF51. I believe the problem with the ES-LA63 is that it is NOT waterproof (even though its a &#34;wet-dry&#34; shaver). The LCD is too cute and gives too much information (time shaving, battery level, other irrelevant data). That's why it fails over time. I just need battery level. Why do I care how long it takes me to shave?<br /><br />The Panasonic ES-LF51 is waterproof and still has the 4 blade technology. I have been using it for a little over a week and it yields the same close shave with a smaller shaving head. And the LCD only tells you battery level - perfect! Hopefully it lasts longer than the LA-63.
  683. I've stayed with rotary shavers all my adult life because many years ago I got a closer and less irritating shave with them. My last was a Norelco XL on which I had changed the blades once and was thinking it was time to do it again because it seemed to be getting harder to get a close shave, particularly on my upper lip, right under-the-nose area. First I looked at Norelco's newest and most artfully &#34;beautiful&#34; model but saw that the blades were now positioned farther from the edge than on the older models. That would make it even harder to get a close shave where I needed it most. So I ruled out a Norelco upgrade just using reasoning. With a shaver, function trumps art. I also noticed that my old Norelco's battery was needing recharging more frequently than it used to - maybe a sign that I'd have to replace it soon. That left me with the scary thought of going back to a non-rotary shaver and the daunting task of reviewing all the other shavers on the market.<br /><br />I decided to take a chance and try out this Panasonic, figuring I had 30 days in which to return it if I didn't like it. I chose it because (1) I don't like the idea of having a large black &#34;sterilizer stand&#34; out on the bathroom counter at all times, (2) it was cheaper, and (3) the bulk of the reviews were sufficiently convincing.<br /><br />After 1 full week am I happy with my decision? Absolutely thrilled! Since I'm so used to a rotary, the very first shave felt a little awkward but I saw that it shaved my upper lip area closer than I had seen it in a great many years. The blades get a little warm where it works hard on that area but it does not irritate one bit. Fantastic! The manual tells me my skin and I need some time to adapt to the new shaver action. I can't speak for my skin, but each day I find that my shaving technique improves as I learn what I need to do differently from when I used the rotary - something about learning which way the hairs grow in different facial areas so I can shave &#34;against the grain&#34;, so to speak. I'm catching on and taking a little less time each day - which reminds me that I love the timer readout. I never knew exactly how much time a shave takes, as if it matters, but it's an interesting bit of feedback to ponder while still half asleep. The other functions viewable on the blue lit screen are useful and cool. Best of all, I'm now getting the closest shaves I've ever had. As I develop more expertise in shaving my own face, I suspect that I'll start playing games trying to beat my speed record.<br /><br />On the down side, maybe only for me, I wish it came with a small stand to put it in after I rinse it off and some drops of water remain. I don't like laying it out loose on the countertop, so I stow it away in a drawer, but that's a problem if it's still wet. And the cleaning instructions and pictures are somewhat contradictory and vague. I'm not really stymied about how to clean the shaver, but it's not because of Panasonic's explanation. Overall, after just one week, I'm very pleased with its performance.

  698. It works great when my hair actually enters in to the grating at the top. But my facial hair lies flat and regardless of the direction I shave, most of it does not enter the grating and hence cannot be cut. Admittedly, it gives an extremely close shave to every hair that it actually does cut. But only like 40% of my hair gets cut on each pass. It takes like 30 passes to complete my shave. The head pivots nicely, but it doesn't fix the basic problem I have.<br /><br />I've had this problem with cheaper electric razors as well. I thought I'd give something more high-end a try, but it didn't work. I'll go back to using disposables. The Mach 5 is okay, but my current favorite is the Shick Xtreme 3.

Rather than paying to pay for a second set of foils and blades, I decided to upgrade to a better Panasonic model.<br /><br />This razor is absolutely fantastic. The ES-LA63-S shaves even closer than my old Panasonic (both of which shave closer than my last Braun). What's really amazing is how many more shaves I get from a single charge. With this new razor, I get 12 shaves from a single charge. Interestingly, it not because the ES-LA63-S has a longer battery life, it's because this new razor shaves so much faster. The multi-pivoting head and the 4-blade system really seem to make a difference.<br /><br />Pros:<br />Fantastically close shave<br />Displays the length of time for each shave<br />Very easy to clean<br />Shaves much faster than previous razors<br /><br />Cons:<br />None

Normally I charge about every two weeks and shaving time is 4 to 6 minutes each time. Great for sensitive skin. I order replacement blades about every six months. When shaver starts to get warm as I shave, this tells me blades are dulling down. Tried cheaper electric razor first and it did not shave as well.   721. I'm an electric shaver lover. In fact, you might call me slightly obsessed with the devices (i.e. I have several). I like the Panasonic ES-LA63-S Arc4 for a few solid reasons:<br />- it's light<br />- it's easy to clean<br />- it has a travel lock<br />- it provides a smooth, comfortable shave<br /><br />To clean the shaver, simply apply a little liquid hand soap to the head, give a long press on the &#34;On&#34; button to activate the Turbo Clean and run it under hot tap water. When the Turbo switches off (about 20 seconds) remove the head and continue running the tap water onto the head of the shaver and inside the removed head (about 10 more seconds). Then simply shake off the excess water and leave to dry on the counter (I usually put it on top of a face cloth to absorb the water). About once a week I will spray Shaver Saver (either from Remington or Norelco) on the shaver's head and run the shaver for about 20 seconds. This lubricates it and helps clean any mineral deposits from the tap water.<br /><br />The Panasonic is a linear shaver that runs at 14,000 rpm (the fastest in class). It uses stainless steel blades on a swivel head that can be locked if desired. There are four blades, hence the Arc4 designation. The handle is ergonomic and therefore easily held whether over the sink or in the shower. Yes, you can use this shaver dry OR wet. I do not shave in the shower but on occasion I will shave &#34;wet&#34; over the sink by applying some shaving cream to my face. The resulting shave is extremely close and comfortable.<br /><br />The only minor drawback is the size of the head which makes shaving the upper lip a bit cumbersome but certainly not impossible; it just requires a little patience. When we travel I always take the Panasonic with me since it is so easy to clean, light and has that travel lock.<br /><br />Really, you cannot go wrong with a Panasonic shaver. This one is very affordable and one of the best foil shavers available today.

  743. Very pleased and a little surprised by this razor. Have used Gillette 5 blade razors for years with complete satisfaction, but finally ran out of coupons and discounts. Tried Remmington King of Shaves to save some money. Those looked similar to the Gillette blades, but are not nearly as sharp after a couple of shaves.<br /><br />So, I'm camping for a few days on a military base and dreading the thought of shaving at 5:30 AM, in the dark, with cold water and my dull blades. I have a coarse, dark beard and wanted to look presentable amongst the clean-shaven soldiers at breakfast, but just couldn't bring myself to shave. Hearing the buzz of an electric razor reminded me that there were other options.<br /><br />I've tried electric razors in the past, but always given up after a month or two because I always ended up with a 5-oclock shadow. Tried Remmington, Braun, Norelco and Phillips over the years. With the pricey Brauns out now, I began to think that the electrics must be improved or folks wouldn't pay so much for them. After online research, the high reviews of the Panasonic Nanotech, I decided to give it a try.<br /><br />My only reservation about this shaver was the clunky looking head. I was drawn to the reviews about the close shave, wet or dry options and the charge indicator which shows percent of charge remaining. After using it for a month, I must say I'm extremely pleased. Shaves are close, comfortable and it doesn't get too hot or require a zillion passes to get a great shave. The pop-up trimmer is great for sideburns. The clunky looking head has a purpose, it pivots and eases shaving your lower jaw and neck. Didn't hurt that the pricing was less than the Braun and that cleaning is fast and easy with running water rather than cleaning solutions.<br /><br />If you're considering giving up blades, I'd highly recommend this shaver as an alternative.

  756. I have had 3 previous Panasonic wet/dry shavers. In general, the linear blade design is superior to others I have tried. This model is a disappointment. Shaver head is so wide that for the contoured part of the face, only 1 side is cutting. The center part of the shave head doesn't really do any shaving. This makes shaving take longer. After a couple months it is causing skin irritation. Battery life is also short. I get 4 maybe 5 shaves in 1 charge. I wish I could return it but I went over 30 days. I recommend the ES8103 or ES8109 models. Lower price, shaves in less time, gets just as close with no skin irritation.
  757. I am 47 years of age and been using a blade to shave for my entire life. However, when considering the cost of a package of 16 Gillette Mach 3 Razors (about $35), I have found myself shaving every other day just to save money on buying refills. Fortunately my face can tolerate a shave every other day without looking overly scruffy.<br /><br />...but I wanted that clean-shaved look day in and day out and figured that perhaps switching over to an electric razor may be a better alternative, saving me money on blade replacements in the long run. I would have never really considered going electric with the bad reputation such razors have had -- but I do think there have been great strides made in electric razor technology over the past decade. When I heard about the Panasonic Nanotech shaver in a radio commercial I decided to take a look at the many reviews posted here on Amazon. I was shocked at how much praise there was for this razor. I just had to try it out for myself.<br /><br />I didn't rush into this review. I knew that I had to give my face 3 weeks to adapt from blade to electric. So, I am giving you an assessment of the Panasonic ES-LA63 now three weeks post purchase where I have shaved just about every day since.<br /><br />My initial reaction to using the Panasonic Nanotech shaver is that it's extremely comfortable. Its wide head covers a lot of area and to date I have never felt any pulling of hairs whatsoever. No doubt, the experience of using an electric over a razor is more preferable as far as comfort and ease. You never need to press down hard with the electric shaver (in fact you shouldn't) and there is never the fear of cutting one's self (though I never regularly cut myself with the Gillette blade).<br /><br />I have used the Panasonic both wet and dry. I suppose I somewhat prefer to use it wet along with KING OF SHAVES ALPHA GEL which is sold here on Amazon and I HIGHLY recommend. A minute amount of gel goes a long way and really adds comfort to the shave. The only thing I noticed is that the shave seems to get better 5 minutes in as the skin and gel dries as there is more direct contact with the skin. In essence, I think the dry shave gets you closer but I do love the initial lubrication that the shaving gel provides.<br /><br />No doubt, this electric razor gives you a shave that is as close as a razor. I run my fingers across my cheek and it feels super smooth as if just shaved with a blade. That being said, the Panasonic doesn't do the job nearly as well across the entire area of the face and neck.<br /><br />Let me go back to the first day of using this razor so you can see how far I have progressed in three weeks....<br /><br />On my first day, I used this razor dry. I immediately got close, blade results across my face. However, I found patches of unshaved hair where the face curves right below the ears towards the neck. And the neck itself was a mess. I had to repeatedly run the Panasonic across these areas several times, pulling the skin tight in order to achieve the best results. My neck became red and bumpy from repeated passovers. Initial total shave time was more than 6 minutes.<br /><br />Three weeks later I would say the results have improved somewhat. I have gotten my shave time down to 5.5 minutes. I am getting more used to the problem areas that need more attention. I'm doing a better job getting the side curves of my face below the ear. However, I still have to put considerable effort into doing several passes to get small patches in the corners of my face.. The neck hasn't really improved with the exception that it doesn't nearly get as red and bumpy as it used to. I can get 90% of all the stubble off my neck but there is always small areas that the razor just won't cut and that I have to attend to with a dry blade.<br /><br />Ultimately, the problem with this electric razor is that you'll still need to use a quick dry blade to pass over areas of your face and neck to do the job perfectly.<br /><br />For instance, I have a goatee. The Panasonic ES-LA63 does a good job of trimming around the goatee even with its large head. I just turn it sideways and shave up and down along the goatee line. However, it doesn't do a good job of giving the goatee line definition. For that I have to follow up with a razor just to define the line.<br /><br />The Panasonic features a display which alerts you of remaining charge level and total shaving time. Unfortunately the display goes off once you start the shave but comes back on as soon as you turn the shaver off. There is supposedly an indicator letting you know when you need to clean the shaver. I have yet to reach that point yet. However, the Panasonic seems very easy to clean. I always remove the cover and run water through the foil and blades after every shave.<br /><br />I have been able to get about 6 6-minute shaves before the razor needs recharge. My immediate concern is how many charges this baby is going to continually allow me before the battery goes sour and it has to be replaced. I suppose if I get two years out of this Panasonic shaver before that happens I will have gotten my money's worth.<br /><br />CONCLUSION<br /><br />I love this Panasonic razor. I so much prefer using it over a blade. Even when it using it with gel and water I find it to be a much more satisfying shaving experience than using blade and water. Using it dry is even better because you don't have to deal with cleaning up the sink full of shaving cream and water.<br /><br />That being said, I find it hard to believe that anyone is having completely satisfactory results using an electric razor over a blade. Yes, the Panasonic does shave as close as a blade across the face. However, when it comes to the neck and lower sides of the face, you aren't going to see perfection. Even looking at my neck minutes after shaving, I see specks of hair all over the place that the razor just could not cut.<br /><br />Everyone's face is different so I suppose I am part of the unfortunate sect that are going to have difficulty with the neck area. Perhaps my face still has not completely adapted to the electric razor. However, judging by some of the reviews I have read I know that the neck area can be a real problem.<br /><br />Was this a good purchase? Absolutely. I love to shave with this thing. Just have to accept the fact that I have not rid myself of the blade completely. The Panasonic accomplishes 90% of the task but I still have to do a very quick dry swipe of the blade over certain areas of the neck.<br /><br />UPDATE: Now one week later (a full four weeks) I am seeing improved results in the neck area. Can it be? Is the Panasonic actually doing a good job on the neck? It seems so. I suppose the neck area took a little longer to adapt to an electic razor than the face area.<br /><br />I am convinced that I will never go back to a blade again. I love using an electric. For all of you who are making the switch from blade to motor, just give your face 3 weeks and your neck and additional week to adjust. It's amazing how close this baby shaves. Just hope this razor lasts at least 2 years.ee. The Panasonic ES-LA63 does a good job of trimming around the goatee even with its large head. I just turn it sideways and shave up and down along the goatee line. However, it doesn't do a good job of giving the goatee line definition. For that I have to follow up with a razor just to define the line. The Panasonic features a display which alerts you of remaining charge level and total shaving time. Unfortunately the display goes off once you start the shave but comes back on as soon as you turn the shaver off. There is supposedly an indicator letting you know when you need to clean the shaver. I have yet to reach that point yet. However, the Panasonic seems very easy to clean. I always remove the cover and run water through the foil and blades after every shave. I have been able to get about 6 6-minute shaves before the razor needs recharge. My immediate concern is how many charges this baby is going to continually allow me before the battery goes sour and it has to be replaced. I suppose if I get two years out of this Panasonic shaver before that happens I will have gotten my money's worth. CONCLUSION I love this Panasonic razor. I so much prefer using it over a blade. Even when it using it with gel and water I find it to be a much more satisfying shaving experience than using blade and water. Using it dry is even better because you don't have to deal with cleaning up the sink full of shaving cream and water. That being said, I find it hard to believe that anyone is having completely satisfactory results using an electric razor over a blade. Yes, the Panasonic does shave as close as a blade across the face. However, when it comes to the neck and lower sides of the face, you aren't going to see perfection. Even looking at my neck minutes after shaving, I see specks of hair all over the place that the razor just could not cut. Everyone's face is different so I suppose I am part of the unfortunate sect that are going to have difficulty with the neck area. Perhaps my face still has not completely adapted to the electric razor. However, judging by some of the reviews I have read I know that the neck area can be a real problem. Was this a good purchase? Absolutely. I love to shave with this thing. Just have to accept the fact that I have not rid myself of the blade completely. The Panasonic accomplishes 90% of the task but I still have to do a very quick dry swipe of the blade over certain areas of the neck. UPDATE: Now one week later (a full four weeks) I am seeing improved results in the neck area. Can it be? Is the Panasonic actually doing a good job on the neck? It seems so. I suppose the neck area took a little longer to adapt to an electic razor than the face area. I am convinced that I will never go back to a blade again. I love using an electric. For all of you who are making the switch from blade to motor, just give your face 3 weeks and your neck and additional week to adjust. It's amazing how close this baby shaves. Just hope this razor lasts at least 2 years.
  758. After reviewing all of the electric shavers on the market, I decided to buy the Panasonic ES-LA63. I was not disappointed. It met every feature that was claimed and gave me the closest, cleanest without any skin irritation. I admit it took a week for my skin to get used to the new shaver and get optimum performance, but I've never had a better shave. Thanks, Panasonic.
  759. Up until now I'd gotton by with a cheap electric shaver. When I noticed the ES-LA63 as a gold box special on amazon with a $30 mail in rebate it was too good of a deal to pass up. This shaver is amazing. It gives me a great shave even after not shaving for 3-4 days. It's motor powers through the thick chin hair without much of a problem. It does a preatty decent job on the neck as well, although like all electric shavers it requires multiple passes in multiple directions. It shaves really close and the LED display is a great touch as well. I only have used it to dry shave so I can't comment on how it works with cream or in the shower. I hope that the blades and foils last a long time because replacement ones aren't very cheap. I've used this product for ~2 months now. A+ Product!
  760. Very close shave. I have been using Norelco since when I started shaving, and was reluctant to try anything different. The Panasonic gives a much closer shave with less irritation. I feel much more comfortable shaving around the neck area with the Panasonic than my old shaver. The dual pivot head allows it to hug my face very well. And cleaning up is a breeze. I'd recommend it.
  761. I received the shaver about 2 months ago. The first shave was the best I've ever had. The ES-LA63 is a bit large in size than I'm used to but not overly so. I realy like the larger shaving head. Cleaning is very easy and a charge is quite fast. Best shaver I've purchased in the last 10 yrs.
  762. excellent shaver. 5-6minute comfortable & very close shave. works very well with shaver pre-shave oil. delivery to UK efficient. a real bargain.
  763. What can I say; Braun user since 1985; Have used 4 Braun models averaging 5-7 years each; prices have risen dramatically on Braun shavers (last model, $70 Walmart, entry price today about $130-$150 for a 5 series model). Also very anti- the cleaning/soaking base - more $ to lay out for something that a quick shake into the sink takes care of. Figured if I have to pay that much dough, I should be more shrewd and see the lay of the land. Have had good experiences with Panasonic phones and Plasma TV, so read reviews on Panasonic shavers, saw this model, took the plunge. A shave that used to take 4-5 minutes is over and done, closer and with less fanfare, in 2 minutes, dry. All while sipping bourbon with the other hand. Charges faster, lighter, great ergonomics. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
  764. After 2 years it still works great. Smooth and clean shave every time.
  765. A little bulky but I like it.

  769. This shaver exceeded my expectations. But I decided to give this a shot. I think it shaves closer than a blade in half the time. It is a snap to clean in water. Now I do not have to buy blades or foam or gel. It is also very quiet. The 14,000 rpm is what gives it the smooth shave. Really, I cannot gush enough about this Panasonic ES-LA63-S. Give it a try. You will not forget it.

  779. I bought this to replace my old razor and to try it out as a wet razor. It shaves very cleanly either wet or dry. I'm totally satisfied. As to the negative reviews about how easy it is to damage the cutters or the screen - I've had no problem. There is a plastic head cover which provides total protection. As long as it is in place the screens are protected from damage.<br /><br />It is annoying that the razor will not function when plugged in but it is what it is and not an issue as long as you don't totally discharge the unit. Simply looking at the indicator will tell you about how much charge is left so you don't really have any excuse for not charging it up before it goes dead!
  780. Prior to this shaver, I had used a Phillips 2D Sensotouch shaver. The main problem I had with this shaver was the irritation it caused especially on my neck - every shave cause my neck to turn red and sometimes caused cuts. So with my purchase of this Panasonic, I was really looking for something that was much gentler on my face. 1 year later, here are some pro's and con's of what I've found.<br /><br />Pros:<br />- Overall, the shaver is MUCH gentler on my face! Occasionally there are some problem spots on my face that require me going over the area a good number of times and this often causes a little irritation, but nothing as bad as with my previous shaver.<br />- The design of the shaver fits really well in my hand and is very comfortable to use!<br />- Travel case is pretty nice. It's not incredibly amazing, but it looks nice and seems pretty durable. Definitely handy when going on vacation.<br /><br />Cons:<br />- The mechanism used to open the trimmer is not at all easy to engage. Sometimes it works and sometimes it doesn't, seeming like it is locked in place. Not a huge issue for me, as I don't use it much, but it can be an inconvenience.<br />- The battery life for this shaver leaves much to be desired. Personally, I don't get more than about 4-5 days of usage before the battery is dead, which is less than my previous shavers. Not awful, but if you forget to bring the charger on a trip, you might be in trouble.
  781. Wonderful. Have to shave my disabled husband and it has been taking so long and the results were not good. With this one, it takes about 4 minutes and is the closest to shave with a manual razor we have had yet. Absolutely recommend this razor.
  782. This Shaver's LED screen does not work for more than a month. I was just sent a replacement shaver because the LED screen would not display meaningful data. From now on I may just use the $13 Panasonic travel shaver which gives as good a shave and doesn't pretend to have a LED screen.
  783. always used razors to shave in the past this Panasonic Electric shaver is great does an excellent job.
  784. Very quality electric shaver. I am very happy with what i bough :)
  785. You know, most of us men have to shave every day (unless we are retired, have a beard, or some disease that prevents facial hair), so one might as well have the cadallic on the market (or close). This shaver is not perfect; there are a few things that slightly bug me: first, the head is so big, it is difficult to get just under your nose with the shaver (but not impossible); second, it doesn't do all that well with a dry shave and I have had a couple of times of mild razor burn (when wet, that is never a problem). So, you wonder, why did I give it four stars? First, it really does shave well in the wet mode, almost all of your face, and it even does a good job on my neck area (most shavers I have used fail the neck test). You can use it wet or dry; I have always used a shaver dry, but I tried this one with water and shaving cream; it worked all right, maybe a tish better than dry shaving (and there is no chance of razor burn) Third, this unit is super easy to clean; you can put some suds on the foil, turn it on to turbo (just keep start button down for 20 seconds or less), and it will clean the unit. You can pop the head off and also use this cleaning feature. You can use water while you are cleaning it. It always comes out sparkling clean (and cleaning doesn't take but a few seconds). Some people moan about you can't shave with the shaver plugged in; you must have the shaver unplugged; this is a safety feature because you can shave with this unit in water (like in a shower or wherever), and Panasonic doesn't want you to get electrocuted. But they have a digital readout telling you how much juice is left. When you get down to around 20%, you just plug it in. When it gets charged (like under an hour), a green light flashes, telling you it is fully charged. Hey, it's great! I have used Braun for years, and I even tried a Remington (nice shave but very cheap units), so I graduated up to this unit. I hope to have this for many years without problems. So far, great product. I know this product isn't cheap, but at least you are getting quality for your money. It even feels like a well made unit in your hand. When you look at the inside (underneath the foil cover), you see metal and quality, not junk and cheapness. If any problems develop, I will come back to this review and comment. I have updated and altered my shaver review. After having it a couple of months, I am not as impressed; it doesn't really shave as well as my cheap Remington dry. Wet, it works well, but I prefer a dry shave as I like to look at the mirror when I shave. Yes, you can do that, but it is messy with water and soap everywhere.
  786. Great product. Shave is pretty deep and completely harmless. If anyone is looking to buy this I have an extra open box Panasonic ES-LA63-S Arc4 that is completely clean at a much lower price. (by student.sellers)<br /><br />http://www.amazon.com/gp/offer-listing/B00HHE44A4/ref=dp_olp_used?ie=UTF8&condition=used

  794. My old Braun Series 7 Shaver was getting rusty. Having read the Gizmodo reviews on shavers, I decided to try out different ones (taking advantage of various money back guarantees). I tried a Philips SensoTouch 3D model (all of their shavers in the same series perform the same way. Only differences are bundled products and maybe the finish of the product) initially. It felt very smooth, the shaver looked great and was quiet. But I could never get it to shave close, wet or dry. Braun Series 7 was on sale at Walmart, so I bought one and kept it in a box. Since I had Braun before, I knew how it performed. I wanted to try Panasonic, after reading mostly positive reviews. The shaver is great! It's the closest shave I've ever gotten. With either Braun or Philips, I would have grown 5 o'clock shadow by later in the afternoon. With this one, it's the next morning. But it doesn't look as sleek as the other models, and do not come with a stand, which is a bummer.<br /><br />Pros:<br />- Closest shave (compared to Braun or Philips) both wet and dry<br />- Very easy to clean (will save money, not buying those cleaning solutions, which is a must for Braun)<br />- Feels great in hand and nice carrying case too<br />- Affordable vs. comparable Braun or Philips<br /><br />Cons:<br />- Prices do fluctuate a lot, which few reviewers have already mentioned<br />- Silver model does not look as nice as Braun or Philips units<br />- No stand. It just lies on your bathroom counter.<br />- I've also had few nicks and cuts. Maybe it cuts too close.<br />- Only 30 day trial period - which wasn't big deal, because it cut close from day 1.<br /><br />Overall, very satisfied. Panasonic makes solid everything, it seems...

  796. Great shave, no Irritation, and EASY TO CLEAN<br />I have been shaving for > 25 years, and have had several shavers.<br />I was wary of Panasonic, they are not as well known as Braun.<br />My last was a $300 Braun 3 series, complete with the cleaning station, which does not work at all.<br />The major reason for purchasing Panasonic was VERY SIMPLE, it has a detachable foil from the Inner blades, and easy to clean either with a brush daily, or under the tap with some hand cleaning lotion.<br />other than that, the shave is easy, its like vacuuming your face ! a great shave, I only have to go round my face once, so no irritation to my neck like before with Braun.<br /><br />Braun Issues: This may sound illogical to some of you, but when you shave daily, and you simply cannot clean your shaver foil and blade, it gets blocked, blunt, and smells. Washing under the tap, and even the cleaning station do not work. I bought many of the brand new cleaning fluids for Braun and they don't work. I bought new $25 foil/blade combos every 3 months to fix the issue, which is expensive. The idea of a combo foil and blade does not work, and Braun need to rethink quickly as they have designed an inferior product.<br /><br />*** Feedback report now after several months of use<br />The Pana is just FANTASTIC. its like vacuuming your face ! And with the ability to take apart the foil from the blade and clean with a small brush after each use is HUGE. Braun made a real mistake in a combo blade/foil as you just cannot clean it. I LOVE my Pana.
  797. The shaver works fine, bettery than my old Norelco. Unfortunately the LCD screen died.In spite of this the shaver performs as expected.
  798. Bought this for my better half, and he is very happy with it. Says it is the best electric razor he's ever had.
  799. Every guy's face and beard are different, which makes reading and evaluating reviews difficult. I have the awesome combo of extraordinarily thick and tough whiskers with an incredibly sensitive face. Blade or electric, I can't shave everyday because it tears my face up (seriously). Even more fun, I'm more than a little OCD so when I shave I will grind and shave until my face and neck are *smooth*. So I need a shaver that can handle my stubble on two to three days of growth without destroying my face or being too painful. The Panasonic ES-LA63 was great! I only used it wet, and the large head (and it is large) was not a problem for me. I loved it! Totally five stars, even though it's true the battery life is not great and it is loud as a lawn mower, but I didn't care about that if I got the things I was looking for. Not only did I, but got as good a shave as with a blade with less pain and skin irritation. Then it started to crap out.<br /><br />When I bought this on Amazon, I had read about the LCD going out problem, and I found advice online on how to use and care for the shaver so that wouldn't happen. It happened anyway. Into my second year of use (early 2012) the LCD display went out. Okay, that was irritating but not a deal breaker. I would rate it three, maybe four stars at that point, because by then I basically knew how often I needed to charge it and that sort of thing. I didn't really *need* the LCD display, and it was still shaving Nirvana for me. But then a couple months later the shaver stopped holding a charge at all, at which point it became an expensive paper weight.<br /><br />If you want to gamble on the LCD/no-charge problem not happening to you, go for it. It's a great wet shaver when it's working. Just be advised that this could happen to you.
  800. The outer packing is like the old, damaged seriously, unlike new.shiping is rapidly,.I am very disappointed, because I was bought as a gift.
  801. It worked as well as my previous Panasonic razor. Only downside is the size of the head. A little large and clunky.
  802. There's a note inside the box that tells you that if it does not shave perfectly when you first get it, keep shaving with it for at least a month and your opinion will change. Well that happened to me and I was glad I kept with it for the month, as it seems to have adjusted somehow to my face/beard and now I regard this shave as the best I have ever owned.

  804. I have enjoyed using this razor for almost 2 years, using it as a &#34;pre-shave&#34; before I cleaned up with a regular blade. I usually use it in the shower, and it really does a surprisingly good job for an electric. I highly doubt any electric razor can get as close as a regular blade, but this is pretty darn good. The trimmer portion is fair, and really not all that useful to me. Battery life is good and the razor charges pretty quickly. VERY odd that the instructions actually say to THROW THE RAZOR AWAY if you lose or damage the charging cord... WHAT? No replacement? Bizarre. All that said, after not quite 2 years, the display has taken a dive. This is more than slightly annoying, especially in a razor in this price range. If it held up it would have gotten 4 stars easily.

  806. Shaves close and fast. Motor holds speed when the battery is low. Quiet motors. Much closer shave than my previous electric shaver.
  807. Very good, I like, thank you
  808. This is a gift for my friend, and I am not supposed to open it. But the package arrived to be intact.
  809. Not as good as expected. Does not have 4 blades as ads appear to claim.
  810. I'm only marginally satisfied with this product. I have a very light beard and most electric razors do a good job for me. I really have to work my neck over with this one to get a decent shave. Does great on cheeks, chin, mustache.
  811. I have used it for 9 months and it still gives a close shave. I shave with it after showering and have a dry face; I have not tried it wet. I give the shaving part a 5 star. The size of the head does not bother me, it took several days to adjust to the larger size. My trimmer is very hard to open; I can open it after several tries but my wife cannot open it. Also the trimmer does not trim as well as other Panasonic Razor's I have owned. I give the trimmer 3 star, so overall I give it a 4 star. I recommend it because it does give a very good close shave.
  812. Got this shaver for my dad for Christmas. It has a $30 coupon and ended up costing $97. For that price, it is very well built and my dad says he really likes it. He was a razor user his whole life and now in his 70's he found this to be much easier.
  813. I've loved using Panasonic wet/dry razors for over a decade. When it was time to retire my treasured Arc 3 shaver, I thought the extra blade with the Arc 4 would be even better, and the reviews all seemed to support this. It's a false premise.<br /><br />The extra blade makes for a massive shaving head that isn't ideal for shaving the curves of an average man's face.   815. I had an earlier version of a Panasonic shaver that was just OK, but I used it for three years or so with no problems, it just had a habit of not getting the hard-to-get hair on my neck area. When I decided to get a new one, I was planning to get an Architec (sp?) because they look so cool but after reading many user reviews, I changed my mind. My next idea was to get a top of the line Panasonic with the cleaning unit, but changed my mind there too because of not so great reviews about the cost of the cleaning system and the additional products needed and because i have limited space on my vanity area. I am SO happy I bought this one. The minute I started using it I could tell it was FAR superior to my previous shaver. It shaves my face in a flash, even the hard-to-reach areas! Really does a GREAT job! And it has a \\"turbo\\" setting to use to clean it with a little hand soap which I am sure will be more than adequate. I would highly recommend this shaver to anyone.
  816. I bought this shaver a month ago. The first time I used it I thought throw away my old electric shaver! I shave while showering and then I clean the shaver right there. So easy and no solutions to buy. I have had melagnoma on my face so it left a scar and this shaver works perfectly there. My old one took so long then it got warm. I told my brother about it and he loves his too. I love shampooing my whole face and shaving at the same time. I never did that before. I highly recommend it.
  817. Having owned at least 5 Panasonic shavers over the past 20 years, I thought this one would be the best shaving and most advanced shaver I have ever owned. It turned out to be a decent shaver but after only three weeks the trimmer got jammed and the game was over. It is now back at Panasonic for a replacement. While it was working, the blades were fine but no closer than the older less expensive shaver I had for 3 years. The top of the shaver is indeed bulky and a bit hard to hold. The screen for reading remaining power etc. is the best I have ever seen so that was a plus. The shaver lasted much longer than any previous shaver which is because of the newer battery design. Overall, a fine shaver Made in Japan, but this defect tells me that the design of the trimmer is complicated and may be prone to jamming. Overall, I am using my old shaver right now and I like it better than I ever did while I was using it every day!
  818. It's not as massive as some think. The narrow, but comfortable grip, makes the head seem big. Much quieter than my other shavers (Braun, Remington, Norelco). Clean, close and smooth shave. No pulling or irritation. Being able to rinse out the blades under the faucet is a plus. Very satisfied.
  819. Below is my initial review. However, I've now had this for over a year. I'm not sure I'll purchase another high end Panasonic, particularly if I intend to use it in the shower. My previous version had the electronics quit about every six months. I bought it from a store that let me return it, so it was a fair trade off to me. However, Amazon doesn't have such an extreme return policy, so when the electronics died after six months, I have to live with it. I sent the first one back to Panasonic and they replaced it, and the replacement died after six months as well and is no longer covered. Now mechanically it still works great, and the electronics on the ones I bought for my dad and uncle who don't use it wet are still going strong. However, a small part of why I paid so much for this razor were the electronics, and 6 months of use does not seem worth it. If you intend to use it dry, I'm sure you'll be very happy. But if you intend to use it in the shower, go for the cheapest Panasonic model you can get! Oh, and don't expect much sympathy from Panasonic, their customer support is not that great.<br /><br />**** old review ****<br />I recently bought this for my dad based on how much I love mine, which is the LA93 version, the only difference is the cleaning/charging base. This is the first electric razor I've owned that gives me the same feeling that I get when I shave with my Gillette Sensor (Braun Pulsonic Series 5 & 7, and Panasonic Arc 4 Nano I've owned previously). Don't get me wrong, electrics don't shave as close, and anyone who says different should be questioned. However, with every other razor (even the excellent Arc 4), I still feel some stubble when I run my hand over my face and head. This razor gets it so close that you barely feel that stubble. Add in the fact that you can take it in the shower and use shaving cream and you have an extremely comfortable shave. The design makes it look like it would be odd to hold, but in fact it's very comfortable. I'd say that it's a little awkward upside down on your head, but if you switch your grip it's not a problem.<br /><br />One other thing I'd say is that if you don't plan to keep the razor in the charger/cleaner every day, then buy this version and save the money. The cleaner for the Panasonic's doesn't really seem as effective as that for the Braun's. However they're much less expensive to run as they don't utilize the special alcohol based cleaning mixture. I will say that the cleaning cycle for it is much longer but not as noisy as the Braun's.comfortable. I'd say that it's a little awkward upside down on your head, but if you switch your grip it's not a problem.<br /><br />One other thing I'd say is that if you don't plan to keep the razor in the charger/cleaner every day, then buy this version and save the money. The cleaner for the Panasonic's doesn't really seem as effective as that for the Braun's. However they're much less expensive to run as they don't utilize the special alcohol based cleaning mixture. I will say that the cleaning cycle for it is much longer but not as noisy as the Braun's.
  820. I used a Braun (top of the line prior to the Pulsonic release) for 5 years prior to buying this model. It is really important to note that the transition period and process from blade (I was coming from Fusion) to electric is not to be underestimated. First few shaves with the Braun were absolutely brutal. It took forever to shave the neck in particular. For me, it required about 2 months of sticking with it (with numerous moments of intense doubt along the way) for my beard to make the transition. Once I successfully crossed over to the world of electric, I was very satisfied with the Braun. Just recently however the switch began to wear out. After much research I decided to give this Panasonic a try. First shave I tried dry and with results slightly better than the Braun. Second shave I tried wet using some lathered bar soap. Simply incredible. The closest, most comfortable shave I have ever experienced, period. I have a beard of medium thickness, so keep that in mind. I can grow a legit beard, just not something you might see on beard.com. For me, this model kicks the Braun to the curb, especially for the price. That is purely on performance, let alone the fact that cleaning is so simple. You really do not need a cleaning station with this shaver.

  836. I was going to buy the new lv61 or lv81 model that has 5 blades, but I just couldn't justify spending $400 more for an extra blade (5 blades versus 4). I'm glad I didn't because this is a fantastic shaver, and blows my prior Braun Pulsonic out of the water. If there is an improvement in Panasonic's new models, it's probably marginal, and I can certainly wait for the prices to come down. As someone who has to shave daily and used to feel like a cactus at night even after shaving in the morning, I think this shaver is amazing. I can use it dry or in the shower (I haven't noticed a big difference like other reviewers), and it gives me a shave that is super-close in only 5 minutes. Cleaning is VERY easy. All you have to do is remove the top cover, rinse it off under running water, and do the same with the blades. It has a cleaning mode that vibrates the blades faster for cleaning purposes. I was getting tired of spending $10-$20 every few months just to get replacement cartridges for my Braun Pulsonic cleaning system. Trust me -- it's a big waste of money, so don't bother spending an extra $80+ for the more expensive version that comes with one (the shavers themselves are identical except for color). All you will end up doing is spend more money every month or two for replacement cartridges. Like I said above -- it's so easy to clean under running water with the high speed cleaning mode. So, I highly recommend this shaver for anyone who has to shave daily, and doesn't want to spend a lot of time doing it every morning. It's the best shaver I've ever bought, and a fantastic value for the price (I paid $149.99). I will be paying attention to future reviews for the newer 5-blade version, but honestly -- why pay $400+ more for that when this does such a great job?
  837. I have been using this shaver for the last 6 months now and have been totally disappointed with it. The head is so large that it is very difficult to maneuver it over the contours of the face.   843. I was so excited to get this shaver. After reading all the reviews, I was sure this was going to do provide a (somewhat) close shave and not cut me up (a problem I've had with past electric shavers). I do, however, want to start with some positives. I know that my stars already provide my opinion about this product, but here's some great things:<br /><br />The LCD Battery Status: This was extremely helpful to see how much time I had left on a charge. It was incredibly accurate and shows the percentage of battery left. It also tells you how long you've been using it for that particular shave.<br /><br />The trimmer: Not sure what to call this, but the trimmer that sticks out the back is great for getting longer hair off so it doesn't get caught and pulled out, hurting you when you shave.<br /><br />Cleaning: I felt like cleaning this was very easy to take apart, wash, and sit to dry. I've had shavers that I can't get all the hair out, or they get messed up when I do try to rinse it. This never had that problem. Truly waterproof.<br /><br />So, what I didn't like was when I actually shaved with the normal head. I will admit, I never tried to use shaving cream, and I kind of regret not giving that a go after seeing that that is what most people had the most success with. HOWEVER, this is supposed to shave dry no problem. That is not the case.<br /><br />When I would try a dry shave, it would still cut my skin and leave me feeling very uncomfortable. It also left a lot of hair behind, meaning it was not a close shave AT ALL. It simply didn't get all that I needed it to, making it take forever to finally get a good shave. I understand now that I should have used shaving cream, but I was under the impression when I bought it that it was not entirely needed. Again, a little misleading.<br /><br />Also, my BIGGEST qualm is that the outer foil broke on me. What do I mean? It started chipping away to the point that if I tried shaving the metal would cut my skin, meaning I can't use this anymore until I get more outer foil. Now, it doesn't matter what you paid for this, though most say how expensive it is. I was hoping to get at least 6 (but wanting 12) months out of this before I had to replace the foil. Instead, after 1 month I can't use this anymore. New foil here on Amazon is $60, meaning I'm in over $200 already on this razor. I'm scared to even buy new foil if this happens again. Very, very disappointed and frustrated.<br /><br />I contacted Panasonic and let them know how quickly the foil broke on me and was hoping they'd understand that this shouldn't happen after only a month's use. I didn't want a refund on the shaver, but hoping for another foil to see if I was maybe shaving too hard (which I doubt). They told me that it's disposable material that breaks down, so it's not covered under warranty. I do understand that, and don't blame them. Still, it's frustrating that I bought this shaver and can't use it after a month.<br /><br />Just a thought: Avoid shaving dry with this. I really think it's bad for the foil and doesn't provide a good shave for the price. Once I get more foil and some shaving cream, I will possibly update this. I was going to give a 3/5, but I just don't think it's fair that this has never happened to me before with an electric shaver and I've always shaved dry. I understand if that's not how it should be done, but I've never been told or shown otherwise.<br /><br />I really hope this helps people make an informed decision and to use this correctly. Again, maybe I didn't use it as it should have, but I don't think that was the problem.
  844. My old ES4026's battery was not holding it's charge anymore and after getting my son a cheap Remington 5800, I started to look into getting myself a new razor. My ES4026 wasn't good with a full days worth of growth, but to clean up after a regular razor or for a small amount of growth, it really got close and smooth. After much research and the fact that a cheap Remington did a pretty good job, I was so excited to get this LA63 figuring it would be amazing. Well, it does whip thru a days worth of growth pretty well, but that's pretty much it. It does a terrible job on my chin and especially under my jaw bone area and neck. I've been using it for the recommended 8 weeks or so and I've tried dry shaves, wet shaves, shaving creams, soap, and pre-shave lotions. All with the same crap result. Now if I want a close shave, I finish up with a bic razor or grab the old ES4026. Also, it says you can use in the shower but a few days after trying that, the led screen went out. So much for that. The head is bulky so it's hard to get under the nose area and back of the jaw line. Next time I'll stick with the three foil type or go to the Brawn. In fact, my son is home from college so I tried the Remington again and it had no problem getting my neck and chin area close. Now I'm kicking myself for not just getting one of those.

I put it back together and it wont work anymore. I took it apart a few more times trying to make it work, but I guess there is something about taking it apart that it doesn't like. I was surprised to see an an electronic circuit board in there. Anyways about the shaver.<br /><br />This is a very good shaver, you can shave on it every day for a couple years before changing the blade and foil set. I never had a problem with the batteries on any of these. I've had 2 of these. I just bought one to replace one that I've had about 2-3 years. I've had another high RPM Panasonic shaver before this for many years, I had it long enough to change the blades a couple times. The batteries and motors just keep running and running and running. I was looking for an excuse to buy a newer higher RPM one like this, but it kept going and going and going. When it came time to change the blades for the third time I decided to just buy a newer one with higher RPMs like this one. My very first Panasonic shaver which was over 10 years ago also lasted a few years of daily use. I just bought a new one when the blades finally went bad. But the first one was a regular speed shaver, it wasn't high RPM like this.<br /><br />These days I shave about 4 times a week and it will last me about a month before needing to recharge it.<br />I can shave about 14-18 times with this before needing to charge it. If the battery is dead and you need a quick shave you can shave with this while it is plugged in, or you can just charge it for 5 minutes and you will have plenty of power to get a full shave, probably 2-3 shaves.<br /><br />I never timed it, but it will charge from empty to fully charged in about 45 minutes. When I took it apart I seen that it was a round battery that was about 3 inches long. It had some custom pins on the ends of them, I guess to hold it in securely.<br /><br />Since I just got this new about a month ago I know it will be good for at least 2-3 years before it will need new blades or foil. I would expect this to last at least 4-5 years minimum before needing to look for a new one. By then new shavers will probably have Bluetooth or WiFi and some apps or something, who knows.

We paid around $260 for the other shaver and I paid $100 for this shaver. If you were to compare the shavers the more expensive one (Panasonic ES-LV61-A) is obviously with out a doubt a better shaver. It took me around 5 minutes to shave my face smooth with this shaver which was around the same amount of time it took to shave with the other shaver. You can notice that you may have to take multiple passes depending on the way your hair grows and how thick or thin your hair is.<br /><br />Overall for $100 dollars it is an excellent shaver. We both used to have Braun shavers (their highest tier shaver) and also used to use the cleaning kit and always having to buy the cleaners. Honestly, using the more expensive shaver and now starting to use this one daily there is no difference between running water and cleaning everything out vs using the Braun or Panasonic expensive cleaning kit.<br /><br />I hope this helps someone and I believe this shaver is worth at least $200 dollars or less. You get what you pay for and if you purchase this one or spend the extra money for their more expensive shaver you will see what I am talking about after using it a few times.<br /><br />Cheers!
