  861. I’ve used several other electric shaver brands over the years (Remington, Norelco), most recently an old Braun that seemed to work best, but I thought I’d try the Panasonic when I got an email from Amazon about a sale price (and saw the consumer ratings). My first shave was good, but didn’t seem enough of an improvement to me to warrant keeping it instead of replacing the head on my Braun again. But by my third shave with it my wife and I were convinced--if you are careful to pull your skin back and move against the grain it really gives a very close shave without needing much pressure or many repeat passes. I couldn’t duplicate this close a shave with the Braun no matter how I tried--and my wife agrees even with a new head the Braun never did as good a job. It also seems to catch all the odd hairs very well, even close to the nose. The higher pitched noise of the motor surprised me, I liked the quieter, lower old Braun sound, but I think it may be a sign of more speed and power and in any event I got used to it quickly.
  862. Works great and very clean cut. Easy to clean just by running it under water.
  863. This razor works as expected and guess it could really be 5 stars but it is difficult for me to get real excited about a razor. It does what I expected and have tried using it wet, dry and with shaving cream and all is well. Glad it didn't cost any more than it did.
  864. Works excellent. I have sensitive skin and I don't get a rash using it. It is quick and works well wet or dry.
  865. Best cordless electric shaver I've ever had.
  866. a gift for my father. He said it shaves pretty clear
  867. Husband loves the razor!
  868. The thing about this razor that I had a hard time with was its size. It is large and a bit unwieldy in the hand and the general feel is awkward. Not very ergonomic and more like holding a hammer than a razor. And because the blade surface is surrounded by so much material, it is hard to know exactly where the blades are shaving. Would definitely not recommend if you are using this on your face and have any facial hair, such as a mustache or even sideburns that you want to get neatly around. This shaver doesn't allow for much accuracy in trimming around a mustache or near sideburns. As someone who normally shaves with a blade, but likes to have an electric just to do a quick 'trim' for going out, on weekends or when I'm in a hurry, I found this unit to be too much of a hassle to use. I could spend 20 minutes trying to shave with this and still have hairs sticking out around my mouth or on my chin. I got this to replace an older Norelco triple header, which I loved, but couldn't find blades for anymore. The Norelco never gave me razor burn or irritation but this one does. For an angular face like mine, a regular blade gives a much better and cleaner shave, especially around the chin area and on my neck.
  869. Product arrived very promptly and as described. Very happy with vendor.
  870. This is a great shaver. Years ago I used a Remington screen shaver but started having a lot of ingrown hairs. I switched over to multi blade had shavers but ended up with some kind of skin irritation likely connected to rosacea. A friend recommended this to me and I'm been pleasantly surprised. I only use it as a dry shaver so cannot attest to the wet shaving experience..
  871. When I got into wet shaving using DE (double edge razor blades) an straight razors I never abandoned my love for a good electric.<br /><br />My favorite electric for 35 years have been by Braun and the top of the line series 7 have proved to be the best razors of this type I've ever owned. That said I had great hopes for this Panny and had read great reviews both on and off Amazon - so I gave it a try.<br /><br />Because I'm also a head shaver, how the head foils float and move is essential for a decent shave. When it comes to getting a great shave on the old melon the Braun and my Norelco Senor-Touch 3D do an exceptional job.<br /><br />Electric razors are a highly personal item, so much of it is purely subjective what works beautifully for one can be torture to another. Skin sensitivity, elasticity, beard density, frequency, bone structure - all come into place.<br /><br />All considered I really wanted to like this razor and gave it a good three weeks to earn it's stripes. But ended up returning it. In my case the razor has some fatal flaws.<br /><br />1) The head is far to big making shaving under the nose and above the upper lip near impossible.<br /><br />2) The double motor does make for a powerful razor but it also heats up the head fairly quickly and was without question the loudest electric I've ever used.<br /><br />These are minor complaints and I could have easily gotten used to them. However the design of the ARC razors is in my opinion pretty terrible. For say, head shaving, because of the high arch in the center of the foils you're only making minimal contact of foil to skin of about an inch.<br /><br />You can rock the razor side to side to cover more territory but this puts the foil at an odd angle and made it prime for hair pulling and razor burn. Not to mention it was extremely uncomfortable.<br /><br />To be fair this razor, like most all electrics was never promoted or touted as a head shaver. I was forcing the design by Panasonic to perform an application it just wasn't constructed to do. And although some electrics are excellent at shaving the dome - this is the last one you would want to use for that purpose.<br /><br />For the face and neck, the razor did a marginal job at best. Again, I fault the ARC design. It requires to much pressure and although the massive 4 foil head pivots with ease - if I have to spend this much time working with angles I would rather lather up and use a straight blade.<br /><br />In fairness, it did do quite a good job on my face right out of the box, but the neck area seemed impossible to get smooth - and I would eventually end up going over the same area with my Braun to get rid of any stubble.<br /><br />Without question there are many guys who love the ARC line. Panny does make a Linear line of razors without the ARC and perhaps I'll take one for a test drive one of these days.application it just wasn't constructed to do. And although some electrics are excellent at shaving the dome - this is the last one you would want to use for that purpose.<br /><br />For the face and neck, the razor did a marginal job at best. Again, I fault the ARC design. It requires to much pressure and although the massive 4 foil head pivots with ease - if I have to spend this much time working with angles I would rather lather up and use a straight blade.<br /><br />In fairness, it did do quite a good job on my face right out of the box, but the neck area seemed impossible to get smooth - and I would eventually end up going over the same area with my Braun to get rid of any stubble.<br /><br />Without question there are many guys who love the ARC line. Panny does make a Linear line of razors without the ARC and perhaps I'll take one for a test drive one of these days.

  876. This is a precision instrument, well made, worth the Amazon price. The shave is much better than my (old) rotary by far: smoother, closer, easier, less irritation, no razor bumps. The battery doesn't last as long as my old rotary, but enough for a trip of a week or more. It is a cinch to clean, though that is not often necessary. One complaint only: there is no stand, it has to lie flat on my shelf; that takes up room, especially when it's disassembled for drying. But I've dealt with that, too. Highly recommended.

  887. My trusty Braun shaver was starting to get a bit long in the tooth so I decided to see where modern electric shaving was at.<br /><br />Picked up the [[ASIN:B002N5MHLU Panasonic ES-LA63-S Men's 4-Blade (Arc 4) Multi-Flex Dual-Motor Wet/Dry Rechargeable Electric Shaver with Nanotech Blades, Silver]] (the model names are so confusing) and now find myself being drawn to the bathroom because I just want to keep shaving with it. I'd actually forgotten what a close shave felt like.<br /><br />I have non-sensitive skin with a course, dark growth. The Panasonic glides through it all with balletic grace.<br /><br />I was curious about how the size of the shaver head would affect its dynamics around my face - it turned out to be no trouble and effectively probes into the difficult neck, under nose and upper sideburn areas.<br /><br />Dry shaving gives you a close shave. Wet shaving gives you a blade-like closeness - beautifully smooth.<br /><br />I've experimented with a wet face covered with shaving oil. While this gives a close shave, the oil combines with the shavings and clogs the close-set blades. Simply washing the face, rinsing and leaving wet works fine without any additional lubricant.<br /><br />Cleaning the blades as per the supplied instructions works well (essentially holding under running water with a bit of hand-soap applied to the foil). I tend to leave the foil cover off and leave to dry above a heating vent.<br /><br />Highly recommended - eroding the reputation of babies' bottoms everywhere.

  901. I've had this shaver for 2 months now so I saw it fit to write a quick review. It says in the manual that you should give about a month for it to get used to your facial hair without using any other shaver and it should give you the best results thereafter (considering that return time is 30 days, not very ideal but let's go ahead with it anyways). So I use it once a week and what I have seen is that it doesn't shave everything. It shaves the parts above my chin (top part of my facial hair) very well and very smooth if i go over most spots 2-3 times and there are no irritations or redness. I can do this 3 ways: dry shave (neither machine nor face is dampened), could do it wet (either in shower or by dampening one or both), or using a shaving cream along with the machine although this doesnt seem necessary and usually tends to cause little bleeding in certain spots so i just recommend using it dry or wet without shaving cream). Results are pretty similar, at least for me for all 3 methods though. So the top part is an easy and fast shave (faster than using a razor) with different options. The parts on the neck though (below the chin) are a pain. It gets only some of it. Whichever of the 3 methods I use, none of them allow me to shave everything on the neck parts. On top of that, going over 2-3 times on the neck can cause redness (but not irritation) and also minimal bleeding and will take u a while to get things close to right (but it will never be fully right). I've tried the shave with little to a lot facial hair but I never get good results on the neck part so I gotta use my gillette fusion power razor to get the rest (I don't wanna do that though since I bought these to avoid buying $30 cartridges for the razor). I do know these electric shavers (even worse ones) work for some ppl perfectly fine though so I guess it really depends on the type of hair you have - thin or thick, little or a lot, etc. I guess another plus is that it's easy to clean and takes 30 seconds to a minute after each shave. Overall, for me its worth 3 stars because although it looks and feels like a quality product, since it doesn't shave off everything on my face, it takes longer to shave now and is a little annoying. But the overall shave is better since it gets rid of most hair and causes no irritation. And even using the razor after doesnt cause irritation really because i have little work left with it. But for what it does for me, its a little pricey cuz i still have to keep buying razor cartridges, i just replace them less often now...

  920. This review will address a DRY SHAVE ONLY as I've never used this product for a wet shave. I purchased it to replace a Braun 7505 that I'd had for years. I have a thick beard and was hoping this model would reduce the shaving time I had with my Braun. I was disappointed. After using it for a month I'm sorry to say it takes me longer to shave with the Panasonic. At a $300 MSRP that's just not acceptable (I got it on sale for $150).<br /><br />For men with lighter beards this razor may work just fine, but I still think it's overpriced. My sense is that you're paying for bells and whistles you don't really need: e.g. the detailed display with battery life and cleaning notification. Also, the head is quite large. It's fine on my cheeks but not so good on my upper lip, chin and neck. Also, the trimmer is smaller than on Braun shavers and it's difficult to deploy it. I have to push quite hard to get it to pop up.<br /><br />I just purchased a new Braun 380s for half the price of the Panasonic ES-LA63 and it outperforms the Panasonic. Again, every man's beard is different, but from my experience this razor is overpriced and overrated. I'm sticking with Braun.

  926. This is my third Panasonic shaver, and easily the best. Aside from the bulkier head of the Arc 4, I have no reservations saying this is a vast improvement over my old Arc 3. It glides much easier and I only have to make a couple of passes to get to smooth skin. Still, of all the electric shavers I've ever used, from Norelco to Braun, Panasonic has always been hands down my favorite. Hence, this being my third one.<br /><br />I don't mind not having the cleaning station. I don't have the counter space, and having owned a few shavers in the past that included them, I find it to be more of a nuisance than anything. The cartridges and the filters and the noise. Soap and water does just as well.
  927. As a long-user of older, similar-style Panasonic razors, I've been very unhappy with this one since I started with it. I've given it a 3-week trial now (long enough for my skin to &#34;adjust&#34;) and continue to have the same issues. I have 2 main problems with it:<br /><br />1. The shave: when I shave dry (as I did with my previous Panasonic), the thing doesnt give a very close shave. If I press down a little harder, I cut myself or get that surface &#34;burn&#34; kind of cut that oozes blood a little bit. When I shave wet (with water and shaving cream), it really cuts me deep. This has been my main issue, and hasn't gotten any better with time.<br /><br />2. The head on this thing is HUGE. Makes it very difficult to shave your upper lip and in the curves of your neck.<br /><br />Overall, I've found this thing to be extremely disappointing and do not recommend it for the price.
  928. Did not give a close shave. Expected more from the wet shave but this was not very good either. If you are seeking a close shave buy another razor.
  929. My old Panasonic gave a better closer shave. Sent it Back.
  930. I've used electric shavers for 50+ years. I've tried several models from all the major brands. This is the best yet. I get the closest, most comfortable shaves I ever have. It's not cheap, but as as an Amazon Gold Box special it was nicely discounted. Great shaver, super deal!
  931. It shaves good but not as close as Norelco lift and cut shaver which I am replacing.<br />Does not get the hair on my neck, have to press hard to get them.
  932. Husband loves it. No more nicks, face is nice and smooth. Shaves while watching the news. Makes a great gift.
  933. Great gift for my friend! Great price for me! Great tool for my friend!<br />My friend said he loves it very much!
  934. This is the best electric razor I have ever owned. KUDOS TO PANASONIC!!! Before this razor I was using a Braun (admittedly an older model) which did an okay job. But back to my Panasonic ES-LA63-S razor. The shaves I am getting from this razor are second to none! They are as good as the best blades on the market today. And, that was right out of the box. No waiting 30 days as the owners manual suggests to get the best results. Due to the newness and unfamiliar shape of this razor, it did take a few days for my hands to familiarize themselves and get the right feel on holding and handling it but, now it is USER FRIENDLY!
  935. I bought a smaller, cheaper Panasonic shaver 2 years ago. Just when I needed to buy a new head for it, and was wishing I had bought a more expensive model, Amazon cleverly send me a notice that this one was on sale! The new head would have been about $30, and this was just $100, so I sprung for the extra $70 and now own one of these.<br /><br />Like the earlier Panasonic that I've owned, it's a very rugged machine. It's completely sealed, so you can shave in the shower, although I don't. But you can also clean it by removing the head and running it under a running faucet, which works great. This one has a larger shaving head than my previous one, so it shaves more quickly. It also swivels nicely to track your face, making shaving easier.<br /><br />You can't shave while it's charging, but in 5 minutes it'll charge enough to shave you, so that's not really a disadvantage. It has a gauge so that you can see how much charge is left. I don't take the charger when I go away for just a weekend--I've never come close to using all the charge.<br /><br />It comes with a nice case that protects it well. I wish the case also held the charger, for those longer trips. But it doesn't.<br /><br />Another nice feature is the lock on the power switch. When you turn it on, you can lock it on so that it won't turn off while you're shaving if you happen to bump it. Also, when you're traevling, and if like me you may not have brought your charger, lock the power switch in the off position so that your luggage doesn't turn it on and discharge it!<br /><br />Overall, I think this is a terrific product at a reasonable price.
  936. Very quiet, fast, and really hugs the curves of your face well. Works dry, with shave gel or foam for a close, comfortable shave with NO RAZOR BURN, no matter what you may be shaving.
  937. I have had two older models both with the linear motor. I have the es-la63, BTW the es-la93 is the same shaver plus the Vortex stand (plus display extras for the cleaner). Great product. Note the Braun as well as the older Panasonic's do not incorporate a convex arc in the foil shape. I think this is a key feature here.<br /><br />The shaver is much more usable without the \\"foil frame\\" where the black foil \\"carrier\\" is exposed. This way the shaver is much easier to get closer under the nose and easier to see what you are doing.<br /><br />Just remove the foil frame then remove the foil carrier from the frame. The foil is not reversible so note the orientation, the lone hair cutter goes toward the trimmer. Then snap the carrier (only) back on the shaver.<br /><br />But what to do about securing the cap? I made an elastic \\"chin strap\\" to hold the cap on. Using one of those hair bands with a hole (3/16 drill bit BY HAND) where each release tab \\"bulge\\" is. The \\"chin\\" being that area under the pivot. Just knot the band on the outside of the cover just like you would for a hat strap. Also if you cut the, now unnecessary, corners with a pair of dykes the cap goes on easier.<br /><br /> For the longer and stubborn neck hairs use the trimmer but drag it up your neck (upside down) with the foil facing down. This shaver now is a Five Star!<br /><br />I thought the blank display while shaving was an oversight but if it showed the time I would check it often and slow my shave time.
  938. There is so much to love about this razor,my last razor was a Panasonic ES7109 that i thought<br />was a pretty good preformer but the ES-LA63-S is better in every way from the 4-blade cutting<br />system to the shaving head that will move up and down and side to side to follow the contours<br />from the neck up to the face and 14,000 cycles per minute cutting rate that results in a close stright razor like shave!
  939. I got this for my husband, who shaves his face and head every day. Every few months he needs a new razor. Here's a hot tip: find the most recent model, then find the most recently retired model - that's the best deal!

  946. I have not used an electric shaver since the mid-1980's. When I was in college, I used a blade, had a decent Trac-II compatible razor, and stuck with it for decades. However I have found myself cutting my face more and more lately, so I thought I would give an electric another shot. I read reviews and found this one to be the best bang for the buck.<br /><br />Overall, I am very happy with this shaver.<br /><br />From what I have read, there are good and bad aspects to all of these products. The bad that I read didn't seem so bad, and people liked the shave they got, which is why I went for this one. There may be better ones out there - I don't know where one goes to &#34;try out&#34; electric shavers.<br /><br />What I like:<br />- Shave is close, albeit not as close as a blade, but apparently it never is with an electric.<br />- Wet/Dry compatible. I thought I would be shaving in the shower. After a few weeks, I am more comfortable shaving before I get in the shower, so wet/dry is not as important, but still getting it wet is not something I have to worry about. Also helps with my next point:<br />- Can be cleaned simply by taking the foil off and running under water. Very simple, and no bulky stand, outlet required, cleaning solutions or cartridges to replace.<br /><br />What I don't like:<br />- Takes longer than I thought it would to shave. This may not be any better with any other electrics, though. I have to go over my face on multiple angles to get a close shave. It probably takes just as long with a blade, and I had to go up and down that way too, but I thought the process would be quicker.<br />- It will not handle multiple days growth. The first time I tried it out, I had 3 days worth of growth and it took a LONG time and many passes to get it all. Even then, there were definitely spots where I noticed afterwards that I had missed. Granted, this was the first time I used it, and perhaps I would have a better idea of how to tackle that kindof beard with this thing now that I have used it for a month, but I'm sure it would not be my usual 3-4 minute shave. This is another issue that I would not be surprised to be the case with ANY electric shaver.<br /><br />Battery life is worth mentioning. They say it will last 45 minutes, which is definitely top end. I would estimate it at more like 30. It tells you how long it has been on each time you turn it off, so I know I'm using it for 3-4 minutes a shave, and I won't get 10 shaves out of it. This does not bother me very much, as I shave with a blade on Monday morning, then use the electric Tuesday through Friday, then plug it in, but I definitely think it is worth pointing out to maintain buyer expectations.<br /><br />Having not tried another electric shaver in the past 28 years, I don't know how this compares to others, but I would be very comfortable recommending this to a friend.
  947. The closest shave in my experience with electric razors that included my Braun and Norelco. The shave is right up there with old fashion blade shaving. I have only used this as a dry razor in the first couple of months. I was a little concerned how close of a shave that I would get under my nose with such a large head on the razor. It hasn't been an issue at all. It's also very good about keeping the whiskers/stubble contained in the razor. My Braun would sprinkle whiskers everywhere despite cleaning it every day. I only clean this Panasonic 1 time a week. Easy. The battery lasts about 10 shaves or so which is the longest of any razor that I used. The noise level is acceptable. I have been loyal to Braun but this Panasonic has converted me. Try it and you will believe too.
  948. I recently purchased a 8103s (another panasonic shaver) and was extremely impressed by the quality of the product considering the price. I was so impressed that I wanted to upgrade to a better shaver (it didn't get the hairs under my neck however), so thanks to panasonic's liberal return policy, I went for a more expensive and higher spec model: the esla63s.<br /><br />This is an amazing razor. I shave my head daily, as well as my face, and when used wet, it cuts close, comfortable, with no irritation or cuts- period. Now, the best part is that it actually cuts the hairs on my neck, which like most men, tend to be the most sensitive spots, as well as the thickest hairs. It cuts them close, not perfectly, but damn close- i'd venture to say closer than with the grain. Now, everywhere else on my face is just as close as close as shaving against the grain. Unless you stretch the skin, you really couldn't tell the difference.<br /><br />For head shaving: The razor cuts through the hair effortlessly. The biggest advantage that this shaver has is that: 1.) the head swivels in all directions, and 2.) the shaving head is larger allowing for a better indication of when all the blades are touching the skin. The 14,000 rpm motor is a big upgrade over the 13,000 motors, and the second motor in the razor head does dramatically help the shaver get hairs that earlier models miss.<br /><br />I wouldn't go with a dry shaver ever, nor would I waste my money on a cleaning stand. Just use Dawn, antibacterial soap, in a coffee cup with slightly warm water to clean the shaver. The cleaning cartridges from panasonic are basically just that anyway. As far as the comparing it to the Braun 790- the esla63 wins in terms of specifications hands down, has one more blade, and can be used wet- plus it's cheaper.<br /><br />It won't cause razor bumps, because it cuts the hair the same way a straight razor does, at skin level, without an angled cut. This makes it perfect for sensitive skin, individuals who get break outs, as well as those with curly hair. I couldn't recommend it enough. It's worth the price.
  949. The LCD display broke after only owning this product for three months. While the shaver performs well, it's pretty ridiculous considering the price I paid for this to happen. Do not recommend at all!
  950.   951. Best electric shaver by far!
  952. I have been using the shaver for about two and half years. This is the best electric shaver I have ever used, but the LCD display has a problem. It breaks down every 4 or 5 months although the saver works fine. I called Panasonic Customer service and they told me to send it for repairs. I did not send it for repairs because I heard that they do not actually repair your shaver but send you another refurbished shaver, which I think is a very unhygienic practice. I have found a simple solution to fix the problem - open the razor, remove the battery and let it dry overnight and then reassemble it. It fixes the LCD display. I think either overcharging, using it after the battery level is at 10% or moisture causes the LCD display to break down, although I never found any moisture inside the shaver. I do not understand why Panasonic cannot fix this simple problem. Except for the LCD issue I would have rated it 5 stars.
  953. Keep your blades, you'll need them. The Panasonic LA63-S like many other highly-touted electric razors does not shave nearly as close as a Schick Hydro blade or the popular Gillette Fusion and much less satisfactory than a good double edge. I have used, in over 45 years of shaving, razors from Braun, Norelco, and Remington. All, including this one, exhibit certain features that claim a better shave and and they all do what they claim...simply, they cut whiskers. Where they all fail is in the closeness of the shave. If you're not too concerned with feeling stubble a couple hours after using the Panasonic, or any other electric regardless of cost, electrics may be appropriate for you.<br /><br />The LA63-S is probably one of the better shavers with decent build quality, easy claning, and without the extra burden of cleaning stations, liquids, etc.<br /><br />Is it worth it? Yes, provided you understand it is not a substitute for a blade.
  954. I have had at least 10 different Panasonic wet/dry shavers over the past many years.This one is the best yet. Here's why: 1. Virtually no vibration against skin when in use 2. Swivel head is better designed than on their previous shavers; this one actually follows the contours of one's face instead of moving all over the place 3. Quiet 4. Faster shave time, due to increased CPMs to 14K 5. Ultra smooth shave. The other Panasonic wet/drys were great, but this one approaches the closeness of a straight edge. It was worth paying for the upgrade and the ES8103S Arc3 I was using still works fine. I use a Gillette five blade power glide razor on my face and neck (shave down) and then shave with the wet/dry. This is the only way, regardless of electric razor, for me to get a close shave. My skin is too sensitive to shave up on my face with a blade. 6. Long time between charges. I can go 3 weeks without recharging. Including cleaning mode after shaving, I probably use it between 1.5 - 2 mins/shave (shaving with a blade first helps reduce the time I spend with the electric, I'm sure).

  977. I've been using electric shavers over thirty years and this is the first one I've used that is efficient enough so that I don't have to occasionally shave with a blade.<br />Most of us who have used electric shavers know that there are usually one or two areas that the shaver tends to overlook, usually at the neck line. Over the course of a few days, it really starts to show and you then have to break out the razor to clean up.<br />Thanks to the super high motor speed and extremely well made blade assembly, I haven't had to.<br />It's also the fastest shave I've had.   980. I changed over to Panasonic after using Philips Norelco Arcitec for 5 years. Here are the results<br />Pros - more power, faster, bigger coverage area and reaches trick ares without much hassle. Does not pull hair, better trimming blade. Charges faster. Cost half.<br />Cons - Less battery life than Philips, the cut hair does not completely remain in the collecting chamber and end up sprinkling all over the face.   981. History:<br /><br />I used electric razors when I first started shaving. Then I went back-and-forth between wet/blade shaving and electric razors. Then I tried a couple of the various 'wet shave' electric razors about 7-10 years ago, my experience was awful (lots of irritation, poor shaves, difficult to clean). My facial hair is fairly coarse and thick.<br /><br />So I was doing the Gillette 5-blade cartridge wet-shave for many years, and that was okay...not great since the cartridges are quite expensive, but the shaves were okay, and didn't irritate my skin THAT much, I could get a few shaves out of each cartridge.<br /><br />Then, about 6 months ago I got intrigued with all this new elitist &#34;old-timey badger hair brush, double-edged safety blade shave&#34; trend that has become quite popular, with people claiming that this old method actually yields the best shaves. With all of the videos on You Tube showing big, burly guys with the thickest stubble imaginable shaving their face after bragging about their badger hair shave brushes and fancy blade holders, I was all but convinced that I'd get the best shave that way. Wrong...I tried many razors, many creams, soaps, gels, methods, etc., and I couldn't get a shave that was EVEN as close and comfortable as when I was using the Gillette cartridge razors. Sure, double-edged blades ARE cheaper, but my face couldn't have cared less about that fact...even after 3 weeks of double-edge razor shaving, the irritation never subsided. Not to mention that shaving took a frickin' LONG TIME between foaming a soap with the brush, applying the soap with the brush, shaving, and then having to go over areas again because the single safety blade didn't seem to shave adequately closeclose at all...<br /><br />My experience with this razor:<br /><br />So, feeling discouraged that I'd find a comfortable, easy shave at all, I started looking up wet-shave electric razors, and came across this Panasonic ES-LA63-S Arc 4. I shave wet (with a shave gel) with it, and it gives me the absolute BEST shave I've ever had, and even when I have 2 days of stubble, shaving with it is easy and the gel provides an excellent reduction in friction. Even with a couple days stubble, I can finish a wet/gel shave in 5 minutes. The shave is closer than almost any shave I've ever had, and I don't notice any irritation/discomfort with this razor; doesn't even seem like my face had to 'adjust' to the razor, which is uncommon when changing shave methods.<br /><br />Pros:<br />-Easy, comfortable, and FAST wet (gel) shave<br />-Comfortable to hold, nice weight<br />-Easy to disassemble and clean<br /><br />Cons:<br />-Doesn't last a million years on a single charge<br /><br />Seems like reviews complain about two things with this razor: The short battery life, and the fact that the razor won't operate while the charging cord is plugged in (i.e., if it runs out of battery while shaving, you can't plug in the cord and continue shaving). First, with the short battery life (~50 min), I don't have too much of a problem with that. I can usually finish a shave after 5 minutes of use, so I can typically get at least a week of shaves from the razor. And plugging the razor in for ~5 minutes yields enough charge to get at least a shave in (from completely dying). Regarding the fact that the razor won't operate with the charging cord plugged in: this is because the razor is designed to operate wet (in the shower/bath)--OF COURSE it shouldn't be operated with an electrical cord under wet conditions, so that feature is disabled due to safety.
  982. I gave it a rating of 2 stars because it grabs individual hairs and yanks them out -- quite painful. They urge you to use it for a month before returning it but I can't put up with in yanking out hairs for a month to see if it will quit.<br /><br />I do like the way you clean it. It is more convenient than my previous Norelco. But, I liked the way the Norelco shaved better even if you don't count the pulling out hairs which it would also do after the blades got dull
  983. I like shaving variety; therefore, I will use an electric razor for a while and then a regular razor/shaving cream a while. Most of the time it will be electric due to the sheer convenience of not having to use shaving cream and continuously rinsing the razor in the lavatory. My experience with electric razors has been Norelco and Remington early on, then Braun for the longest time but never a Panasonic until now. I liked the reviews I was reading on the ES-LA63-S Arc 4 and due to the age of my Braun and the high costs to maintain it and keep it clean, I ordered one. I read information about allowing time to pass to allow you and your new razor to become accustomed to one another. I knew the second day I was holding in my hand something I liked. I think I learned enough tricks over the years using an electric shaver that my break-in time would be predictably short. I already knew that too much pressure on the shaver against the face caused the shaver to get uncomfortably hot. Likewise, I was &#34;up on&#34; shaving against, with the grain, and across the grain to get an all around close shave.<br /><br />Only the Braun's shave resembles the Panasonic's but in my opinion is not as good, nor is the Panasonic as heavy. I did have to train myself to hold this shaver correctly with my thumb above the power button to avoid cutting it off at unwanted times. Complaints I have read in other reviews concerning poor battery life are not what I am experiencing as I will get about 6 shaves per charge shaving once daily. I appreciate the fact it will not run connected to the power cord, which was not an oversight on Panasonic's part but a planned safety feature because you can use it while you are in the shower. If charging only 5 minutes gets you your next shave, you shouldn't need to plug it in while in the bathroom except to recharge it and then for an hour. Bottom line, I already know I like this shaver and have your good reviews to thank for purchasing it. The least I can do is try to furnish a review to those who buy later a reason to do so. I may shave with gel or shaving cream in the future but it will only be out of curiosity as I am getting a very smooth, close shave dry. Money well spent and I highly recommend it!
  984. I ordered this after seeing it being sold in the Gold Box deals. This is the first time I am using an electric shaver and I must say I don't find it very useful. The shape of the head is such that it does not reach to every point on the face easily. It also takes much longer to shave with this as compared to my older shaver. The battery is also disappointing. While the manual and product description says 45 mins of battery time, in my experience it does not last more than 25 mins and that is barely enough for 3 shaves since average shave time is also on higher side. Overall, I won't recommend this product for its price.
  985. I absolutely love this shaver! It shaves as close as a razor, it has a comfortable &#34;bulk&#34; to it, and is VERY easy to clean. The replacement screen and blades are inexpensive on Amazon (screen every year and blades every 2 years). I use it as a wet shaver which makes it a bit more messy but I feel it's worthwhile as it makes the experience very comfortable. I am currently using canned Neutrogena shave cream but I'm eager to try Dollar Shave Club's Shave Butter (I used this when I was using a razor and absolutely loved it). Your skin will need a few weeks to adjust to this shaver but that's to be expected. You will not regret this purchase!
  986. Due to my sensitive skin I could only shave once a week. After some serious research I decided to give this product a try. This coupled with the Lectric Pre-Shave has changed my shaving life. I am able to shave every other day and that is an amazing feeling. Before this I have been using the Gillette Mach 4 coupled with Proraso sensitive skin shaving lather, pre shave balm, and post shave cream. I am even able to run my razor over my face after the initial shave with the Panasonic if I want to tighten up that smooth feeling.<br /><br />If you have sensitive skin preventing you from shaving with any regularity then this is the shaver for you!!
  987. This is my first electric shaver EVER! And I must say I am very pleased. It takes a while to get used to but once you get the hang of it you'll be shaving quick and efficiently. I bought this because shaving with razors really hurts my skin and makes me break out. Thankfully this shaver does not cause problems for me. At first the after feeling was odd but you get used to it and its no big deal. I didn't have any problems with the unit charging slow like some people reported, and the charges hold fairly well. I really have no complaints. Give it a go y'all!

  991. Have had it for about a month and still getting used to it ... haven't yet found the perfect &#34;lubricant&#34;. But am very pleased with the package overall. Gives a nice, clean finish with very little effort. Doesn't last a full 18 hours like the blade did, but a quick &#34;touch-up&#34; shave for a night out is an easy fix. I changed from blade shaving because sun-induced skin lesions were being exacerbated by the blade. The ES-LA63-S has been much more skin-friendly.   992. I have been using an electric shaver for about 3 years, since I got tired of bleeding like a stuck pig every time I used my Mach3, and paying $40-50 for new blades every few months. I got a Panasonic ES7037 wet/dry for only 20 from the Egg place. I liked it better than the razor, but it took 8-10 minutes of going over and over each area, pressing harder, pulling skin- a real chore. It worked slightly better in the shower, but still took a while, and wasn't all that close a shave.<br /><br />I got an e-mail from Panasonic, who were selling this shaver for 105 just before Xmas. It was 131 on Amazon, but then a 30 dollars off coupon magically appeared, and I pulled the trigger. Really glad I did. I charged this baby up (it came 40% charged and took only a half-hour to hit 100), glanced at the \\"manual\\" and hit the On switch. 2:49 later my face was smooth as silk. Being used to the long rough shaves with the 7037, this was like going from a Lada to a Lexus.<br /><br />The features are fine. I don't really care how long I've been shaving, but battery remaining (in 10% increments) is handy. It beats 3 little blinking LED lights. It charges fast. The locking head is nice: I mostly use it in the locked position, as I find that works better for me. The large size of the head is not a problem, as some reviewers have stated. I have a relatively small face, and have no trouble shaving my upper lip at all. Manual cleaning is quick and easy, I just rinse and dry, and only use the soap & turbo cleaning every other time. It's very low maintenance. I actually bought new blades for the 7037 once, but it did not seem to make any difference in its performance. I don't think $50 for new blades and a foil (if needed) every 2-3 years is all that bad.<br /><br />I can't speak to the longevity of this shaver, or its water-resistance, as some have noted the LED display winking out. I use it dry, and try not to let any water get near the LED screen during cleaning. And it is no noisier than the older electric I had, only much higher pitched. But I have it turned on for about 1/3 the time. I am extremely happy with this shaver, glad I bought it (at a reasonable price), and would highly recommend it to any man inclined to electric shaving. There is always an adjustment period going from razors to electric, but going from an older, cheaper, electric as I did, this was a huge upgrade.the older electric I had, only much higher pitched. But I have it turned on for about 1/3 the time. I am extremely happy with this shaver, glad I bought it (at a reasonable price), and would highly recommend it to any man inclined to electric shaving. There is always an adjustment period going from razors to electric, but going from an older, cheaper, electric as I did, this was a huge upgrade.

  1005. I've had this product in my hand for less than 24 hours, and as for the product itself, it seems fine. But dear shopper, let me warn you of a caveat emptor: Panasonic customer service. It's abysmal. Firstly, they ask you to register your 2 year manufacturer warranty either online or via mailing in a warranty card. This being 2014 and all, I opted to go to their website. They ask you for the serial #. Then their form tells you that the only serial # on the damn device doesn't have enough characters (needs 9 - 11 digits or \\"blank\\") but the serial # on the shaver they sent me is only 7 digits long (and no, I am not confusing it with the model #). Do I leave it blank and then have my service denied when something goes wrong? To find out what to do, I call the 1-800 number listed on the warranty registration card. I wait for 25 minutes to talk to a human being, except the person who answers tells me she is at the audio products department and will have to connect me over to the shaver dept. 35 minutes later, I'm still on hold (annoyingly enough, a message came on 30 min ago informing me that my \\"wait time should be less than one minute\\" --- yeah right! ). I can't imagine what a headache it would be actually getting this obscenely customer-hostile bureaucracy that can't even provide the correct phone # on the product literature that comes in the damn shaver box to file a warranty claim, but rest assured, any warranty or promise of service from Panasonic is purely theoretical. If this thing breaks, be expected to spend easily the purchase price in your pain and hassle before even getting to talk to a human being about what is wrong with your shaver.

  1030. Dear Panasonic: I am returning my Model ES-LA63-S for replacement. As you see by the accompanying receipt, I purchased this shaver on December 11, 2013. I purchased it as a birthday gift to myself to replace the Panasonic ES4283A that I purchased on August 31, 2012, which was a replacement for the Panasonic ES8103S I purchased on December 31, 2009 as a replacement for the Panasonic ES8243A purchased on April 15, 2009. This last was a replacement for the ES8152NC I bought on July 13, 2006. In fact, I bought three of these, including two for my sons. My purchase history goes back further, but you get the picture. Why you may wonder have I acquired so many Panasonic shavers over so short a time. There are five main reasons: 1) The close shaves they give are unparalleled. 2) I like to shave in the shower, thus all of the models I have bought are wet/dry. 3) The motors have never failed, although one or two of the recent ones have at times wheezed as though out of breath. 4) The blades last for a reasonable time. 5) The displays do not last. What happens to the displays? There is an assortment of failures that begin as small quirks such as a missing diode in a number--for example a 5 may display without its top so that it appears as an upside down question mark--to complete failure, which is the case with the one I am returning. Until this most recent purchase, I convinced myself that I had just been unlucky with the displays. However the one on this razor began to fail after only two months and like the others the severity of its failure progressed. The failures were tolerable at first and through the years I had become accustomed to Panasonic's kludge digitals, so I overlooked them. But then one day everything displayed--blade change, wash, charge, and the time readouts went haywire. Recharging brought new variations on this failure. And then nothing at all displayed. So, having invested many hundreds of dollars in Panasonic wet/dry razors, the displays on all of which have failed, I decided to return this very expensive one (I also still have its two predecessors if you would like them). Thanks, Terry Gilliam PS Within a week of returning this razor for repair, I received a new one to replace the old. 6/27/2015 update: Nearly seven months after receiving it, the replacement is still giving the usual great shaves and the display is working perfectly. I've added a star to my original review. If it lasts a year, I'll add another. 7/5/2016 update: Well, it didn't last a year. The replacement failed within a month of my June 27 update. The good news is that Panasonic replaced its replacement shaver with another new one. The unfortunate news is it failed as well. Throughout, the issue has been the same. The display goes haywire in 4-6 months. When I returned the latest replacement I was given this lesson: &#34;Our warranty covers two years from the date of original purchase or 90 days from the latest replacement date. Your two-year warranty has run out and so has the 90 days.&#34; What really rubbed me the wrong way was that several weeks after sending in the shaver I had heard nothing from Panasonic, so I had to call them to find out status and to get the aforementioned lecture. When I asked about repairing my shaver, I was told &#34;It wouldn't really be worth it; we recommend buying a new one.&#34; I will. But it won't be a Panasonic. It seems the product reliability and the manufacturer's 90-day warranty are well matched. I've changed my rating to match my experience with the product and manufacturer.

  1052. Let me first say that I have very particular skin when it comes to shaving. This may be a great razor for most men but it was terrible for me. I did a good deal of research when I was choosing an electric razor since I was switching from a blade with the hopes that it would be easier on my face (I asked several people, inculding dermatologists, who all said electrics were easier on skin). I was willing to spend some money since I would be using this so often (I shave about three to four days out of the week).<br /><br />Let me also disclose that I have very thick, and dark facial hair. That being said, not only did this razor not get as close as a balde, it left PATCHES of hair all over my neck and chin. AND, my face broke out terribly! Yes, I seemed to have an alergic reaction to this thing! I gave it two weeks, hoping my skin just needed to get used to it, but it only got worse.<br /><br />This may be a great razor for most but if you have sensitive skin, razor bumps, or any other sort of complication this may only make things worse for you.

  1056. It was time to let my Braun electric shaver go. It was getting old and loud, wouldn't hold a charge past a day or two, and wasn't cutting well. I started doing research about a new Braun shaver, but was reluctantly open to other brands. While reading reviews on electric shavers on Amazon, this product caught my eye. It had a large number of reviews and, more importantly, it had a large number of positive reviews so I bought it. Thank you to all the people who posted in-depth and thoughtful reviews especially those comparing different brands/models, which I read and considered before making my purchase. I've had this shaver for under a week and it is simply the best electric shaver I've ever had in 25+ years of using an electric shaver. Amazing: it works both wet (with water plus a shaving cream/gel/foam) or dry like most other electric shavers. I've been using it with a shaving gel and it works great. I can shave my entire face in much less time than I ever could with my Braun -- I'm done in a matter of minutes. I get a much closer shave than I ever had using an electric shaver. The sound of the device (a whine akin to a dental cleaning tool) isn't too bad at all. It isn't perfect on hard to reach spots on the neck or under the nose, but that's no big deal given the other benefits. So... so far, so good. Very good!
  1057. My husband says it shaves very close and he loves it.

  1064. I don't have the thickest of facial hair and only shave maybe once every 4-5 days, so I can't say how it will work for those with extreme facial hair. I also only do dry shaves, and have found nearly no irritation after use.<br /><br />The trimmer on the side is really nice too, I use it for sideburns, which it effortlessly glides through.
  1065. So far so good. I've had the shaver for about three weeks now and haven't had to recharge yet (averaging about 3-4 shaves per week). Really close and effortless shave. Haven't had to clean it yet so can't comment on that.
  1066. I wasn't expecting a much better shave than my Braun was giving me. I had settled for a mediocre shaving experience and didn't think this would be much different but received it as a gift so I gave it a trial. As it turns out, this is one of the best shavers I've used in a long time. I know it takes time to get accustomed to most shavers but this one felt good and provided a great shave from day one, which was about 3 weeks ago. I can only expect the shaves to get better as time passes. I had been using a Braun Series 7 790cc which is around twice the price but no where near twice better. As a matter of fact the Panasonic ES-LA63 gives me a better shaving experience than the Braun (the whole cleaning system hype is not worth the extra $). The ES-LA63 is easy to use. Easy to clean. Extremely comfortable to hold and glides across my face like no other shaver. One of the best things about this shaver is that it shaves my neck and jaw line without having to go back and forth a million times like I always have had to do. A wonderful surprise of a shaver that I highly recommend.
  1067. I have tried it twice since its arrival. First one as dry shaving and second one as wet shaving.   1068. Pro's - 1) Gives a good shave, 2) A wonderfully high speed and strong motor. 3) It handles long hairs better than I expected.<br /><br />Con's - 1) Big and bulky head that takes getting use to (I've learned to 'pull' the razor, instead of 'push' it.), 2) battery doesn't have as much shaving capacity as previous razors I've owned. 3) Small trimmer.. but works well<br /><br />I've always used 'low end', single-shaving-screen, razors and typically enjoyed them until they totally wore out (not that I EVER enjoyed shaving!).<br /><br /> After my old 'all-time FAVORITE' Panasonic ES-SA40 (no longer produced!) was dropped on it's screen onto a tile floor (No replacement parts) I started looking for a replacement, as the battery was dying after almost 6 years of continuous use, any way,<br /><br />A purchased a Braun Series 1 190S. What a pathetic waste of money (I'd used Braun successfully in the past). The motor was SO WEAK, it would literally bog to a stop on my chin and mustache whiskers! The screen was much more irritating to the skin than the Panasonic also. After less than 10 shaves I gave it away. It's probably in the land-fill now. This new ES-LAY63-S Arc 4 doesn't even know there IS a 'load' on my chin/mustache whiskers! I love it!<br /><br />*Sorry for the rant* I purchased this Razor for much cheaper than normally advertised, as it was on sale and also there was another discount that applied. I still paid 3x more than any other razor in my life (I'm 69)... but it's a keeper. Maybe it'll last until I won't need one any more! :)

  1081. I love panasonic razors.. but the problem with this version is the blades I bought are not sharp, unlike the past ones that had a great close shave. This is my 3rd one in 4 years
  1082. Back in the day, Victor Kiam, who owned Remington, used to advertise his microscreen shavers on TV with the slogan \\"Shaves as close as a blade, or your money back!\\". Back when I bought one, some twenty years ago, well, lets just say if people really held him to his guarantee, his company would have gone bankrupt very quickly.<br /><br />Advance forward to the present - since then I've owned a Braun, one of the earlier Panasonic wet/dry's (ES762), one of the earlier Braun self-cleaning models (5709), the Panasonic ES-8043 with the 13,000 RPM motor, and now with this model I'm on my third Panasonic. The ES-8043 completely blew all of the previous models I've owned straight out of the water. The motor was the biggest difference - very fast, and it would just keep going, not slowing down until the battery was actually fully discharged - unlike earlier models where it would slow appreciably after the first few minutes of shaving. The other big difference was the shaving head tilting side to side. Previous models I'd owned had fixed heads, or heads that pivotied forward or backwards. I found the side-to-side pivot on the ES8043 to be much more helpful. The one downside to the ES-8043 was the narrow pop-out trimmer, much narrower than on earlier models - well fitted for sideburns, but more time consuming for removing longer hairs on the neck. Still, this shaver did such a good job I found myself rarely needing the trimmer with it.<br /><br />Now enter the ES-LA63-S. Panasonic has done themselves one better. The motor is even slightly faster than the ES8043. The head now pivots both side to side and forwards and backwards (superb!). The trimmer is still narrow, and now its a little bit harder to engage (the head needs to be straight so that it can be locked, and the trimmer then can pop-up), but I need it even less than before.<br /><br />One thing about this model is that the shaving head is HUGE. I thought this would hinder me, but it hasn't been a problem atall. Its not difficult to manuever in the tight areas, such as in the area between the upper lip and the nose. I think the shaving head pivoting in every direction really compensates for the larger size when it comes to the tight areas.<br /><br />Once again the motor just goes and goes, and does not slow down until the battery is dead - indicated with plenty of warning by the bright blue illuminated display. I have not had a problem with the battery life - the only thing I can say is that I think the charge indicator on the display is calibrated incorrectly, or intentionally made to error on the side of getting you to recharge the shaver sooner. I intentionally ran it down until the batter died. The display shows the charge status in 10% increments. I noticed that in the 20-100% range, the indicated charge goes down by 10% every 4-5 minutes. But I was able to run the shaver for 15-20 minutes more once 10% was indicated. The motor did now slow at all until the very end, when it slowed down over the last 3 or 4 seconds before shutting off completely. I wonder if other reviewers who have complained about battery life have let it run down all the way, or are just basing their beliefs that the battery doesn't last as long as claimed without letting it run down all the way, instead deciding its time to recharge when the indicator says 10%?<br /><br />Cleaning it is very easy. Rub a little soap on the foils, and turn the shaver on in cleaning mode (hold down the power button until the motor shifts to the ultra-fast speed) while running it under warm water from the shower or faucet. Remove the foils, and run it in cleaning mode again for 20 seconds under the shower or faucet to clean the inner blades. As of now I've had the shaver 3 weeks, and doing this after every use I've got it spotlessly clean - absolutely no shaving residue on the foils or around the inner blades at all. This same shaver is available for more money with a cleaning station. At first I wondered if it was worth the extra money to buy that model, but there is also the ongoing added expense of buying the cleaning solution from Panasonic, and this shaver is pretty easy to clean manually with a pretty minimal effort. So I would say get whichever version floats your boat, but know you won't go wrong with this model<br /><br />As for the actual shave, I've used it both wet with shaving gel, and dry, and it is astoundingly good for an electric. Every part of my face is shaved closer than before with the ES-8043. I really can get that \\"as close as a blade\\" shave over most of my face - I'm not kidding, I cannot tell the difference between what this does to much of my face versus what I get with a Gillette Mach 3 blade - well, except for the difference that my face is not irritated with the Panasonic and with the Gillette it often is. The traditional trouble spots for me (corners of the jaw, neck) are not quite as good, but they're much better than I got even with the ES8043. Overall, I am very very pleased.<br /><br />Right now, this \\"4 bladed\\" series of Panasonics are not the latest model. There's an newer, more expensive series with 5 bladed shaving heads. I haven't tried them, and I can't imagine they're any worse. But if they're really any better than this model, I'd say Panasonic has pulled off a miracle, because I can't really imagine an electric working any better than this.
  1083. If you are like me, in the morning I am stumbling around in search of my coffee and trying to do the things I need to before I am off to work. Shaving is a pain in the you-know-what. So this was my motivation for buying the Arc4. I received this electric shaver and plugged it in, in an hour it was charged. (I am used to waiting 12 hours.) I have thin skin and a medium beard. This shaver did a great job out of the gate. I was surprised that I felt no pulling or cutting. Just the whir of the blades. Although I have just gotten this, I am really happy with it. My shave left few if any whiskers remaining, and my time to shave was nothing compared to using a razor and shaving cream. Admittedly, using the razor gives a little closer shave, but this is plenty close for me ! Great buy.<br />1/16 Update: I have owned this for a year now and I am even more happier with it ! I started using Williams Lectric shave lotion and this electric razor shaves as close as a blade ! I am super happy with this product.

  1109. I actually liked this shaver and it gave the closest shave I've gotten from an electric shaver. Unfortunately, it had two design flaws.<br /><br />The first flaw, and most important, was the spring mechanism is part of the shaver itself, unlike my previous Braun shaver where the spring is part of the replaceable blade. Also, there is only a small plastic piece that holds that spring mechanism in place in the Panasonic. During cleaning, I will remove the blade and the last time I did it, the plastic piece had broken off and the spring flew off. I found the spring but there was no way it would stay in place without the plastic piece which made this shaver useless - without the spring, there's nothing to push the blade up against the screen. I took off two stars for this.<br /><br />The other flaw is, you cannot use this shaver while it's charging and the battery life isn't that long. The shaver is light in weight so I don't know why they wouldn't put a larger battery in it, especially since you can't use it while charging. But I still don't understand why you can't use it while it's charging. I took off a star for this.<br /><br />I'm not affiliated with Braun, but since that's what I was using before, I'm back to it. At least it works. I never had a spring fly off of it, and even if it did, I would only be out the blade part (which should be regularly replaced anyway) and not the whole shaver.

  1120. The Arc series of wet and dry shavers from Panasonic are the performing that I have ever used. I strongly recommend them. The foils and cutters usually last 4-6 months. I use a liquid hand soap in the ultra vibrate mode to clean the heads. Works great.
  1121. I got this for myself for Christmas after looking at the overall reviews for many different shavers. My last shaver was a German brand that was also highly rated but turned out to be a bit of a disappointment.<br /><br />I charged this up as directed when I opened it the day after Christmas. So far, almost 3 weeks later and after daily shaving I am still working on that initial charge. I am at 40% remaining power and the motor seems to run as it did when fully charged. I cleaned it a couple of times under water as directed and found it comes out like new. I tried to shave in the shower a couple of times but did not care for it much. The shave was close enough but after shaving for more than a half century dry it is too different.<br /><br />I like the way this holds in your hand. It seems quite natural and the pop up trimmer works just fine for my needs. As long as the quality holds out I think I will be enjoying this razor for many more years.
  1122. I bought this razor in June 2011, and used it pretty much every other day since then. My prior razor was a Braun Pulsonic, which I liked very much, but the trimmer broke just after the warranty was up. After that, I decided to see what else was out there, and I decided on the ES-LA63. The first thing you notice about this razor is the really big shaving head. I thought that would be good, since it would mean a faster shave. But, it didn't turn out that way. The head is just too big to be maneuverable on my face. The shaving head tilts and moves in all directions, but I just couldn't get it in some parts of my face. The blades didn't seem to be as sharp or cut as well as the Braun, even when the Panasonic was new.<br /><br />I really wanted to like this razor. The trimmer is good, and the controls are useful and friendly. It can be used in a wet (with shaving oil or shaving cream) or dry mode, which is good for convenience. It washes easily with liquid soap and water - you don't have to have a cleaning module, although there is a model of this razor that has that if you want it. Personally, I would rather save the money and just wash my razors with soap/water. The motor on it is pretty quiet, and the shaver build quality is outstanding. But, the razor just didn't shave as well as my old Braun, and that's the bottom line. You might find it just fine, but I like a really close shave, since I only shave every other day. After a few months, I'll review the Braun.<br /><br />I purchased a new Braun for Christmas, and I think I will be much more satisfied with it, even though there is nothing really wrong with the Panasonic other than it's not as good for me as a Braun.<br /><br />Your mileage may vary, and probably will.
  1123. Starting to get a close shave after 50+ years with the latest blade razor. Takes me about 2.5 minutes for a full facial shave using soap and water as a preconditioner. The shaver felt clumsy at first but now feels great. Great price, great razor.
  1124. Great razor. Shaves close and very easy to clean with running water. Recharges super fast. The display is easy to read and gives you usable information. The pop-up trimmer works great. I can't report on durability yet but I have used it almost daily now for about 3 months with no problems. I think it gives you about a 90-95% closeness as compared to a blade but saves a lot of time and it's easier on your skin so you might shave a little more often due to the convenience. This is the first electric I've owned in about 20 years and I can say they are vastly improved so if you are one that hasn't tried one in a while you will probably very pleased with it's performance and features. I forgot to mention that I have only used it dry so far but it can be used wet as well.
  1125. I have been unable to shave with a regular razor for well over a year now do to changes in my skin and that come along with a graying beard.   1127. I have over the years used all of the major brands of shavers and have been let down. Braun (2), Remington, Norelco, etc. All given me the same results, mediocre performance. I accepted that I would be forced to use foam and a razor. By the way, I also tried all of the fancy razors too. two blade, three blade even four blade, I tried them all. Well, after reading the positive reviews of the Panasonic Arc 4, I convinced myself to give it one last try. I have to say, it was an excellent decision. This version from Panasonic does everything I expect from a shaver and more. I have a very troublesome spot under my jaw that even the razors could solve. I was always left with 80 grit sandpaper under my chin. Well no more.<br /> I really am impressed with the Panasonic. Three minute dry shaves give me the results comparable to a razor. Quick and smooth. In addition, you get the bonus of being able to use this shaver wet! Yes, I didn't believe it but I decided to give it a try. Wow, even more impressive. Very quick and I do believe it is even closer than a razor. I love the ease of being able to clean it just using water and a little soap. Easy to clean and maintain.<br /> I travel several times a year and the Panasonic Arc4 will really solve the necessity to carry the disposable razors. I am looking forward to going on another cruise and taking this shaver along. Being able to use it dry or wet is a big bonus. Also, the ease of cleaning will add greatly to a carefree vacation. The Braun cleaning station with purchasing cleaning cartridges, ( gets real old, really quick), was a constant inconvenience. Plus, what do you do on vacation? Everything about this shaver is a positive.<br /> So, go out and buy the others, spend more money, but if you want performance, the satisfaction of getting a close, excellent shave, and being able to use it wet (shower, sink) or dry, plus the convenience of very easy cleaning, then you deserve to get this shaver. It definitely works for me and I am very satisfied.<br /> By the way, I ordered it on a Thursday afternoon, paid an extra $3.99 (pocket change) and had it in my hands the next day! Wow, talk about customer service! Amazon is the best, and whenever I need something, Amazon is my first destination to shop. By the way, Amazon also has the best price! I saw the same model listed as high as $200.00 on another site. Thanks Amazon, you box with a smile on it always puts a smile on my face!

  1133. I opted not to get the most expensive model with so-called automatic cleaning. I clean it every third day of shaving with just a little hand soap and rinse under the tap water. I am glad I didnt pay extra for the solution bath. The sink water and soap method is effective enough.   1148. It's ok, the product itself is built quite well, but if you're expecting a clean shave, this just doesn't really do it compared to a blade.
  1149. I LOVE this razor. 3 disclaimers.<br />1.) Some people like rotary razors. If that's you, ignore this review. I tried the top of the line Norelco and hated it. This is a foil razor -- I've had lots of Brauns and Panasonics. This is the best foil razor I have ever had.<br />2.) There are thousands of reviews of electric razors and you will find passionate defenses of and eloquent attacks on each. Obviously faces differ. Bottom line: find someone who had the kind of razor you used to have (and liked). Their reviews will probably be most accurate for you. Mine have been high end Braun and Panasonic. My old Braun was falling apart -- even with new blades. This is the replacement.<br />3.) Some people like the &#34;auto clean&#34; features -- they raise the price about $90, give you a big stand into which the razor fits, plus you have to buy expensive cartridges or washing fluid. Most of them don't disinfect. (I think the Braun may) Some of them smell disgusting -- the Norelco fluid smells like the cheapest nasty body spray you've ever smelled. The manufacturers obviously have an interest in getting you to buy a renewable -- think printer toner -- rather than just a device. They claim it has benefits on efficacy. Interestingly, I've seen no empirical study beyond the ad copy that the auto clean features actually increase the life, efficacy or cleanliness of the razor over just rinsing the blades with warm water and liquid hand soap (not detergent) every week or so. If you disagree, and want the auto wash feature -- I admit it sounds cool -- this isn't the razor for you.<br /><br />Why do I love it? It shaves closer with no tugging or pulling. It has &#34;nano tech blades&#34; which sounds like marketing BS but it is actually similar to the really fancy blades on the Gillette wet razors. They really are sharper. I typically to a light shave with an electric and then shave with a Gillette 4 wet razor. This was so good that -- even used dry -- it wasnearly as close as the wet razor. Trimmer is small but very good. Bottom line: superb product. Highly recommended.
  1150. I've used a Braun 360° for the past 5 years. It was never very good so I always followed it up with a standard Gillette razor. Recently the foil on my Braun got a hole in it so I figured I'd get a new electric and picked this one. After three days of not shaving my Panasonic ES showed up. I was a little concerned since my beard was a bit long but I figured since it's a wet/dry shaver I'd give it a shot. I fully charged my razor (it took a bit less than 1 hour), lathered up with just liquid-soap and water, and ran it over my face. Wow! It took a little bit of time and pressure but 5 minutes later my face was as smooth as if I'd used a razor blade. Without a doubt this is the best electric razor I've ever used. I considered the Arc5 but it's too pricey and I don't think the price warrants the extra money for me. Don't bother with the cleaning stations; They take up too much counter space and you can just use a little soap and water every so often to clean it. I've only had it a week so it's possible I will run into issues but so far I'm extremely pleased with my purchase. Update: After a few weeks of using the razor I've noticed that after using it dry, it leaves my face smooth, but I can still see the stubble just under my skin. And once I step into the shower the heat causes my hairs to raise up and I can feel the stubble so I've been going over it with a razor blade afterwards. When I tried to use the razor in the shower it didn't do as good of a job as my first shave at the sink with a longer beard. Specifically, it didn't do a good job of picking up my hairs that were stuck against my neck. For now I've gone back to my previous use of a dry-electric shave before showering and using a blade in the shower. I still love this razor. It's the best electric razor I've ever used. It shaves my face pretty well in less than 3 minutes. I would buy it again in a heartbeat.

  1156. I previously had tried many different electric shavers and had never been quite pleased with the results. I was displeased with multiple units I'd tried from Braun and Noreleco and kept going back to a Mach III. Too much irritation or hair pulling. The only unit I'd been some what pleased with was a Panasonic linear unit that wasn't wet dry. I decided to roll the dice on this unit after reading rave reviews everywhere. I got this nearly two years ago and I have to say it continues to be fantastic. I use it to shave both my beard and my head. It shaves well enough dry that I don't feel I need to use water or shaving cream. In fact I prefer a dry shave as there is much less irritation. With shaving cream it is almost as close as the trusty Mach III with none of the potential for nicks and cuts and much less irritation. The battery life is pretty good, and it can make it through a week of quick shaves, and it charges very quick. It's fairly easy to clean as well. I haven't had any issues with blade or foil longevity. Added bonus, it's one of the Panasonic models that's still made in japan. True it costs a pretty penny and it's not on sale very often. The side burn trimmer is not the greatest, but acceptable. My only other gripe is that if you don't shave for a couple of days it won't do as good as a job and it pulls hairs, but honestly that's to be expected. I use it in combination with a philips trimmer when I get lazy to rectify that particular problem. If you're on the fence, just get it, especially on the somewhat rare occasion it's on sale for under $100.

  1182. I just received and started using this new razor. I have been using rotary Norelco shavers for many years, and in the past have tried foil razors, but they never matched the rotary razors. Not any more. Very powerful motor, unlike my current, anemic Norelco, and more powerful than any I have had in the past. Because of this., there is no pulling of whiskers. No cuts like from past foil razors. Closest shave of any electric I have ever used. While my Norelco is quieter, this unit is certainly not offensively loud to me. The only part of my shaves that require a manual razor is to shave where my sideburns and skin meet. The battery life has also been very good (although it is i new). I have been VERY pleasantly surprised by this razor, and I have only used it dry thus far. While I have only had it a short time, it sure seems like a real keeper.

  1190. As most have noted, the shaver does an excellent job when working. Unfortunately, between this shaver and another Panasonic (ES8243) I have owned, I have sent it to Texas for warranty replacement four times and once to NY for repair - which totals around $50 for my cost to ship to them (the ship back is their cost). Each time the same failure occurs with the electronics malfunctioning, the razor turns on randomly and the display does not work. Prior to these I used a Norelco Nivea razor which did not cut as well but never stopped working. I really do like this razor's performance but I wish they didn't claim it was submersible and for wet use.
  1191. This is the second Panasonic ES-LA63-S that I have owned. Great product in my opinion! Very reliable comfortable and lasts.
  1192. I take blood thinner and as a result any cut results in excessive bleeding. I bought this electric Panasonic E5 razor thinking it would give me a safe close shave. It does'nt even after the suggested 1 month \\"give it time\\" statement from the manufacturer it does not give me the close shave that I want. I will go back to the risks of using a straight razor until I can locate a satisfactory replacement. STAY AWAY!!!
  1193. This shaver works very well, my second Panasonic electric shaver. I received the ultimate compliment the other day when my coworkers and I were discussing electric vs. manual safety and he pointed out he thought I used a safety razor because of the close shave.
  1194. Works great. It gets as close as a razor for me but the only difference would be the hair grows back a bit faster with this vs a razor. Doesn't irritate my skin though I'm not too sensitive. I mostly use it dry but when I take it into the shower it's even better. The battery life isn't as long as my norelco that I had but 10 times better than the norelco. I get about 5 full shaves on it before needing a charge<br />I would recommend it and would buy another if I broke this one
  1195. pros:<br />- close shave on most parts of my face<br />- easy to clean<br /><br />cons:<br />- trimmer felt cheap, like I might break it every time I open it to use it<br />- had difficulty getting in tight areas, like upper lip under nose<br />- the head on this thing is huge - like shaving with a two-by-four<br />- expensive<br /><br />bottom line:<br />- might work for some, but I was just never comfortable using it with it's huge head, and was annoyed that it couldn't get into tighter<br /> areas of my face
