But after reading some reviews of this shaver, I figured the technology had improved. It's certainly a nice looking razor. And it's not loud. And I like how the head swivels. It's just that it doesn't actually remove any of my hair.<br /><br />There's a slip of paper in the box that says (paraphrasing here), &#34;Please don't send this back until you've used it for a month.&#34; But I can't go to work for a month with a hairy face.
  1199. I've been a blade user for over 40 years and decided to try an electric shaver. I read all the reviews and it came down to Panasonic vs Braun. I went with the ES-LA63-S primarily because of the price, performance and the ease of cleaning. I didn't want the whole cleaning station thing and after using this shaver, I think they are totally unnecessary. I also didn't think I would really use it for a wet shave, but I had a bunch of Edge shaving cream and gave it a try. Wow! Super close, smooth and comfortable.I would even go so far as to say that it gives a shave closer than a blade. Of course, I use it \\"dry\\" too, but like to use a pre-shave like Willimas Lectric shave or something similar. It holds a charge for about a week or seven shaves. Once it is down to about 20% I plug it in to charge. Also, I was concerned about being able to shave my upper lip close to my nose with such a big head on the shaver, but I've found that I have no problem at all. The only other thing that I would point out is that it really does take time to get used to an electric shaver. You have to perfect your shaving style based on your face and beard. Be patient and give it a couple of weeks. I'm very pleased with it.
  1200. Superb shaver, best shave ever. Not cheap, but well worth the cost. I have tried every electric shaver on the market, Braun, Philips (Norelco), Remington, and this Panasonic leaves them all behind! It is well engineered and gives a superb shave.
  1201. I recently retired my 8 year old Panasonic ES8228. It was pretty good, but it always struggled with the neck. The only way I could get a relatively close shave towards the end of it's life, was using a full suite of wet shave products (pre-shave gel, shaving cream/brush, after-lotion). This ES-LA63-S absolutely blows it away. The dry shave was closer than a full wet shave with the old Panasonic, plus I can get through it in 2 minutes tops. Wet shave is marginally closer than the dry, just leaves a bit less irritation. The old one, the wet process would take a good 8 minutes, dry about 6. End of the day, even a dry shave with this, minus the neck, is as close as a safety razor shave, no doubt. The neck is the best I've gotten with an electric razor and it's very close to a blade shave. No cons with this purchase, I should've done this years ago.
  1202. He loves it! I don't know anything about razors but I thought this looked like a good deal for a pretty fancy razor. He especially seems impressed with how fast it charges and stays charged.
  1203. I bought this in May 2013 and I can proudly say this is one best products from Panasonic and a real 'Made in Japan' one. I used a Braun before (Which was good) and Remington ( Worst). The Arc 4 does an excellent job and gives a clean shave. I have a thick beard and a dry skin (worst combo). So normally with a Gi****e razor I must shave every two days or the beard really thick I literally scream of pain while shaving. With the Arc4 I never had that problem, however one little issue (most common with most elec. shavers in the market) is it's a little difficult to shave the neck area. I have to use the blade. The battery seems great so far. Maintenance is easy too, just put a little liquid soap on the foil and turn on the shaver, rinse under water and you are done.

  1207. I like being able to shave while in the shower. Much easier to clean that way. I had a shaver with shaving heads before this one and it was a big pain to clean. I think the shave is actually a little worse with this one, but not a lot if any. There is one annoying thing about this shaver is the position of the switch to turn it on. When you hold the shaver to shave it is easy to hit the switch with your thumb and it shuts off. You can lock the shaver in the on position, but so far I usually forget to do this until I shut it off, then I remember. Not a big deal, but a slight annoyance. Still early...if I encounter any problems or become even more pleased I'll be back to update my review.

  1222. I have tried several different electric shavers over the years and finally found the one that really works for me. Several years ago I bought one of the first wet/dry models from Panasonic and I liked it. After that one stopped working it got replaced by other models as I tried to find one that would give me a closer shave. I finally went back to Panasonic and bought the ES-LA63-S. I have used it now for one month. This one can be used with equal efficiency dry or wet (I like to use it in the shower). Compared to my previous shavers from Norelco, Phillips, and Braun, this one works better. It provides a closer shave and it is faster. It takes me about 2 minutes to get a complete shave and it is very smooth without &#34;skip areas&#34; like some of the other shavers. The high RPM's and multiple (4) blades of this shaver seem to make the difference in efficiency and ability to give you a very close shave. The battery life is very good and it charges very fast. I will keep this one for a long time.
  1223. This is my third Panasonic shaver and the best I've ever had. My beard is not an easy one, with hair growing in all directions chaotically. The previous two razors (with two and three blades) never were able to shave a little spot near the mandible, close to the right ear. Well, this one does. And with a single pass.<br />Pros: great value for the price, smooth shaving, quiet (in comparison with older models from Panasonic), easy to clean, duration of battery.<br />Cons: should come with a charging dock and a small brush to remove the hair from the blades without the need for washing, the travel bag shoudl also fit the charger, in the case of long trips.
  1224. As I mentioned in a previous review, I have been a Panasonic electric shaver user for over 20 years. I like the overall quality of Panasonic shavers and I think that they are the best electric shavers on the market. I have a heavy beard and they give me the closest shave with the least discomfort. That having been said, I was very disappointed with my previous Panasonic shaver (Model ES8077S Vortex Hydraclean System Electric Shaver) for two reasons: the shaver did not last as long as other ones I have owned (the rechargable batteries wore out way too prematurely for a shaver at this price level), and the HydraClean base unit was too large and bulky. As I said in my review of the HydraClean cartridges, the HydraClean system is an expensive gimmick.<br /><br />I have sinced purchased this Panasonic wet-dry shaver Model ES-LA63 (on sale at Target + a $25.00 rebate from Panasonic) and I am much happier with it. It is also much easier to clean by putting a few drops of SoftSoap on the foil head and rinsing it under the faucet at nano-speed.<br /><br />One more tip: Panasonic shavers frequently go on sale at discounters like Target and WalMart, and Panasonic offers rebates from time-to-time so it pays to read the circulars and shop around, especially around Fathers Day.

  1229. I bought this razor after having looked into the Braun momentarily. As everyone who reviewed that one critically had said they switched to the LA-63, I thought I'd give it a try. The \\"minor\\" inconveniences outlined in other reviews (that gave it 4-5 stars) seemed to be manageable, I would like to say that they are not.<br /><br />-Many people say that \\"it doesn't do a good job on the neck,\\" this is a major understatement. It does a terrible job on the neck, when it feels the convenience to do the job at all. The reason I switched to electric was to save time in the morning, I'm finding it takes LONGER to use this than a normal razor.<br /><br />-The head is more than bulky, it's like trying to shave with some sort of savage's club. Forget sideburns, literally impossible to get a good line. A bit of hair around your forehead out of whack? Forget it again, you risk destroying your entire hairline.<br /><br />-Finally, and probably most disconcerting. This product doesn't work when it's plugged in. The genius who invented this feature must be a pretty malicious little devil who purposely thinks of ways to annoy people. It may be a \\"safety feature,\\" but as there's a \\"lock\\" feature this becomes an unnecessary and bothersome redundancy. When I'm \\"done\\" shaving in the morning, and then catch a [few] little spot[s] that the tennis-ball-on-a-stick missed, I need to unplug it to embark on another journey. When you're in a hurry in the morning this is a significant inconvenience as it's fairy hard to plug and unplug [this is a good feature as it's secure, however when combined with the non-functionality of being able to operate while plugged in, it becomes an ill-conceived inconvenience).<br /><br />Overall, I'm unsatisfied with this product.

  1234. I purchased the ES-LA63-S as an upgrade to the 3-Blade ES8103S I'd been using the past three years. I've been using electric razors for a long time, working through Brauns, Norelcos and Panasonics. My beard is coarse and dark, so it's difficult to get to a smooth face with any of these razors. My hope was that the ES-LA63-S would shorten my too-long shave times, and leave me feeling smooth into the evening. Recently, I’ve been using the Lab Series Electric Shave Solution with both the old and new razors, which leaves my face smoother and less chaffed.<br /><br />I used the ES-LA63-S for three weeks, and am now returning it. Its performance was no better than the smaller and easier to maneuver ES8103S - in fact, when I thought I was done with the ES-LA63-S, I found the ES8103S would still find areas of bristle to shave smooth. Even worse, my face had a stinging feeling and more nicks that I was used to finding.<br /><br />The ES-LA63-S does have a very large head, making it challenging to move under the jawline and above the upper lip. I thought I might get used to it, but all I had to do was pick up and use the old ES8103S to recall how nimble that one is by comparison.<br /><br />The ES-LA63-S’s cutter blade is also more difficult to use – it is rather short and hides behind the massive shave head when trying to guide it using a mirror. The shaver does come with a nice zippered travel pouch. I also liked the lock switch – good to lock it off during travel, but I also had to use it while shaving to lock the razor on, as the on/off button is too easy to hit while shaving.<br /><br />In summary, this over-large, more expensive shaver under-performs the leaner, less-expensive 3-Blade shaver. I really hoped for this version to be a step up from the simpler model, but found it to be a real disappointment.

  1267. Wow! Impressive shaver. I was skeptical to pay so much for an electric razor, but my wife had checked the reviews and this one kept getting high marks. I have NEVER had a closer shave with an electric razor, and I have a heavy beard. It does not pull. It holds a charge. It has an LED display that tells you how much charge you have left that is accurate. It is light weight and comfortable in your hand.   1268. My husband says this is the best shaver he has ever had (though it has to be said he has never spent this much on one before!). He loves this thing. He has sensitive skin so I chose this one because I found a review somewhere that said it is good for people with sensitive skin. But don't think for a moment that that must mean it doesn't do the job: my husband had basically never had a thoroughly clean-shaven face until he got this shaver, because some of his stubble is very tough indeed. Now he is perfectly cleanly shaved every day. He generally just does a dry shave, but sometimes he uses Kiss My Face Moisture Shave for a sort of wet shave with this shaver. (BTW, Kiss My Face Moisture Shave is another excellent product that doesn't stink or upset sensitive skin.)<br /><br />In the event that the shaver needs to have parts (blades??) replaced before the time the manufacturer states, I will update my review accordingly. My husband said that even a cheap Remington worked well for the first week (though it never got him any more clean-shaven than any of the other cheap shavers he's had in the past) -- until the blade(s) went blunt -- though by &#34;worked well&#34; he didn't mean that the cheap Remington got him clean shaven, just that it didn't feel too bad or destroy his skin while leaving most of the stubble in place.
  1269. My husband really likes it. It does a great job. I did read several reviews before I made this purchase.
  1270. It is better than my last shaver and not expensive. But it does not reach my expectation. I think manual shaver is better.
  1271. It does a great job of giving me a close smooth shave. I love that you can get it wet and have a nice cool shave by rewetting it. It is really easy to clean. Just put a liquid soap on it and run it with a little added water on the blades. No more brushes that get caught in the screen.

  1276. Works as expected. Holds a charge amazingly long. I've probably had this for 8 months or so...maybe a year now. I use it every day and charge it once every couple weeks. Charges up very quickly and then I put the charger away again. Nice for travel as well, since I don't need to bring the charging cord. Prior to this I had an older Remington. This is superior in terms of technology, at least compared to my older model. Bought this based on reviews. Although I like how the Remington fit in my hand a little better. More natural. The big head on this makes it top heavy. Not a big deal. I got used to it pretty quickly. *********************** Update April 2015 ************************** I've had this for a year now. Still running strong and very satisfied. I only charge it once every couple weeks, but my usage is probably every other day or so. I recently took a 10 day vacation and it's so easy to bring this vs shaving kit. I didn't bring the power chord, since it easily holds a charge all week. I believe it still had 40% of the battery life when I returned home. It's already been a week since my return and still haven't re-charged it.
  1277. I did a lot of research on electric shavers online. There's always positive and negative reviews on every single shaver out there. I suppose that's because everyone's hair is different, so different products work better for some than others. I myself am mostly Italian with very thick, almost black hair. My facial hair doesn't grow really fast though. I settled on Panasonic because I got their Nose/ear hair trimmer and it cut incredibly closely with ease and without pulling hairs.<br /><br /> However, I was more than a little disappointed with their electric shaver. Especially for the price- over $100 when I got it. Not sure what it's at now and don't care to check. First I'll start with the pros though:<br /><br /> Easy to clean- Doesn't get much easier than this. Run it under water, or squirt some hand soap on the top and let it bubble up and wash it off. When you need to take the head off and clean the insides, a light goes off to tell you. The head comes off and goes back on very easily.<br /><br /> The head can either be locked in place or bobble around freely. This creates much more maneuverability going around your chin and neck especially.<br /><br /> Very close shave- the finished results are an incredibly close shave. Smoother than I can get with a razor.<br /><br /> Now the cons are shorter, but much more important. Though the product is easy to use and clean, and the finished results of what it does get are incredibly smooth, it just doesn't get everything it should. I have to go over every spot over and over and over again. And then on my neck and some parts of my face I end up just using a razor because this shaver simply wont get them. It's very frustrating paying over $100 for a product that wont do what it's supposed to. With how long it takes just to shave what it is able to shave, I found myself returning to the good old razor blades.<br /><br /> In the future, I will be trying Wahl's electric shaver. My barber uses it on me when he cuts my hair and it works extremely well with minimal effort. I'll be posting a review of that one too when I try it.

  1280. I have used 3 electric shavers my entire shaving career (25 years) - 2 remingtons and, most recently, a braun 3 series which died after only 3 years of moderate use. I bought it just over a year ago. It has worked fine for 3-4 shaves a week. I use it in the shower wet with a not-too-lathery shaving cream. I've used it dry a couple of times while travelling and definitely prefer the wet.<br /><br />The large head and contour-following blades shave everything on my face quickly - even the bit right under my nose.<br /><br />Mine developed an issue with the LCD screen going wonky and then quitting altogether after about 8 months - it still shaved, but I couldn't tell how much charge was left. Since the warranty was for 2 years, I boxed it up and sent it into Panasonic's repair facility in TX and got a brand-new boxed LA-93 (same model, essentially but with the optional cleaning/charging base) in about 15 days. Haven't tried the cleaning cartridge on that yet, but the LA-63 was easy to clean with a quick soap and rinse.

One or two passes won't cut it. Even with that said, it's so much easier and convenient to shave with an electric razor.   1307. I do not have a heavy beard. It's coarse, and even, but I can go without shaving for a couple of days.<br /><br />I have tried this product wet, with and without shaving cream or lotion. I've tried it dry as well: My conclusion is this device is grossly mislabeled. It's not and never has been intended to use to shave facial hair. It was likely a failed school project. Or possibly a a device designed to exemplify the meaning of electrical inefficiency, or how loud something must be to cause permanent hearing loss over a prolonged period of time. I won't pretend to have the answer. I know only this: It is a dismal failure at shaving my face. I can go over an area multiple times in multiple directions and it misses 20-75% of the stubble. After a the time required to 'shave' ones face; the irritation is worse than that of a traditional razor. It's extremely inefficient when it comes to power consumption, and delights in dying in the middle of a shave with no warning at all whatsoever. The head is broad and laughable in its imprecision. The trimmer is so poorly placed as to be utterly pointless, but at this point, I'm so disappointed I may be nit-picking. I tried everything suggested and more to make it work correctly. I did so with diligence past the point of return. So I am stuck with this damned, over-priced noise maker.
  1308. I was skeptical of the reviews. I've tried electric shavers of all sorts, mostly cheap ones. They all left my face feeling like I shaved with a belt sander. I am a believer now. This doesn't pull, nick, scratch or abrade. It just leaves my baby face untouched. Really nice product.

  1310. I have been using this for over a month now as a replacement for a recent Braun model (of which I had 2) that kept dying. Even though I had already been using an electric razor (the Brauns that needed continual repairs on which I finally gave up), it took about 2 weeks of using this Panasonic before I could say I was finally starting to get a really close shave. The things I like about this razor: Very smooth shaving - no pulling, no irritation; very fast charge times, very easy cleaning; good balance for handling; solid construction; close enough shave (the Braun was marginally better, this is still really good); pivoting head. Things that could use improvement: Battery life - it is good but the Braun was better - I can get about 10 days vs. 14 days with the Braun on a charge - I hate travelling with chargers; the wide head makes it tough to get your upper lip under your nose - I need to do some careful maneuvering; the pop-up trimmer could be a bit bigger, and an even closer shave. Thus far, I have generally been happy with it. At least it hasn't died yet!<br /><br />***Update July 24, 2015***<br />I have been using it for about a year now, and it is still going strong. Battery life remains decent, and the shave is still good. I am about to replace the blades and foil since it seems like I need to spend a greater time shaving now to get a close shave. About a 1 year for a replacement baled and foil isn't bad. The large shave head and size is more of an issue for me now, so I also just bought a Panasonic ES-LT41 to use for travel. I have been happy with the quality of the Panasonic razors. This model remains a 4-star.

  1327. Having ventured out into the world outside of Panasonic as far as men’s shavers are concerned- let me say this- I’m not going back into that world. Recently I bought the Braun 3 series and shelled out almost $200. It is a fine shaver but it never came close to Panasonic. It did a good job overall but over I needed to go over spots many times- and progressively it took longer and longer to get the results I wanted. This did a number on my skin and during the cold dry winter months my skin would be very sensitive and sore, especially the area below my nose. I knew I needed to go back to Panasonic so I bought the ES-LA63-S Arc4.<br />Off the bat the shaver looks very different form the other Panasonic models I’ve been used to. Its got a huge head- but it feels right and comfortable in your hand. I charged it a bit up to 30% and tried it out- the motor is superfast and its very quiet. The razors do a great job picking up everything even the hard stubbles above my neck- at 30% the shaver did a faster and better job than the Braun model. I was impressed already but really I expected the ES-LA63-S Arc4 to do well. Im glad I went back to the Panasonic shavers and I know my sensitive skin will thank me for it.

  1329. After some 40 years shaving with various electric razors, I have been generally disapointed one way or another until now. I have come to believe that different faces will get better results with different styles of cutting heads and much will be a matter of trial and error. For me, this Panasonic is fantastic. My last 2 razors were Braun because I believed they were the best for a close shave, plus I liked the self-cleaning feature. My last Braun 2 months ago, was terrible. It was the 2nd from the top of the line (replacing the next lower model which I had for 4 years). I got a good shave for about 2 weeks then it started actually pulling out hairs. Quite painful. It went back. Then I tried this one. I was hesitant because I thought the size and shape of the cutting surface would keep me from getting all the difficult spots. I was wrong. This unit is very smooth and close for my medium-tough beard. I have never used it wet or with lotion and it is still excellent.<br /><br />Another concern was from other reviews that complain about the short battery life. That is either a bad unit or someone is doing it wrong. I have had this for nearly a month and I'm still on the first charge. It's now 30%. What I did was I shaved and ran it all the way down when I first opened it. Then I recharged it to max. I think this conditions the battery to hold a full charge. Even now at 30% it hasn't slowed down and shaves great. It cleans easily by just pulling off the top and running under water. Time will ultimately tell, but I think I will enjoy this shave for many years. I highly recommend this Panasonic ES-LA63-S.
  1330. Skin type: super sensitive<br />Hair type: coarse<br />Hair density: medium to heavy<br /><br />Have happily owned a Panasonic ES8243A Arc 4 for the last 4 and a half years without complaint. Was time to order replacement blades so I decided to look at the new options available. Here is my quick review of the updated ES-LA63-S<br /><br />Yes, Panasonic still makes the world's best shavers. I've owned a very expensive Braun which did not get this close. Any Arc 4 is going to get you RAZOR CLOSENESS. I prefer using dry shave with a bit of 'lectric shave to help the razor glide, without hindering my ability to pull the skin in various directions to help get a closer shave.<br /><br />The ES-LA63-S is a terrific razor, but may not really be worth an extra $39 over the &#34;older&#34; ES8243A (at time of publishing it is $39). The cutting system appears the same. The now &#34;thinner&#34; foil is something I can't really test.<br /><br />The advantages are :<br />-It is pleasantly quieter over the original model<br />-The head has some additional tilting mechanism, which might be useful for some people (I prefer a rigid head so I can really control the damn thing. The LA63 is like a lexus, the ES8243 was more like a BMW in that regard, but you can lock the head and achieve the same.)<br />-Brighter LCD<br /><br />The shave, to me, is nearly identical. So identical I couldn't tell you if this razor is cutting closer because the blades are new, or if because it has some enhancements.<br /><br />I'm a marketer so sorry if I don't believe everything I read.<br /><br />The one Con : The head is like 30% larger than the previous model, but you don't get anything additional shaving space...It probably just holds the mechanism for tilting side and back. Ok that's fine, but see my comment about regarding control.<br /><br />If money is an issue, grab the $99 ES8243A while you can - I promise you won't be able to tell the difference. If you have the extra cash, get the brighter LCD, quieter motor, and more floaty head on the LA63.<br /><br />These are my 2 cents. Enjoy!

  1334. I only use electric and have owned a previous Panasonic model for the last 7 years. My current shaver costs roughly the same amount as this one back then. The difference between this model and the old one is almost indescribable. The 4 blades glide over your face with no resistance as opposed to the constant grating/grabbing of hair. It almost feels like the shaver isn't cutting, but it feels just as close if not closer than a traditional shave...so much so that I now shave every other day as opposed to every day, there simply isn't enough growth the next day to warrant it. The larger head allows a quicker shave than before. That being said the head is pretty large and you need to be a little more careful making sure you get to all the hairs on the upper lip.<br /><br />A few notes if you are considering other Panasonic models:<br /><br />-You don't need the separate cleaner...I've had one before and when i did use it (not very often) it didn't clean any better than simple soap and running water from the faucet, and it left an undesirable smell (you are putting this thing under your nose) that you had to rinse off anyway. Plus it takes up space and you need to buy cleaner fluid. Does not add anything other than $$$.<br /><br />-Number of blades. Had 3 before and that size was a bit more manageable. Not sure if the 4 blade cuts so well because of the number of blades or the newer technology. The 4 blade is on the verge of being too big but it works for me so far (travel a lot and need all the space I can get). I would sacrifice the size for the comfort. I think the 5 blade would too big and too hard to maneuver on the upper lip.<br /><br />-Price. Extremely happy with purchase and would pay more for this to get the comfort. I've had Panasonic shavers and they last (regular cleaning and replacing of blades every 2 years or so), never had an issue functionality wise (battery was good for the last 7 years).<br /><br />Bottom line is I looked at all the reviews and knew I personally liked the foil type better than rotary and knew that Panasonic makes a decent, durable shaver, knew I didn't need a separate cleaner and was hoping to get a marginally better shave than what I had now (didn't want to invest any more money into replacement blades for a 7 year old shaver). I got a huge improvement and couldn't be happier with the purchase, so much so that I put a review here, something I have rarely do, especially a positive review.views and knew I personally liked the foil type better than rotary and knew that Panasonic makes a decent, durable shaver, knew I didn't need a separate cleaner and was hoping to get a marginally better shave than what I had now (didn't want to invest any more money into replacement blades for a 7 year old shaver).   1337. I've owned this razor for about a month now and I have to say I absolutely love it! I used to stay away from electric razors because of how badly they irritated my skin, especially around my mouth and all over my neck. I do not have those problems with this razor at all. I've used it wet and dry and I have to say that both ways leave my skin feeling good.<br /><br />The shave quality is pretty dang good, if you shave every day. If you don't shave for a few days more passes on certain areas are necessary. That being said I usually shave every day and when I do this razor provides a shave equal to most of the traditional razors I've used.<br /><br />Also of note for anyone with sensitive skin use an aftershave balm that is alcohol free! A lot of cheaper after shaves have alcohol in them and that will cause irritation no matter how good of a razor you use. I received some lavender aftershave balm from the Art of Shaving, it is crazy expensive but it is a good place to start looking. The key is to get alcohol free!<br /><br />The battery life is pretty good as well, I charge it once a week and have had no problems with the battery or charging cable.<br /><br />If I have any problems with the razor I will be sure to update the review here!
  1338. I have only bought 3 electric razors prior...all panasonic so I don't have much base for comparison. The 4 blade definitely shaves cleaner and quicker. The head pivots in all directions but you can also lock it in one position if you want. However like all the other panasonics, the display breaks down after a few months and I can no longer monitor the battery life. I would buy again if the price was right.
  1339. After a month, I really like this shaver. I really liked my old Braun, too, but after 6 or 7 years it got noiser, started to choke on whiskers as the little hole in the drive unit wore larger(where the pin from the blade fits into). I nearly bought another Braun, a Pulsonic, but after reading the reviews on Amazon, and realizing that this was a lot cheaper and I could quit the monthly alcohol-cartridge subscription, I gave it a try.<br />It's great! Smooth, quiet, cleans easily with liquid soap and water every few days, no $$ for cartridges. Best of all, my wife can sleep in an extra hour without having the intermittent BUZZZ going off periodically, like the Braun used to do during it's cleaning cycle.

Then I use a manual razor for the finishing work. This will make my razors last a lot longer since I am not using them as much, just to get everything smooth. The BEST part about this method is that the panasonic with shaving cream does NOT hurt! When you use a manual razor after 2 days of not shaving, there is irritation and pain and it hurts to shave. Now I use the panasonic and it does not hurt.. then when I use the manual razor it does not hurt because there is hardly anything left to shave. With the wet method I do not get a very close shave. There are still problem stops. I have not tested this razor dry. The razor works quickly and I can do the initial shave in about 2 minutes. Quieter and closer, if that's possible, every bit as close as a five bladed Gillette. Then I decided to call Panasonic and tell them my first razor quit and that I had purchased a new one, but wondered what I could do about the old one.   1363. I was in the market for a new electric razor after my Braun just stopped working. I didn't want another Braun for a few reasons. The cleaning system is a sham. You have to buy refills of the liquid and it doesn't adequately clean the razor. The cleaning system itself also gets very dirty and almost impossible to clean. The shave quality was good but there are other razors out there that provide the same shave quality.<br /><br />So I settled on the Panasonic and am extremely happy with it. It gave me a close shave almost immediately even though the instructions said it may take up to 30 days. What I really like is how low maintenance it is. It is extremely easy to clean. Just put some liquid hand soap on the top while its running and it cleans it very well. You can easily take off the blade and see that it's very clean after washing. Very easy.<br /><br />The only possible negative is that the razor head is large and it gets a little awkward shaving the upper lip.<br /><br />Regardless I highly recommend this razor for anyone looking for a reliable product and doesn't want to break the bank.

  1365. For decades I have been under the illusion that only rotary shavers do not pinch you or cause nick while shaving. \\"Foil\\" shavers were just going to be a lot of grief. Then my rotary shaver just wasn't satisfying me anymore so I decided to give Panasonic ES-LA63-S a chance. The reviews I read on Amazon were just too persuasive!<br /><br />From the beginning, I had no \\"break in\\" period. I did not need a month to see the close shaves I was getting even without water and shaving cream. However, I have used the shaver wet and my face seems to be as smooth as it would be when I did a blade shave. Another important thing I realized was with my rotary shaver, I had quite a job to remove the revolving blades and the seat they were placed in to clean them and then to use alcohol and oil to get them back into fighting trim.<br /><br />The Panasonic is a breeze to clean. I mean quick. They have a nice printed instruction sheet with pictures that emphasize that point. Yes, the sideburn cutter takes some getting use to, but I feel that with a little practice I will have no problem in trimming my sideburns and moustache.<br /><br />Someone remarked that they wished that the case for the Panasonic shaver had room for accessories. I have a small bag for traveling that easily takes my shaver in its case and my accessory charger. The shaver's case is so close around the shaver that it easily fits in my travel case, no problem.<br /><br />From a rotary shaver user who finally has had his eyes opened to greater convenience and faster shaves.

The thing that always messed with me was shaving my neck. I always need quite a few passes to get all the hair and this ends up irritating my neck really bad. This shaver is so comfy that even though I have to make the multiple passes my face is still in pretty good shape. I have not tried a wet shave yet but will soon. Even just using this unit dry and having to make a lot of passes my face is still not that irritated. Highly recommend.

You will NEVER get as close of a shave as you would get with a razor blade.   1425. For years I thought my trusty Norelco shaver was the cat's meow. I would intersperse daily shaving with an occasional safety razor (Gillette Fusion) shave maybe three or four times a month just to remember the feel of a nice close, smooth shave. When the Norelco died after many years I sought electric shaver performance that would allow me to discontinue the use of a good safety razor. After reading both positive and negative reviews of various brands sold by Amazon I purchased the Panasonic ES-LA63-S. I frankly could not believe how close and comfortable my first voyage was with this shaver. I haven't considered a safety razor shave since the Panasonic arrival about four months ago. This is not an inexpensive shaver; but worth every dollar in performance. The only two negatives are 1: no shaver stand and 2: the carry case could be a bit larger to accommodate both the shaver and the charger adaptor cord comfortably. I'm baffled why Panasonic didn't include these low cost features with a classy product. Nevertheless, small potatoes once you have tried this shaver. Five stars. Enjoy!

  1433. I've been using for a couple weeks now, I like it, but I'm not in love with it. I will say, it performs substantially better than previous shavers I've used, and I have had both straight foil and the circular shaver for comparison. No electric shaver that I'm aware of is capable of getting as close as a blade, but the trade off is that the stubble this shaver leaves seams a little softer, or less sharp, especially once 5 o'clock rolls around.<br />The head does maintain good contact with the skin and I have to do fewer passes than I did with previous shavers, but because the head is so large, it makes actually seeing what I'm shaving, ie: sideburns, goatee, difficult to get really clean edges on. Furthermore, the trimmer on the back of the head requires some clever angling in the mirror to see what I'm cutting. Also, as with most, if not all shavers, the neck can be a bit tricky, requiring a few extra passes.<br />Gripes aside, the battery does seem to have a fairly long life, I've only charged it once since I got it almost 2 weeks ago and is just approaching the point where it needs to be charged again, so 8-12 shaves on a charge is quite realistic.<br />The motor is very fast, and not much louder than a sonic toothbrush. That is to say, it's clearly audible, but not likely to disturb anyone who isn't an extremely light sleeper, if that's a concern for you. Furthermore, the vibration isn't too obtrusive and it has a system that makes it run at full speed at all times rather than slowly fizzling out and pulling rather than just cutting. The electronic display is kind of nice too.<br />Since it is a wet/dry shaver, cleaning is super easy, and makes the other models with the cleaning station seam a little unnecessary. The one caveat I would mention here is that the shaver has no flat surfaces and just kind of wobbles wherever it is set down, this would be the one reason I could see getting the cleaning station, but I'm not sure it's worth an extra $100+cost ofrefills. the solution I've worked out is to just leave it partly out of its travel case while it's drying.<br />On the whole, I can't give it 5 stars for the reasons I've mentioned, it's not perfect, but this is not to say that this is a much better shaver than many on the market, and the build quality and design do justify the cost, and I would still recommend this shaver.
  1434. I needed to upgrade my razor after my old one started to get too old. This has been a good razor so far. With all the technology and layers of razors put into it I was a bit surprised that some hairs on my face still struggle to get shaven off. I'm not blown away by the quality of the shave, but it effectively gets the job done. The only other annoying thing is that you can't turn the razor on to shave while its plugged in and charging. So make sure enough of the battery is charged first if you need to use it.
